fields.headline: Keane wins the double
fields.trailText: Roy Keane last night completed an awards double as he added the Professional Footballers Association player of the year prize to the football writers gong he won earlier this week.
fields.body:
Roy Keane last night completed an awards double as he added the Professional Footballers Association player of the year prize to the football writers gong he won earlier this week.

The Manchester United and Republic of Ireland captain headed Sunderland striker Kevin Phillips and Harry Kewell of Leeds, who were also second and third respectively in Friday's footballer of the year poll.

Kewell was also presented with the award for young player of the year, finishing ahead of Coventry's Robbie Keane and Steven Gerrard of Liverpool in the nominations.

Keane, who received his award from FIFA president Sepp Blatter at London's Grosvenor House Hotel, has been heavily criticised this season for his hounding of referees.

But there is no doubting the influence he has on his United team-mates and his leadership qualities have been a major factor in the Old Trafford club wrapping up the Premiership title in record time.

Keane also features in the PFA team of the year alongside United colleagues David Beckham, Jaap Stam and Andy Cole.

Leeds, who remained hot on the heels of their Manchester title rivals for much of the season, also have four players in the top team, with Kewell joined by goalkeeper Nigel Martyn, Gary Kelly and Ian Harte.

The nominations are completed by Phillips, Liverpool defender Sami Hyypia and Arsenal midfielder Patrick Vieira.

webTitle: Rangers wrap up the title in style

fields.headline: Rangers wrap up the title in style
fields.trailText: Rangers produced some second-half fireworks to make sure their 49th championship-winning party went with a bang after Dundee had threatened to gate-crash their celebrations.
fields.body:
Rangers produced some second-half fireworks to make sure their 49th championship-winning party went with a bang after Dundee had threatened to gate-crash their celebrations.

The Dens Park side are the only Scottish club to have inflicted defeat on Rangers - at Ibrox last November - so Rangers knew that this was by no means a formality and for 52 minutes the visitors left them frustrated.

But with manager Dick Advocaat ready to hold aloft the trophy for the second time in two years in charge nothing was going to spoil their day.

Rangers turned up the heat and Billy Dodds, Neil McCann and Seb Rozental proved the lives and souls of the party to make sure their 12th title out of 14 years was celebrated in style.

The last time these two met was in February when Dundee were on the receiving end of a 7-1 mauling at Dens Park and Rangers started like a side determined run up a similar scoreline. But they were finding it difficult to break the Dundee defence down in the early exchanges and were restricted to long-range efforts.

German midfielder Jorg Albertz had clear sight on goal in the sixth minute when teed up by the lively Billy Dodds but he dragged his shot wide of Douglas' post from just outside the box.

Rangers' final ball around the area was also letting them down but Dundee were posing little threat in the opposition half as they tried to get behind the ball at every opportunity.

The champions, however, did have the ball in the net in the 18th minute only for it to be ruled out because the ball had gone out of play when McCann crossed from the by-line from Albertz's through-all for Rozental to slide home.

But Rangers came within a whisker of taking the lead in the 21st minute when the impressive Claudio Reyna crossed for McCann, who hit a shot first time which saw goalkeeper Robert Douglas get enough of a touch to push it onto the bar.

The home side again threatened in the 31st minute when Arthur Numan picked out Dodds in the box and the little striker spun and drove his effort on target but Douglas pulled off a comfortable save low to his left. Dundee sent out a warning in the 33rd minute that they could cause another upset when Steven Boyack cut inside Barry Ferguson before unleashing a low drive that Stefan Klos did well to hold onto.

Rozental then wasted a good chance in the 37th minute when the goal opened up for him after a ball from Numan but the Chilean striker fired well wide of the goal.

Albertz stung the fingers of Douglas from 25 yards in the 41st minute that the goalkeeper only just managed to push over the crossbar.

From the resulting corner the Dundee defence left Albertz in-swinging kick and Lee Wilkie's outstretched leg could have diverted the ball anywhere but luckily for him it flew over the bar.

But in the 44th minute Rangers were given their best opportunity of the half. Rozental put Andrei Kanchelskis through but he chose to play it back to him and the chance went begging.

It was one-way traffic again after the restart as Rangers continued to probe but the supporters were becoming increasingly frustrated as the final ball went astray on a number of occasions.

But the crowd came to life in the 53rd minute when Rangers got the goal they deserved after some brilliant play down the right from McCann.

The winger took Albertz's strong pass down superbly on the chest before bursting into the box and playing it off to Dodds, who swivelled and drove home past Douglas.

Rangers smelled blood and in the 55th minute Albertz should have made it two when Kanchelskis crossed from the right and the German blasted over.

But the fans did not have to wait too long before they were celebrating again when Albertz's dangerously in-swinging corner was not cleared and McCann had the easiest of chances to fire home from close range.

Dodds should have got his second of the match moments later when Albertz' corner found its way to his feet but Douglas pulled off a great save to deny him.

Albertz then produced a spectacular volley from a Kanchelskis corner in the 67th minute that went inches past the upright.

But Rangers' celebrations went to another level in moments later when Finnish striker Jonatan Johansson came on to replace Dodds for his first appearance since being injured at Aberdeen in December.

There was nothing that could stop Rangers now and it was Rozental's turn to cash in on their dominance in the 72nd minute when he fired past Douglas from close range.

But Rangers had done enough to make sure that a special day was made perfect and triggered celebrations in Glasgow that were ready to go long into the night.

fields.headline: Ambition and skill
fields.trailText: Anne-Sophie Mutter/ Lambert Orkis Barbican Hall, London ****
fields.body:
Anne-Sophie Mutter/ Lambert Orkis Barbican Hall, London ****

Sharing its title with a well-known sci-fi movie, Back To The Future is Anne-Sophie Mutter's much-hyped retrospective of the 20th-century violin repertoire. Described as a "subjective choice", the series is also a celebration of Mutter's own achievement as a contemporary music performer. Some of it comes over as self-congratulatory, but she has reason to be proud: no other high-profile violinist has so assiduously championed and commissioned new music .

The task Mutter has set herself - 15 works in five concerts in a week - is punishing, and it's hardly surprising that her playing has been inconsistent. The first two concerts, re-uniting her with the pianist Lambert Orkis, were given over to chamber music, culminating in the world premiere of Penderecki's Second Sonata. An uneven enormity, this does too much with too little thematic material, though it also exploits to perfection Mutter's stratospheric lyricism and explosive pizzicati.

Flaws were apparent. Mutter's fondness for filing down her vibrato led to sagging pitch in Shostakovich's Second Piano Trio, in which she and Orkis were joined by the excellent cellist Daniel Müller-Schott. Ravel's Tzigane didn't thrill.

Some of it was remarkable. Bartok's Second Sonata was overwhelming in its precision and intensity. George Crumb's Four Nocturnes sent shivers down the spine. Time will tell whether Mutter has been over-ambitious with this series, but the best of it promises to be very exciting indeed.

webTitle: How to net a new job

fields.headline: How to net a new job
fields.standfirst: With thousands of vacancies now advertised online, and sites fighting to attract admin staff, has the net become the best way to change career?  Claire Phipps  reports
fields.trailText: With thousands of vacancies now advertised online, and sites fighting to attract admin staff, has the net become the best way to change career? Claire Phipps reports.
fields.body:
If you thought the internet was a cool way to buy baked beans from Sainsbury's, try using it to find a new career. Type the word "jobs" into a search engine and you'll be rewarded with a world wide web worth of sites, each claiming to have details of the job you really really want. The statistics on jobs online are certainly more enticing than those offered in a few pages of grubby newsprint: 6,427 jobs on cityjobs.com, rising to 22,292 on totaljobs.com and an impressive 74,898 advertised on gisajob.com. The position of your dreams must be in there somewhere.

If only it were that easy. Looking on "the internet" means, in effect, searching through countless sites, all with different criteria for listing vacancies, and with varying quality of information. For a start, you are only looking for one job, but have to find it among many thousands that you would never consider. With such an enormous volume of data, it makes sense to assume that many positions posted on these sites are duplicated elsewhere online, so the thousands of possible new opportunities might in the end come down to a handful.

Even if you have managed to narrow your search to a few positions that interest you, there can still be problems. Katie Portwin is the co-editor of Jobberwacky.co.uk, a new independent online guide to job hunting on the internet. She has found that different sites expect varying levels of commitment from the applicant. "Some request your CV as a Word document, which is easy enough," she says. "But others want you to fill in exhausting forms with so many mandatory fields that you give up before you get through them. You have to be very sure of what you're looking for."

Victoria Lubbock, managing director of online recruitment consultancy recruitmedia.co.uk, agrees. "Job hunters need to define exactly what information they want and what information they are prepared to leave about themselves." It is wise to seek reassurance about how widely your details will be circulated - post your CV on a site that doesn't require you to approve all the companies that it's sent out to, and your details could end up on the laptop of your current employer. With estimates suggesting that more than 100m CVs will be circulating on the internet in the next 10 years, keeping track of who has your personal details could become impossible.

IT positions are still the most likely to be advertised online, but the boom in job sites has sparked a scramble to attract jobseekers in all fields. As recently as last year, the number of visitors to UK job sites was too low for web auditors MMXI Europe to register. By January 2000, enough people were using the sites for it to be officially labelled "a trend", with more than 1% of the internet population clicking on to the much-trailed site monster.com. Within a month, the figures doubled. Stepstone.co.uk came top, with 265,000 unique visitors (site users are counted only once, no matter how many times they visit - Stepstone claims 1.9m hits per month). As the number of users increases, sites need more jobs to keep them coming.

And secretaries and support staff have become prime targets. Most secretaries now have internet access in the office and are frequent readers of online job ads. But recruitment agencies claim that they can find good candidates without advertising beyond the agency's own website, leaving other online employment services with few jobs to splash on their own sites. As a result, these agency jobs can often pop up unauthorised on unofficial sites to beef up their secretarial sections.

It may seem a confusing process, but there are a few simple pointers to guide you through the soup of job data online. Established recruitment agencies are the obvious place to start: most now have an online arm that allows job hunters to pluck details of positions that meet their criteria. Some may require candidates to register for job searches, and most will have an element of face-to-face (or phone-to-phone) conversation. Recruitmedia post extensive client information online so that applicants can start the process knowing something about their potential bosses; the agency also interviews all candidates before recommending them to employers. "There's no piece of software that can determine culture, style and personality fit," says Lubbock.

But not all online job sites exercise such controls, as established agencies hasten to point out. Jane Littlefield, manager of the secretarial division at recruitment consultancy Joslin Rowe, is concerned at the proliferation of websites that promise to pair CVs to job ads. She argues that these sites are often under pressure from advertisers to generate as much internet traffic through the site as possible - and that means having as many jobs as possible, from whatever source. Jobs advertised on official sites can be copied on to less scrupulous web addresses. "The more well-known sites are displaying jobs that they are authorised to display," she says. "But many of the others can't fill their sites without taking jobs from elsewhere. And they're not committed to monitoring or policing those ads in the way we do."

It may annoy agencies, but isn't it providing a service for users? Littlefield concedes that job searchers might find it useful, but warns that these sites are often slow to update their information. "The internet is now the best database in the world," she says, "but when candidates ring us about positions they have seen advertised elsewhere, and the job became inactive months ago, it reflects badly on us. They want to know why we are still advertising it, and we have to admit that we didn't know anything about it."

"The billboard lists of jobs don't have consultants behind them," agrees Lubbock. "There's too much choice. If you want to be represented, you need to go to a recruitment agency, and a reputable one at that."

Agencies have been on the defensive since a stinging DTI report last year branded many of them cowboys. Much has been done since to clean up the industry, but some fear that the explosion in online job sites could see them forced once again to defend their reputation. Tim Richardson, chief executive of the Recruitment and Employment Federation, the professional standards body for the industry, welcomes the newcomers, but thinks guidelines will be needed. "The government does need to keep an eye on this, and it will require co-ordination between the different companies to find out what the codes of practice should be. The online sites are changing our industry, and some people are concerned by the fact that it's still a new thing. But it's the good sites that will survive."

Some believe that regulation is the only answer, although, as always, the problem of policing the internet is the major hurdle. "Sites should have to contact companies to ask if they can use their job ads online," says Littlefield. "At the moment, anyone can set up a job site, and while they can, they will." But Victoria Lubbock has doubts. "There are sharks out there, as with all industries. But this happens everywhere. You can't control what appears online."

fields.headline: Site seeing
fields.standfirst: At a glance... your guide to the online jobs jungle. By Claire Phipps
fields.trailText: At a glance... your guide to the online jobs jungle. By Claire Phipps
fields.body:
The agency sites
Five years ago, even the big secretarial agencies didn't have websites, but most now list their job information online. Don't expect to find all their vacancies on the website: some are more comprehensive than others, and most will still expect candidates to contact a consultant to discuss their application and other vacancies.

Candidates do not go through the entire application process over the net; usually you simply register online, although the more sophisticated sites will forward your details electronically to companies. Some agency sites, such as reed.co.uk, carry ads for other agencies that might not be up to the minute, although Reed does at least warn job hunters of this.

Katie Portwin of web job guide Jobberwacky warns that some agencies advertise non-existent jobs to encourage applicants to register with them - plenty of client information is usually a good sign.

Agency sites often carry advertising, but as the net is a small part of their business, they don't need you to log on to make their money.

The online classifieds
Traditional job ad publishers now routinely carry them online too. The Guardian's own site, jobsunlimited.co.uk, has all the jobs published in the print version, and as such carries more secretarial ads than any other national British paper. Other good sources are loot.com, bigbluedog.co.uk (from the Evening Standard, so primarily London-based), appointments-plus.com (from the Daily Telegraph) and fish4jobs.co.uk, which carries ads from local papers - good for regional searches. Essentially the same as the print versions, but customisable search options will take you straight to the jobs which meet your criteria. Some sites provide additional services, such as training information, advice on interviews and assistance with CVs.

The new boys
The big growth area. When web auditors MMXI surveyed job sites in January this year, only one, monster.co.uk, had significant numbers of visitors. Now three others have hit the big time: stepstone.co.uk, topjobs.co.uk and jobsite.co.uk. If your employment horizons stretch beyond the City, these can give you the bigger picture: Stepstone alone has nearly 85,000 job vacancies across Europe. As these are not tied to particular agencies, the range of positions advertised is huge - but this does mean you need to use very specific search terms.

These aren't consultancies, so don't expect too much personal assistance, but they do carry a lot of information. After you register, most will send you regular email updates of new jobs which suit your specifications. Companies are usually responsible for keeping ads up to date and for removing them once filled (so the sites themselves can't help if information is missing or wrong). Companies also pay to be listed here, so job vacancies tend to be genuine.

Temping
Uncharted territory compared to the others, but temp sites claim to give temps more control over the jobs they choose. Specialist secretarial recruiter tempz.com launches this week, claiming to be the world's first fully online temp agency. The whole recruitment process is completed online, with would-be temps and employers communicating directly through the site, and all personal details are kept secure.

The advantage, says tempz.com, is that the company saves money on "bricks and mortar" costs, theoretically allowing it to pass on the savings to temps and employers in higher rates and lower fees. More than 2,500 temps are already registered; tempjobs.com is also worth a look.

Listings
Good for information, but it is not always clear how up to date job ads are - and certainly don't expect to be offered any career guidance. These sites are usually short on design and gimmicks (for example, jobmart.co.uk), and consist of lists of jobs taken from other sources - with or without authorisation. The Jobberwacky researchers were unimpressed by several of these sites: for instance they found jobtrack.co.uk to be short on jobs and time-consuming when trying to search the database or register an interest: a definite miss.

Some of these sites are fine for those willing to promote themselves on the net, but if you want to control who sees your CV, be selective when posting it with a job site. Sites such as workfinder.co.uk and jobtrack.co.uk volunteer little information about how secure your details will be.

Questions to ask:

 Has the ad been posted with the company's/agency's permission?

If not, it might be out of date, and details could be incorrect. Similarly, if there's no application deadline or a lack of firm information on the job or employer, be suspicious. The job could be fictitious.

 Who can see your CV when it's posted online?

Reputable companies will allow access only to selected employers, or will forward it only with your agreement.

 Can you change CV details? And are you the only one who has authority to do so?

If this information - or anything else you need to know - isn't available online, there should be a number to contact for answers. They should be happy to give you details on security, client information, etc. But most sites don't work as traditional consultancies, and you will be expected to guide yourself through the process. If there's no number, you might wonder how interested they are in your search.
fields.bodyText: The agency sites Five years ago, even the big secretarial agencies didn't have websites, but most now list their job information online. Don't expect to find all their vacancies on the website: some are more comprehensive than others, and most will still expect candidates to contact a consultant to discuss their application and other vacancies. Candidates do not go through the entire application process over the net; usually you simply register online, although the more sophisticated sites will forward your details electronically to companies. Some agency sites, such as reed.co.uk, carry ads for other agencies that might not be up to the minute, although Reed does at least warn job hunters of this. Katie Portwin of web job guide Jobberwacky warns that some agencies advertise non-existent jobs to encourage applicants to register with them - plenty of client information is usually a good sign. Agency sites often carry advertising, but as the net is a small part of their business, they don't need you to log on to make their money. The online classifieds Traditional job ad publishers now routinely carry them online too. The Guardian's own site, jobsunlimited.co.uk, has all the jobs published in the print version, and as such carries more secretarial ads than any other national British paper. Other good sources are loot.com, bigbluedog.co.uk (from the Evening Standard, so primarily London-based), appointments-plus.com (from the Daily Telegraph) and fish4jobs.co.uk, which carries ads from local papers - good for regional searches. Essentially the same as the print versions, but customisable search options will take you straight to the jobs which meet your criteria. Some sites provide additional services, such as training information, advice on interviews and assistance with CVs. The new boys The big growth area. When web auditors MMXI surveyed job sites in January this year, only one, monster.co.uk, had significant numbers of visitors. Now three others have hit the big time: stepstone.co.uk, topjobs.co.uk and jobsite.co.uk. If your employment horizons stretch beyond the City, these can give you the bigger picture: Stepstone alone has nearly 85,000 job vacancies across Europe. As these are not tied to particular agencies, the range of positions advertised is huge - but this does mean you need to use very specific search terms. These aren't consultancies, so don't expect too much personal assistance, but they do carry a lot of information. After you register, most will send you regular email updates of new jobs which suit your specifications. Companies are usually responsible for keeping ads up to date and for removing them once filled (so the sites themselves can't help if information is missing or wrong). Companies also pay to be listed here, so job vacancies tend to be genuine. Temping Uncharted territory compared to the others, but temp sites claim to give temps more control over the jobs they choose. Specialist secretarial recruiter tempz.com launches this week, claiming to be the world's first fully online temp agency. The whole recruitment process is completed online, with would-be temps and employers communicating directly through the site, and all personal details are kept secure. The advantage, says tempz.com, is that the company saves money on "bricks and mortar" costs, theoretically allowing it to pass on the savings to temps and employers in higher rates and lower fees. More than 2,500 temps are already registered; tempjobs.com is also worth a look. Listings Good for information, but it is not always clear how up to date job ads are - and certainly don't expect to be offered any career guidance. These sites are usually short on design and gimmicks (for example, jobmart.co.uk), and consist of lists of jobs taken from other sources - with or without authorisation. The Jobberwacky researchers were unimpressed by several of these sites: for instance they found jobtrack.co.uk to be short on jobs and time-consuming when trying to search the database or register an interest: a definite miss. Sites such as workfinder.co.uk and jobtrack.co.uk volunteer little information about how secure your details will be. Questions to ask:  Has the ad been posted with the company's/agency's permission? If not, it might be out of date, and details could be incorrect. Similarly, if there's no application deadline or a lack of firm information on the job or employer, be suspicious. The job could be fictitious.  Who can see your CV when it's posted online? Reputable companies will allow access only to selected employers, or will forward it only with your agreement.  Can you change CV details? And are you the only one who has authority to do so? If this information - or anything else you need to know - isn't available online, there should be a number to contact for answers. They should be happy to give you details on security, client information, etc. But most sites don't work as traditional consultancies, and you will be expected to guide yourself through the process. If there's no number, you might wonder how interested they are in your search.

fields.headline: Best forgotten
fields.trailText: Macbeth False Memory Lyric Studio, Hammersmith **
fields.body:
Macbeth False Memory Lyric Studio, Hammersmith **

Back in 1937 James Thurber wrote The Macbeth Murder Mystery, proving that Lady Macbeth's father killed the king. I just wish Deborah Levy's "21st-century thriller", presented in multi-media form by the touring ATC, had a tenth of the wit and style of Thurber's parodic whodunit.

Levy's aim is to use our vague memories of Macbeth to create a brand new work, but what she comes up with never grips or excites. We see, on film, a stolid businessman called Bennet dining with and then stabbing a bisexual Italian named Lavelli. At home he is plagued by phone calls from Lavelli's suspicious elder daughter while Mrs Bennet talks to the dead Italian in her sleep. We wait, impatiently, for the gruesome confrontation between the vengeful daughter and the murderous suburbanites.

As a thriller this is daft: what kind of killer would answer a dead man's mobile and reveal his identity? Levy's attempts to give the story a philosophical underpinning make matters worse. The best one can say is that the film inserts in Nick Philippou's production are stylishly done and that the actors, led by Jonathan Lermit as the killer and Myriam Acharki as the avenging daughter, perform with commitment. But the total effect is of watching slow-cooking tripe.

At the Lyric Studio (020 8741 2311) till May 20 and then on tour.

webTitle: Both had a love of dark orchestral sonorities

fields.headline: Both had a love of dark orchestral sonorities
fields.trailText: City of Birmingham SO/Oramo Birmingham Symphony Hall
fields.body:
City of Birmingham SO/Oramo Birmingham Symphony Hall

The Finn Sibelius and the Russian Prokofiev are not an obvious musical coupling. But the first concert in the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra's Prokofiev/Sibelius series showed that the two composers had more in common than the fact that they were born and grew up on much the same latitude.

Both had a love of dark orchestral sonorities, and to make Sibelius's Second Symphony and Prokofiev's Second Violin Concerto work, performers need to think in very long melodic spans. Russian violinist Vadim Repin is a natural when it comes to the long phrase: Prokofiev's seemingly endless lines soared and sang. The much-loved slow movement can seem frustratingly episodic, but Repin made the ideas flow effortlessly forward. His tone was full, round and intense. Perhaps there could have been more variety of colour, but it was the kind of playing that gripped the attention.

Conductor Sakari Oramo took risks in Sibelius's Second Symphony. The big climaxes of the second movement and the finale's magnificent ending were taken unusually slowly, but the tension never flagged and the orchestra followed Oramo's beat to the micro-second. Not only was each movement seen whole; the entire symphony emerged as a single drama, emotionally and intellectually compelling, and leading inexorably to that great, trumpet-capped apotheosis.

French music and culture have been hugely influential on the Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho. But listening to her fine orchestral fantasy Du Cristal it was hard to avoid comparison with Sibelius - and even Prokofiev. This is not melodic music in any conventional sense, more an extended play of textures and repeating patterns; but Saariaho also thinks in very long lines. The ear is drawn in and held as securely as in a wide- arching Prokofiev or Sibelius tune.

The capacity audience listened hard and applauded warmly - a tribute not only to the vitality of the music, but also to the CBSO's confident, enthusiastic playing.

fields.headline: Wolves given a hand
fields.trailText: Huddersfield, who would have virtually clinched their place in the promotion play-off zone had they beaten Stockport at home, subjected themselves to a period of agonising uncertainty through crashing 2-0.
fields.body:
Huddersfield, who would have virtually clinched their place in the promotion play-off zone had they beaten Stockport at home, subjected themselves to a period of agonising uncertainty through crashing 2-0.

That surprising lapse means that Wolves, with two matches in hand, will close the gap to Huddersfield to three points if they beat Fulham today. Bolton, with one match in hand, have also been given hope. They moved to within four points of Huddersfield by winning 3-1 at Crewe.

Huddersfield conceded both goals in the opening 15 minutes - the second an own goal by Craig Armstrong. 'We made a real pig's ear of it,' admitted Huddersfield manager Steve Bruce. 'It was a terrible, terrible result for us. But it is still in our own hands, and we have to be positive.'

Bolton's match was followed by an attack on their striker Dean Holdsworth by Crewe's manager, Dario Gradi. He described as challenge by Holdsworth on midfielder Kenny Lunt as 'unarmed thuggery'. He added: 'I thought we would be playing against 10 men and we should have, I have got no time for that.'

But Bolton manager Sam Allardyce insisted: 'If Dario calls that thuggery I must have been a complete animal when I played. I thought Holdsworth went in with his body and got the ball.'

The situation on the edge of the First Division relegation zone has also become more tense, with Walsall and West Bromwich Albion now level on points. While West Brom drew 0-0 at QPR, Walsall - in the third-from-bottom spot - overcame Portsmouth 1-0 through a 13th-minute strike by Pedro Matias.

Walsall's success, though, was marred by a fan being apprehended by stewards and handed over to the West Midlands Police for allegedly racially abusing Portsmouth's black winger Kevin Harper during the game.

He had been spotted by referee Mark Halsey in the first-half running level with Harper and allegedly shouting abuse. The official approached senior stewards and told them to get the man out of the ground.

Inspector Paul Marriott, the police match commander, said statements were being taken from the referee, players and any other witnesses and it was likely the man would be charged.

As for the football, Walsall manager Ray Graydon, whose team face Ipswich next Sunday, said: 'We have achieved what we set out to do - go into the last game still alive.'

West Brom's manager, Gary Megson, was also upbeat. Megson said: 'I think it was a decent point today I fully expected Walsall to beat Portsmouth but I don't expect too many people expected us to get a point down here.'

I was celebration time for Jan Molby's Kidderminster. Though they lost 1-0 at Woking, Rushden and Diamonds' failure to get more than a goalless draw at home to Scarborough enabled them to clinch the Conference title, and promotion to the league.

The promotion is doubly sweet as six years ago. Kidderminster won the championship but could not make the necessary ground improvements in time to take their place in the League.

Crystal Palace announced that they are close to securing an agreement that will secure the long-term future of the club. They then celebrated the news by coming from behind to beat Blackburn 2-1. Blackburn did make life difficult for themselves, though - they had Lee Carsley.

fields.headline: Ginola: 'I've wasted my career here'
fields.trailText: Denis Campbell talks to David Ginola, who believes he has wasted the best years of his career by playing in the Premiership.
fields.body:
David Ginola believes he has wasted the best years of his career by playing in the Premiership.

Ginola, who was voted Footballer of the Year last year, has enjoyed living in England, and even intends to stay in London rather than return to France when he retires from the game - but his biggest regret is not having moved to Barcelona when he had two opportunities to do so in 1995 and 1996.

In an exclusive interview for The Observer, the Frenchman says, 'When I look at the past and I think about my quality, my skills, what I'm capable of on the pitch, I really deserve to have played in a really top team.

'I will not say that Newcastle and Tottenham are not big teams. But when I talk big I mean Milan, Barcelona, Manchester United - teams who are playing year in, year out at the top level, playing for the biggest prizes.'

Ginola left Paris St Germain to join Newcastle, then managed by Kevin Keegan, in the summer of 1995 and moved to Spurs three years ago. His first attempt to sign for Barcelona came before the Bosman ruling and was thwarted by the number of foreigners at the Catalan club, and the second time, when Bobby Robson was in charge at the Nou Camp, Newcastle would not let him go.

'This kind of thing really frustrates me,' says Ginola, who is clearly unhappy at Tottenham's lack of ambition.

If he had played four or five years at Barcelona 'I know I would be huge', he says. 'People who know me, they all know that I am really wasting my talent.'

Ginola, 33, does not rule out a career in management, or possibly in films, when he quits.

fields.headline: Egil's not a family man
fields.trailText: Alan Smith, the man who bought Plough Lane, on the plight of the Crazy Gang.
fields.body:
With Wimbledon facing a do-or-die relegation battle at Bradford this afternoon, the question asked most frequently is this: Have the Crazy Gang lost their famous spirit?

I would have to say the answer is yes, although it hurts me to admit it.

My associations with the club go back to their non-league days, when I was a youth coach. Sam Hammam, the flamboyant owner who recently relinquished control, still tells me I am one of 'the family' because I negotiated the purchase of the freehold of their Plough Lane ground for £100,000 many years ago.

But the whole Crazy Gang thing goes back before then, before Vinnie Jones or the rest were there.

The original guy who started it was Allen Batsford, who took them into the Football League in 1977. He'd been a very successful manager in non-league football, first with Walton and Hersham and then Wimbledon. He brought in top non-League players such as Roger Connell, Dickie Guy and Dave Bassett as captain.

Bassett has mellowed now, but he had one of the worst disciplinary records in non-League football and was a real hard man. So was Batsford, who could be terrifying. I remember one occasion, when as a young coach, he asked me to take the first team one day when he had flu.

I had just passed my coaching exams and was full of great ideas, and I showed the players some old cine films of Pele and Brazil playing the beautiful game. Unfortunately we lost the next day, our first defeat in 14 games, and Batsford was furious. He stormed into the dressing room, flung the films away, with celluloid everywhere, and let me know in no uncertain terms that I had fouled up.

I had such a panic after the incident that I inadvertently left the ground with his keys. I only realised this when I got home, but didn't have the nerve to own up to it so I buried them in the garden.

It was only about 15 years later, when Crystal Palace got to the FA Cup final and he came to Wembley as my guest, that I felt able to admit what I had done.

But that is how tough he was - you expected to have your legs cut off if you fouled up. He even got angry with Mike Batt from the Wombles pop group because Batsford thought it was disrespectful for the club to be linked with Uncle Bulgaria and the rest!

But that is where the true spirit of Wimbledon came from and Bassett took it on when he took over as manager, following a short spell from Dario Gradi. Dario was a very good coach and successful manager but was not perceived to have the right personality by Ron Noades, who was chairman at the time.

Even then, Noades had a way of alienating many of the players but I always felt that helped to build team spirit, which has been based on a them-and-us situation. I had left to manage Dulwich Hamlet but I went back to Wimbledon for a year under Bassett, and I have to say it was the most remarkable year of my life.

There was a unique spirit about the place, with people like Wally Downes who invented the Crazy Gang nickname, and some of the antics were incredible - certainly not the sort of thing you could relate in a respectable newspaper.

By this time Sam Hammam had bought out Noades, who took over at Palace and offered me a job as youth team manager. Bassett took it as a personal slight and didn't really speak to me for the next five years, which shows how bitter he could be if anyone left his 'gang'.

Incidentally, we get on fine now, and he has mellowed considerably from those days. Bassett was a real grafter and worked very hard. With Dave you couldn't get away with anything. That is what kept the hardness and hunger about the team, and continued when people like Don Howe, Ray Harford and Joe Kinnear were in charge.

Kinnear was the ideal man for Wimbledon because he had that great attitude where he really didn't care what anyone thought - he was his own man. He was made for that job and is still underestimated for what he did at Wimbledon.

When he had his heart attack last March, the wheels started to come off. From being a top six side on the verge of Wembley, Wimbledon hardly won a game for the rest of the season.

The idea of bringing in someone from abroad as manager was never going to work. I've met Egil Olsen several times, and used to go out to Norway to see him when he was national manager.

I like him as a person and respect his record at international level. He was also a very good player, probably one of the best in the history of Norwegian football, but I don't think he can grasp the mentality at Wimbledon Football Club with his background.

A lot of people in the game think he is simply the wrong man for the job. He said recently that he could not understand the emphasis here on team spirit and commitment. That shows how much he has failed to grasp what makes Wimbledon tick.

In any team, if that bond between manager and the players is taken away it will never work. It's becoming clear now that some of the current group of players want to move on. The most important players in Wimbledon's past - Dave Beasant, Wally Downes, Vinny Jones and Dickie Guy - all believed that being part of the Crazy Gang was something special. The same goes for people like Noades and Hammam, Batsford, Bassett and Kinnear. It's not just about tactics. You need a special bond.

At least bringing Terry Burton as coach last week should have put back some of the old spirit. Terry and Mick Harford understand what the club is all about.

But I fear it may be too late to save Wimbledon from finally falling off the tightrope and dropping into the First Division.

At least bringing Terry Burton as coach last week should have put back some of the old spirit. Terry and Mick Harford understand what the club is all about. But I fear it may be too late to save Wimbledon from finally falling off the tightrope and dropping into the First Division.

fields.headline: Dreyer's life less ordinary
fields.trailText: Oliver Kay on the veteran defender's late burst of fame
fields.body:
For the first time in eight years of playing top-flight football, John Dreyer was given the celebrity treatment this week. Much to his surprise, he was heavily in demand at Bradford City's weekly press conference, an affair usually dominated by 'names' such as Dean Saunders and Lee Sharpe. What a difference a goal makes.

With his 37th birthday just six weeks away, the defender is finally enjoying his Warholian quarter of an hour. He has become something of a local hero since his goal at Sunderland on Monday, his first for four years, kept alive his club's hopes of avoiding relegation ahead of today's vital match against Wimbledon.

Dreyer's well-timed arrival at the far post at the Stadium of Light caught more than just Sunderland by surprise; never a household name, he has even raised a few eyebrows among his fellow professionals by enjoying an Indian summer in the Bradford defence this season.

'We played against Leicester earlier in the season,' Dreyer explained. 'Beforehand I bumped into Steve Guppy, who I know from when I was at Stoke, and he was at Port Vale. He just said: "My God. Are you still here? I thought you had retired." I think he was being serious. You do get forgotten very quickly if you're not playing.'

Never mind forgotten, Dreyer has even had to contend with being treated as an unknown this week. He was intrigued to read in a newspaper that his appearance at Sunderland was 'only his third game in the top flight' when in fact he spent every year between 1985 and 1992 playing against the best forwards in the land and, more often than not, fighting against relegation.

'I have actually played most of my career in the top division but people probably aren't aware of that fact,' he said. 'I can only assume it's because I've been at less fashionable clubs, like Oxford United and Luton Town, and also because of the timing.

'They didn't have Match of the Day then because it was banned and there wasn't anything like as much media attention.

'We got relegated with Luton the year the Premier League started and that's when the game really took off, with Sky and so on. Basically, because there's more public interest now than ever before, players have been elevated to greater heights.'

The defender has more grounds than most to talk of his peers in the third person, having done time in the 'real world' and waited until the grand old age of 21 before turning professional. While his current room-mate Neville Southall - 'he's from my era' - was winning the FA Cup with Everton, Dreyer was playing for Wallingford Town in the Hellenic Division.

Football was a mere distraction as he began a traineeship as a technical illustrator with Rover. His subsequent relocations as a footballer mean he does not know how Rover's uncertain future will affect his former colleagues, but he is not without empathy for them.

'When you put things into that kind of perspective, we shouldn't be talking about it being tragic if a football club gets relegated,' he said. 'Put it into context and it's not the end of the world, not when you realise what other people have to deal with.'

Dreyer, in common with all at Valley Parade, is confident that Bradford can avert the threat of relegation against Wimbledon. He has mixed memories of similarly pivotal encounters from his days with Oxford and Luton but, with the voice of experience, warned that such matches are not for the faint of heart.

'I've been in this position on a number of occasions,' he said. 'Three times we had to win the last game of the season to stay up and did it. But there was also a game with Luton where we lost at Notts County and went down. I just hope we don't freeze on the day.'

Having finally acquired a taste for the high life this week, Dreyer is not about to surrender it without a fight.

fields.headline: Taylor's in by a nose
fields.trailText: Gillingham 2 - 0 Brentford
fields.body:
A year ago at Wembley, Gillingham were a minute away from being promoted to the First Division for the first time in their history. They were denied by Manchester City who now stand a point away from the Premiership... a position they reached thanks to a goal from Bob Taylor, signed from Gillingham last November. What might have been?

Despite selling their best player - Taylor remains their highest goalscorer for the season with double the tally of his nearest challenger - Gillingham remain very much in contention. At the start of play in the tightest finish in the leagues here's how it stood: one from Wigan, Burnley, Gillingham, Millwall, Bristol Rovers and Stoke would go up automatically, four would go into the play-offs, and one would miss out.

Gillingham started confidently. Dominating the play was Andy Hessenthaler - player-coach, claims unconvincingly to be 5ft 7in, as broad as he is tall - who drifted out to the left to good effect. But the nerves quickly set in. Brentford, 11 games without a win, belied their recent form with some attractive approach play only to confirm it with dithering in the area.

Some chances went Gillingham's way. The best of which fell to Carl Asaba whose fierce shot nearly knocked Woodman through his own goal. News arrived that Millwall were losing 2-0 and Wigan 1-0. Other results were going their way, a win would leave them handily placed to go all the way.

But as the half-hour passed that seemed less than certain. Lumping it forward to the two big men proving to be a tactic as barren as it was unattractive.

Instead it was Brentford forcing the corners and causing Vince Bartram discom fort. Including one from which Kevin O'Connor hit the underside of the bar.

Gillingham responded. The ball was moved swiftly forwards, crossed deep by Barry Ashby and headed in from 10 yards by a diving Iffy Onuora. After being mobbed by his team-mates Onuora made the sign of the cross. Iffy thanking a higher power for helping him add a touch of certainty at an uncertain time.

Half-time brought more good news from elsewhere. Millwall were now losing 3-0, Wigan still losing 1-0, Rovers drawing 1-1 and, although Burnley were two up, Gillingham's superior goal difference meant a play-off place was almost, if not quite mathematically, guaranteed.

However, instead of working up their goal difference they adopted a languorous approach. Hessenthaler busied himself on the left before attempting a lob which Woodman had to claw away. Everyone else basked in the sun. Gillingham's highest league crowd of the season, 9,001, became agitated as their players lolled.

Rather than go for broke Gillingham brought on Junior Lewis, a defensive midfielder in the Carlton Palmer mould, for Asaba. Perhaps they feared Brentford would send on substitute goalie Jimmy Glass for another of his last-minute spectaculars.

Instead that privilege fell to the 38 year old Paul Butler, on for Onuora, who volleyed a very late second for Gillingham. Sometimes it's canny to be cautious.Wigan and Millwall had both lost and Rovers only drawn.

Next week, Cardiff at home and Wrexham away. If they get past a couple of Welsh teams they will enter their promised land. 'It's in our hands,' said manager Peter Taylor afterwards. 'We win two more games, that's it.' On the pitch his squad jogged by and chanted in his direction: 'Big Nose. There's only one Big Nose.'

fields.headline: Smith in 'cheat' row
fields.trailText: Tottenham 1 - 1 Derby
fields.byline: Stuart Barnes at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
A cheeky stoppage-time equaliser by Stephen Clemence, a visible display of annoyance by David Ginola after he was substituted and another post-match demonstration by some disgruntled Tottenham fans failed to disguise the overriding impression of this eventful match.

It was that Derby were unlucky not to collect the three points that would have made their Premiership place safe for next season, despite having Stephan Schnoor sent off for a second bookable offence six minutes from half-time.

Jim Smith, the Derby manager, vigorously contested that decision and was equally outraged by nine other yellow cards brandished by referee Neale Barry. Smith admitted afterwards that Barry is reporting him to the FA for remarks made during the game and his comments made later will inevitably compound his problems.

'It was very difficult with 10 against 12,' fumed Smith. 'We were cheated at the end of the day. I said before the game he is a bad referee and he did not disappoint me. I feel I have to talk about it because we should not be having that kind of official in charge of people's livelihoods.

'Schnoor fell on the ball and was penalised for hands. Then he slipped in a tackle and it is deemed violent. There was one bad tackle in the game and that was not it. It's a shame because my lads were deserved to win.'

Derby had escaped early on when Stephen Carr struck their crossbar, when Schnoor was dismissed for his challenge on Chris Armstrong all the indications were that they would not escape again. But with Rory Delap in energetic form and Horacio Carbonari marshalling the defence, Derby refused to buckle.

Carbonari was denied by a goal-line clearance from Clemence, but he made no mistake after 63 minutes with a crisp volley from Delap's cross. It looked enough until Darren Anderton's corner was flicked on by Sol Campbell to the far post where Clemence knocked in his first League goal for the side.

Earlier, Ginola glared angrily at the bench after being replaced by Matthew Etherington with 20 minutes to go.

'We needed some fresh legs,' said Stewart Houston, who is continuing to stand in for George Graham. 'Sometimes you have to make those decisions. David is aware of that. If he wants to see me, he knows me well enough now to do so on Monday.

'It doesn't need me to tell the players and supporters that we can play a lot better. But we did get something out of the game and to do that showed a lot of character.'

fields.headline: It's United and no Butts
fields.trailText: Watford 2 -3 Man Utd
fields.body:
What started out as a stroll in the sunshine was sparked into a full-blooded affair by the dismissal of Nicky Butt and Micah Hyde midway through the second half for fighting, and ended with Manchester United completing their ninth successive victory to reach a new record points total.

United now have 85 points which is the most achieved by any team in a 20-club Premier League. But they looked to be heading for a rare defeat before the 65th-minute flare-up changed the course of the game.

Butt took exception to a challenge from Hyde and their pushing and shoving match quickly turned vicious and resulted in a free-for-all. When order was restored referee Stephen Lodge showed the red card to both players.

That proved the turning point as Sir Alex Ferguson put Dwight Yorke into midfield to great effect. The striker from Trinidad became the midfielder from hell as far as Watford were concerned, scoring the equaliser for United and then slicing open the home defence repeatedly.

With Watford already relegated and United confirmed as champions last week, this game had no bearing on either end of the table and that showed from the start.

Ferguson chose to rest the majority of his stars and of the eleven who started, only Ryan Giggs and Ronnie Johnsen would be considered first choice players in a full-strength squad. Watford, on the other hand, welcomed back striker Tommy Mooney as a second-half substitute after a long injury lay-off.

So Graham Taylor had an almost full-strength side. The sad truth is they are still no better than a First Division team and struggled even against what was effectively a United reserve team with little to play for.

Neither side had the necessary bite or ability to score in a low-key opening half-hour. Mark Wilson, one of United's new boys missed a sitter mid way through the first half when he failed to convert from close range a Giggs cross and was withdrawn in favour of Yorke at half-time. By then, United were a goal behind after Icelandic striker Heidar Helguson headed home a free-kick from Hyde with a glancing strike in the 33rd minute.

Even after the introduction of Yorke, United failed to make a breakthrough, with Giggs shooting high over the bar. But once the side were reduced to 10 men apiece, Yorke dropped into midfield to create mayhem and broke away to score the equaliser five minutes later. A terrible clearance from Chamberlain went straight to Teddy Sheringham, and the United player did a neat backheel to set up Yorke for a shot that was driven into the far corner of goal.

A minute later, Yorke hit the bar after good work from Solskjaer and Sheringham but United soon took the lead when Giggs ran onto a neat flick from Jordi Cruyff and lobbed the ball over Chamberlain and into the empty net.

Watford were not going down tamely, though, and scored a marvellous equaliser when Smith raced on to a long through ball from Mooney and drilled his shot low into the United goal after 78 minutes.

But there was one final twist when Watford defender Robert Page sold Chamberlain woefully short with a back pass and allowed Cruyff to nip in for the winner four minutes from the end.

Afterwards, Ferguson said: 'In the first half we couldn't complain about Watford taking the lead but Yorke made a difference. The sending-off seemed to change the game and they could not handle him in midfield,' a point readily acknowledged by Taylor.

fields.headline: Ipswich hit the high notes
fields.trailText: Charlton 1- 3 Ipswich
fields.body:
Charlton's opera singer, Bjorn Arvidsson, could not inspire his beloved club to celebrate lifting the First Division trophy in style as Ipswich kept alive their chances of automatic promotion.

Arvidsson was flown from Germany to make it a day to remember for the local faithful, but it was not enough as Ipswich inflicted a third consecutive home defeat upon Charlton.

The manager, Alan Curbishley, expressed disappointment at his side's failure, and revealed he was scared into making changes as he thought a number of people would accuse him of fielding a weakened side.

Curbishley said: 'We certainly know how to spoil a party. We are very disappointed not to have won our last three home games and haven't been able to enjoy what we have done.

'The players have collected their medals, but there were no real celebrations. We didn't even have any cham pagne in the dressing room. It was a damp squib in the end and a little bit sobering.

'I wanted to make more changes to the side, but if I made too many, people would say I was fielding an under-strength side and the game didn't mean anything to us.

'I wish now I would have made a few more, because a lot of the players were on their last legs.'

Ipswich's manager, George Burley, was delighted with the result but still feels Manchester City are the favourites to clinch second place.

Burley said: 'Two years on the trot we have had to wait for the last game to achieve promotion.

'We will try and win our own game against Walsall and then see how City get on. If they do pick up a point, then we are still in the play-offs and there is everything still to play for.

'I think City are the favourites because they only need a point, but Blackburn is a very difficult fixture for them.

'It is all set up nicely for next weekend and we will take it from there.'

Ipswich midfielder Jim Magilton was the inspiration behind his side's victory, netting the first goal from a free-kick on 24 minutes.

And he then played the perfect through-ball for David Johnson to grab the second on 59 minutes.

Substitute Martijn Reuser scored the third on 70 minutes, before Andy Hunt pulled a consolation goal back for Charlton on 86 minutes.

fields.headline: Hoddle losing faith in Saints
fields.trailText: Southampton 1 - 2 Leicester
fields.body:
Southampton defender Dean Richards was sent off in injury time as Leicester completed a comfortable Premiership double over the Saints in the sunshine.

Southampton were already a well-beaten side when Richards clashed with Welsh international Robbie Savage by a corner flag and appeared to kick the Leicester player while he was on the ground.

Referee Mike Reed had no hesitation in brandishing a red card and then presented a yellow one to Moroccan midfielder Hassan Kachloul for disputing the decision.

It was a sorry end to a below-par match in which Leicester recovered from a shaky start to deservedly take the three points after a second-half winner from Muzzy Izzet.

Southampton boss Glenn Hoddle admitted he was furious with the result.

'This was an unacceptable performance and I cannot explain why it should have been like that.,' he said. 'There was strong words exchanged in the dressing room afterwards because we looked like a team under pressure of being relegated. Something mentally was not right.'

Southampton had initially started the brighter as Hassan Kachloul took Leicester by surprise to score in the fourth minute. Once they had taken their lead, however, they seemed to have little idea what to do with it and Tony Cottee scored a deserved equaliser halfway through the first half.

From then on it was all about Leicester and Glenn Hoddle's side needed a series of excellent saves from Neil Moss simply to stay in the match.

Leicester boss Martin O'Neill said: 'We made a sloppy start but after they had scored in the first few minutes we controlled the rest of the game.

'Muzzy Izzet has not scored for three months but he deserved one for his hard work and his tenacity.'

Southampton had initially started the brighter as Hassan Kachloul took Leicester by surprise to score in the fourth minute. Once they had taken their lead, however, they seemed to have little idea what to do with it and Tony Cottee scored a deserved equaliser halfway through the first half. From then on it was all about Leicester and Glenn Hoddle's side needed a series of excellent saves from Neil Moss simply to stay in the match. Leicester boss Martin O'Neill said: 'We made a sloppy start but after they had scored in the first few minutes we controlled the rest of the game. 'Muzzy Izzet has not scored for three months but he deserved one for his hard work and his tenacity.'

fields.headline: Dutch domination
fields.trailText: Everton 0 - 1 Arsenal
fields.body:
In a week when Dutch footballers - or, more specifically, their joints - have dominated Premiership news, Marc Overmars' excellent first-half finish kept Arsenal on course for the Champions League and stretched their winning streak to 10 games.

Not even the fact that Manchester United are on course to win the Premiership by a record margin, having moved 19 points clear yesterday, could detract from this excellent Arsenal performance.

To emphasise the point, Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger argued that the gulf between the champions and his own side is not as dramatic as the table implies. 'I don't think there is that much of a gap,' he said. 'United have the best team in the country at the moment but last season we lost the championship on the last day, two years ago we won it by a point. I believe that gap is more reasonable than what has happened this year.

'They had everything going for them, the championship was organised for them. They had a winter break, didn't play in the FA Cup and could then play their games in hand on FA Cup days.'

Certainly, the talent Arsenal - sans Henry and Vieira - displayed here suggested that if United are 19 points better, they would not have capitulated so disappointingly in Europe this season.

Overmars and Dennis Bergkamp were instrumental in Arsenal's domination of an Everton side whose only resemblance to the team that enjoyed the better of the Mersey derby over Easter lay in the colour of their shirts.

Not until the 79th minute did Everton muster anything approximating a shot on goal, and that a much-deflected, long-range effort. It would not take a brave man to wager on Arsenal to equal their 12-year-old club record of 14 consecutive wins in all competitions.

The initial brute force having been taken out of the contest - a fixture that saw Hutchison and Petit dismissed last season and the latter claim that English football's physicality was driving him out - Arsenal dominated with almost embarrassing ease.

The only major surprise was that it took Overmars until the 34th minute to hand the visitors the lead. Everton defender Abel Xavier engaged in a wrestling contest with Bergkamp that ended with the Dutchman slipping the ball through for Overmars. The winger sped half the length of the field before beating Paul Gerrard with an assured finish.

The Dutch pair began to increasingly exploit their side's midfield supremacy and four minutes after the goal Bergkamp surged through the blue shirts and unleashed a shot that deflected off Xavier and against the post.

Even a dramatic wholesale tactical change at half-time by Walter Smith - two substitutions and seven positional changes - brought no sign of improvement. It took a full-length diving save from the harassed Gerrard to deny Petit the final word from a long-range 65th-minute shot. If anyone deserved not to be humiliated by what Smith conceded was his team's worst performance of the season, it was his goalkeeper.

fields.headline: Brave Shrews set for drop
fields.trailText: Shrewsbury 1 - 2 Brighton
fields.body:
Shrewsbury's 50-year league status is hanging by the thinnest possible thread.

They fought bravely here, especially in the second half when they almost staged a dramatic late comeback. But they were undone by two clinical pieces of finishing from a Brighton side unbeaten in 13 games, and now know that even a win in their final league game at Exeter next week will mean nothing if rivals Carlisle and Chester fail to drop points. Manager Kevin Ratcliffe said: 'I'm disappointed but it's not over yet. We created plenty of chances, but there's no reason why we can't go to Exeter and win. Then we have to hope.'

Despite Ratcliffe's defiance, the majority of the club's biggest league gate for six years (which included their most famous son G Arthur Rowley and Chic Bates, the manager who guided the club to its highest ever league position of eighth in the old Division Two in the early Eighties) were very sombre at the end. The programme summed up the mood by publishing what amounted to a decade-by-decade obituary of the club's league existence.

But the future is not all bleak at Gay Meadow. Ratcliffe recently signed a three-year contract, while there are advanced plans to build a new 10,000 capacity all-seater stadium half a mile away called the New Meadow.

The game turned on an incident at the end of the first half when John Gayle's headed goal was ruled out for a push by the Shrewsbury striker.

Brighton then scored straight after the break when Gary Hart sent Paul Brooker through to slot the ball home from the edge of the box.

Shrewsbury came back strongly and could well have scored when Lee Steele set up Kevin Seabury. His shot was parried into the path of Dean Peer, who could only hit the post before the ball was scrambled clear.

Brighton's second goal came after Scott Ramsey headed the ball on for Martin Ling to apply a cool finish.

Shrewsbury sensed a comeback could be on the cards when centre-half Danny Cullip was sent off with a quarter of an hour left, after pulling down Simon Sturridge for a second bookable offence.

Luke Rodgers outpaced his marker to poke the ball home for his first senior goal, but as the Shrews piled on the pressure in a frantic final flourish, Brighton's defence, urged on by 2,000 fans, held firm.

fields.headline: Zimbabwe get going
fields.trailText: Despite difficulties at home and personnel problems, the summer's first tourists are playing on.
fields.body:
To their delight, the Zimbabweans could play some cricket yesterday. Heaven knows they could do with some distraction from the news from home, which they stoically refuse to allow to disrupt their tour. They had to wait until 1.30pm before resuming their innings, whereupon Murray Goodwin and Alistair Campbell, who stroked an effortless 140-ball century, enjoyed themselves against Hampshire's second-team attack.

Quite why Hampshire should choose to 'rest' so many of their frontliners given the amount of cricket they have played this summer is bewildering. Shane Warne's absence is understandable and they could claim niggles among the rest of them (Mullally, Hartley, Udal and Mascarenhas) but you can guarantee that all of them will be on duty when Somerset arrive for Hampshire's first Championship match on Wednesday. Whether they will be tuned up is another matter.

In other circumstances, the tourists might be insulted by such a selection, but the Zimbabweans were more concerned for proper practice and a boost in confidence for their batsmen after an arduous tour of the Caribbean. Some respite is handy since the tourists have some setbacks to overcome, notwithstanding their troubles at home. They are, for example, denied any sort of spin attack, which might have included two leg-spinners; Paul Strang is not fit enough for first-class cricket, Adam Huckle has given up and young Brian Murphy, who impressed against the West Indies, has some exams to do.

So some gentle sparring at Southampton was in order. They dispatched Hampshire for 131 on Thursday and yesterday they put themselves in a good position to win the first of three first-class fixtures on their schedule before the first Test at Lord's on 18 May. They finished on 281 for six.

Murray Goodwin, who learnt his cricket at the Waca before returning to Zimbabwe, was most impressive. Like anyone who scores runs at Perth, he is an adept cutter and puller, but yesterday he scored runs all around the wicket. He was notably severe on Simon Francis, whom he hit for five fours in one over - two cuts, one pull, but also two flowing drives. Trevor Gripper was more ponderous and less convincing. He has played six Tests matches so far and is almost certain to add to that number since there are only two specialist openers on the tour. He advanced slowly despite the modest nature of the attack until he presented Charlie van der Gucht with his maiden first-class wicket on a day that the young left-arm spinner won't forget easily. He ended with three for 53 from 20 encouraging overs.

Van der Gucht is about to return to his studies at Durham University. His grandfather, you will recall, kept wicket for Gloucestershire and Bengal in the Thirties. Yesterday Gripper scythed outside the off stump and gave a simple catch to Savident at backward point. Then Goodwin pulled a short ball into the midriff of Morris at midwicket and Carlisle skied to mid-off.

But Campbell, in a torrid run at Test level, settled easily in these conditions, driving smoothly through the off side and reverse lapping Van der Gucht just to remind the youngster that the game wasn't that simple. This Alistair Campbell is an accomplished spin doctor as well. Johnson was unable to stay with him for long but Guy Whittall could for most of a final session, notable for its tranquillity, its sunshine and also an impressive start to his innings by the 16-year-old Tatenda Taibu.

fields.headline: Notts face pitch penalty
fields.trailText: Round-up
fields.body:
Nottinghamshire must wait to hear whether they face a 10-point deduction for preparing a poor pitch following an inspection by Raman Subba Row, the England and Wales Cricket Board pitch liaison officer. Subba Row was sent to look at the Trent Bridge pitch after 19 wickets fell during the first day's play between Nottinghamshire and Northants on Friday.

Nottinghamshire were given a 10-point suspended sentence last season when they received a 'poor' pitch mark. Subba Row said that should they be found guilty again then that sentence would be brought back into the reckoning.

The pitch liaison officer was at Trent Bridge on Tuesday and Wednesday to inspect the preparation of the pitch and to watch the first day's play. But due to heavy rain play was not possible until Friday when wickets tumbled from the start.

Northants were bowled out for 153 before Notts slumped to 79 for nine at the close.

Subba Row said: 'After 19 wickets fell on the third day of the match, it was felt that as the ECB representative I should come back and have another look at the wicket, the pitch in general and the cricket being played.

'As we are tightening up on the preparation of pitches this year, I have spoken to the umpires, opposing captain Matthew Hayden and the groundsman.' Subba Row said he would now report his findings back to Lord's.

Darren Stevens underlined his reputation as a batsman with the talent to go a long way when he guided Leicestershire to a draw at Derby. Stevens played with authority on a slow pitch to score 78 from 92 deliveries.

By then, Leicestershire were 12 runs short of the 210 they needed to avoid the follow on and Phil DeFreitas took them to that target to end his former county's chances of victory.

Derbyshire's hopes of winning the game began to fade when early morning drizzle delayed the start of the final day by an hour, and then Stevens and Chris Lewis denied the pace bowlers an early breakthrough.

Stevens timed the ball impressively on both sides of the wicket, hitting seven fours in his 50, which came off only 51 balls. The stand with Lewis was worth 57 when the former England all-rounder fell into a trap set by Dominic Cork when he hooked a short ball into the hands of long leg.

Leicestershire were still in danger at that point, but Stevens continued to play superbly and, with Neil Burns providing sensible support, another 54 runs were added to edge the visitors closer to safety.

Stevens, 24 today, looked on course to celebrate his birthday early with a century but when he tried to force a wide ball from Paul Aldred, he only succeeded in edging it into his stumps.

DeFreitas made sure there were no slip-ups and then enjoyed himself against the county he left at the end of last season. He plundered 79 from 98 balls before he was stumped giving Rob Bailey's off-spin the charge.

Somerset's game with reigning champions Surrey ended in a tame draw, the sunshine coming too late at Taunton to make up for earlier rain delays.

With bonus points to be won, Marcus Trescothick (85), Mike Burns (81) and Peter Bowler (37) made light work of the Surrey pace attack as they set up a good platform for a big score. Somerset finished on 302 for eight.

But leg-spinner Ian Salisbury checked Somerset's progress with a fine unbroken spell of 24 overs either side of the tea interval finishing with three for 56.

Resuming on 15 for two after half an hour was lost at the start of the day, Bowler and Trescothick took their third-wicket stand to 86 before Bowler was adjudged lbw in the penultimate over before lunch with former Somerset paceman Ian Bishop the successful bowler.

With Trescothick in commanding form after a slow start, the Surrey pace attack found the going tough on a good pitch, and with Burns also taking up the attack, runs flowed in the middle session.

webTitle: No joy in land of the missed leg-bye

fields.headline: No joy in land of the missed leg-bye
fields.trailText: Essex County Cricket Club have done splendidly in moving the press at their Chelmsford headquarters from mid-wicket to long-on, where the lads can actually see something.
fields.body:
Dave and I did not get off to the best of starts. I was in his scorebox and I wasn't a scorer. 'I'm not happy about it,' he said, 'not happy at all.' He had a point.

Trouble was, there was no room in the adjoining 'media suite', as Clem called it. Where was I to put my pen? Exactly. And much good it would do there.

Essex County Cricket Club have done splendidly in moving the press at their Chelmsford headquarters from mid-wicket to long-on, where the lads can actually see something - except that even such visionaries as these could not account for an otherwise bog-standard Benson and Hedges fixture against Hampshire attracting hacks in battalion strength. We had come to see one man, the Aussie gunslinger, Shane.

So there we sat: Dave and me, and Vic from Hampshire, and Dave's mentor, Clem, a scoring legend for county and country. I didn't cough.

Nor, when the afternoon tea and sandwiches arrived half an hour late and Dave and Vic appeared - dare I say it - to miss a leg-bye while they were pouring, did I laugh. Not a titter did there come, either, when a girl from the front office arrived with the updated Duckworth-Lewis calculations just as the sun threatened to hit 'mildly bright'.

No, I watched, at pains not to write too loudly. Even when Clem wanted to exchange trivialities about the design of the new windows - 'quite clever, aren't they? you can open them upwards and you can open them sideways.' - I could only whisper agreement, lest Dave turn around and laser a hole in my head with a disapproving stare.

It was all fascinatingly dull, and not without its little charms. There had been confusion over the starting time of the Hampshire innings - 'either 2.40 or 2.41' - and there was a silent, running war with the scoreboard, whose operators everywhere traditionally are at odds with the official version of things up in the scorebox.

I was with Dave on this one; after 16 overs, Hampshire, chasing 202, were 59 for two but the guys in the scoreboard were having a mare, with 'runs required' shown as 193.

The phone rings and Dave, who is busy computing on a computer that insists on behaving badly, picks it up. 'Get them to sort it out in the office!' he says. 'Nothing to do with me.'

Vic meanwhile is beavering away. He's been doing this for 25 years and, like Dave, in recent years he has wrestled manfully with the technology, underpaid and unloved.

Yet chronicling the gubbins of the game, the stuff that cricket is made of and without which it would be totally meaningless, they bring to their chore an almost effortless diligence.

Against the window sill in the corner near Vic's Coke can, stands a Simpson's mouse pad with one of those universally appropriate aphorisms: 'Every time I learn something new, it pushes some old stuff out of my brain!'

Outside, information overload: more match-rigging scoundrels exposed by the day, claim and counter claim... experts who know nothing about, and care less for, the game, predict its terminal breath...

I feel quietly honoured that Dave and Vic and Clem, three proper cricket folk, have suffered my presence for a couple of hours away from all that. Wouldn't want to shout about it, though.
