Yet chronicling the gubbins of the game, the stuff that cricket is made of and without which it would be totally meaningless, they bring to their chore an almost effortless diligence. Against the window sill in the corner near Vic's Coke can, stands a Simpson's mouse pad with one of those universally appropriate aphorisms: 'Every time I learn something new, it pushes some old stuff out of my brain!' Outside, information overload: more match-rigging scoundrels exposed by the day, claim and counter claim... experts who know nothing about, and care less for, the game, predict its terminal breath... I feel quietly honoured that Dave and Vic and Clem, three proper cricket folk, have suffered my presence for a couple of hours away from all that. Wouldn't want to shout about it, though.

fields.headline: The Overseas Players
fields.trailText: DERBYSHIRE - Michael Di Venuto (Australia)
fields.body:
DERBYSHIRE - Michael Di Venuto (Australia)

Di Venuto, 27, an occasional one-day international, is preferred to Michael Slater, a model overseas player (good in dressing room and committee room). Di Venuto, a left-hander from Tasmania, impressed at Hove last summer. Runs at Derby could be harder to come by.

DURHAM - Simon Katich (Australia)

They have replaced an old Aussie (David Boon) with a young one. The Riverside is a long way from the Waca - the bounce is steeper and more predictable in Perth than Chester-le-Street and it's a few degrees warmer. Katich, 24, is a dashing left-hander, highly rated at home, and an occasional left-arm spinner.

ESSEX - Stuart Law (Australia)

Another Aussie who can't make their Test side. Just one Test innings back in 1996, scored 54 not out against Sri Lanka and hasn't played again. Last season he scored 1,833 runs at 73. Now 31, so another Test cap is unlikely.

GLAMORGAN - Matthew Elliott (Australia)

Elliott excelled on the 1997 tour of England, but he's stuck on 20 Tests (average 35). Like Bill Lawry - Victorian, left-handed opener, big nose. Likes to hook and pull, which can be a bit tricky at Cardiff since the ball rarely bounces above knee height.

GLOUCESTERSHIRE - Ian Harvey (Australia)

Perhaps the least eye-catching Aussie of the lot. Modest figures at Gloucester last year, but they won both one-day finals so have stuck with him. He also bowls clever medium pace and biffs away happily.

HAMPSHIRE - Shane Warne (Australia)

Another Aussie. You may have heard of him. Bowls leg spinners and a decade ago he played club cricket in Bristol for free. Hampshire cough up more now. But the county has done us a service by enticing him. He'll be cheered - and jeered - everywhere.

KENT - Rahul Dravid (India)

Canterbury was entranced by Aravinda de Silva, so they'll appreciated Dravid, 27, who averages 48 from 35 Tests and was the 'Cricketer of the World Cup' in 1999. Stylish and correct on-field, polite and articulate off it, Dravid may be the first Indian batsman to take the county game by storm.

LANCASHIRE - Saurav Ganguly (India)

Ganguly, the new Indian captain, was enlisted when Muttiah Muralitharan's international commitments became too heavy. Ganguly is very talented, but Lancashire's opponents will prefer to come across him than the mighty Murali.

LEICESTERSHIRE - Anil Kumble (India)

Only Kapil Dev has taken more Test wickets for India. We know that Kumble's brand of pacy leg-breaks will be effective in England. He played for Northants in 1995, acted as Allan Lamb's chauffeur (he doesn't drink), took 105 wickets and almost won the Championship for them.

MIDDLESEX - Justin Langer (Australia)

Middlesex apparently played better under Langer's captaincy last year than when Mark Ramprakash was not on Test duty and in charge. Langer, a left-hander, now established as Test regular after a hugely productive last 12 months, is their new captain charged with obtaining instant elevation from the second division.

NORTHAMPTONSHIRE - Matthew Hayden (Australia)

One of seven Aussie southpaws unable to secure a regular Test place there, but much sought after here. Has so far played two seasons in county cricket - for Hampshire in 1997 and for Northamptonshire last year. In both summers he averaged over 50.

NOTTINGHAMSHIRE - Shoiab Akhtar (Pakistan)

After Warne, the most likely to put bums on seats. At his best, a magnificent sight unless you happen to be stuck 22 yards away. Worries about his action (now deemed OK) and his fitness (still dodgy) clouded his arrival.

SOMERSET - Jamie Cox (Australia)

He would walk into the England Test side, but at 30 it's probably too late for Australia. Orthodox opener and a calm, authoritative captain. Skippers Tasmania during our winter.

SURREY - Saqlain Mushtaq (Pakistan)

Doesn't arrive until June - a good judge - but that may be early enough to enable Surrey to retain the Championship. Last summer took 58 wickets in seven matches , all won by Surrey. No one can decipher the mystery ball - looks like an off-break, acts like a leg-break.

SUSSEX - Michael Bevan (Australia)

Back after a one-year sabbatical. Already notched two scores over 150 in limited overs games this April. The only blot in a dazzling career is a modest Test record and the indignity of being 'found out' against the short ball by - of all teams - England. This is far less likely to occur on the county circuit.

WARWICKSHIRE - Allan Donald (South Africa)

Picked a good time to absent himself from those one-day games in India. The senior import at 33 and devoted to Birmingham. A great club man and a great bowler. But will his body still permit him to deliver.

WORCESTERSHIRE - Glenn McGrath (Australia)

If he avoids injury, McGrath could catapult Worcestershire into the first division. He should be ideally suited to English conditions. Cranky on the pitch, charming off it, he will fit in well. McGrath, however, will only stay for a year; the Aussies would not contemplate their strike bowler being absent for any longer.

YORKSHIRE - Darren Lehmann (Australia)

Returns after a stunning season in Australian domestic cricket - 995 runs in nine matches for South Australia. Greg Blewett, a Test regular unlike Lehmann, could only average 31 last year for Yorkshire. The wicket in Adelaide is more trustworthy than Headingley, but still expect this resourceful left-hander to cope better than his South Australian colleague.

fields.headline: Memorial to lost youth
fields.trailText: Parvaz Mirza, a Worcestershire fast-bowler, died at his home of natural causes in 1996, aged 24. Raja Khan decided to do something in memory of his friend.
fields.body:
The entry on page 637 of the 1996 Wisden Cricketers' Almanack, looking back at the previous summer, was heartfelt in an understandably prosaic sort of way.

'Events in a transitional period at New Road,' it said, 'were overshadowed by the sudden death of the 24-year-old fast bowler Parvaz Mirza, less than a week after the season had ended. Mirza had been earmarked to play an important part in Worcestershire's future following his emergence, alongside Paul Thomas, in bolstering an ageing attack. But Mirza's death, by natural causes at his Birmingham home, left a void that will be hard to fill. One suspects the loss of someone so young will not hit home fully until the squad reports back for pre-season training in April.'

The alternative spelling of a young Asian's first name (Parvaz rather than Parvez, as he was more often spelt by members of the Pakistani community in Birmingham), the unadorned assessment of a jobbing pro alongside the downbeat regret about their 'ageing attack', and then, stopping to point out there would be 'a void to fill', the closing announcement of business as usual... English cricket wrapped up in a sentence or two, where it is best understood, the game's old yellow-bound bible.

There are others who knew Parvez.

'He was a good friend,' said Raja Khan. 'He'd had a hole in the heart when he was young, although there was nothing very untoward after that until one day he just choked, and collapsed on the floor. The ambulance couldn't get there in time and he passed away. It was right in the middle of his career at Worcester.'

Raja decided to do something in memory of his friend. A lot of people thought he was mad.

'I went to Worcestershire and suggested that they might be interested in taking on young inner-city players on summer contracts, paid for by the Asian business community. I said to them, "We'll bring you some of these young cricketers and, if you think any of them are good enough, you choose and we pay." They were taken aback a little but they said, "Well, we can't lose." So they went for it.'

The first recipient was Abdul Hafeez. Two years ago Worcester took him on and, on his debut at New Road, he opened the batting against a useful bowler for Gloucestershire. Picking Courtney Walsh's bouncers off his nose, with the slips baying for blood, he hit two fours and a six in his first over as a professional cricketer.

'All of a sudden,' Raja recalled last week, 'people were taking notice of someone they'd never heard of, someone who'd hit 14 off Courtney Walsh in his first over for the county.'

It didn't quite work out for Hafeez after that. He was released after a moderate season - but the precedent had been set. This was an idea that had something about it.

A couple of Tuesdays ago, I went with Raja to Grace Road where he had lined up another nine recruits. Leicestershire's coach, Jack Birkenshaw, not an easy man to please, was clearly impressed, not only by the talent on show but the canny business to be done. 'I can't see how we can lose,' he said.

His assistant, Phil Robinson, ex-Yorkshire, wasn't so forthcoming. None the less, he looked pleased enough when he watched the cool elegance of a young left-hand opening bat, Imran Ahmed, at the second time of asking in the nets.

Imran is desperate to be a county cricketer, maybe an England one too. He plays for Ilford in Essex, and Surrey have tracked his progress as well. What they see in him is the most graceful batting against pace you could ask of a player so young and untried. He has the tools. He also now has a place at Leicestershire, after the county took up Raja's offer to pay for Imran.

Others have been placed around the counties. More will follow. Raja took his caravan to Sussex last week and county chairmen only have to pick up the phone if they want to have a look at potential players who will cost them nothing.

After Hafeez, Worcestershire took on Kabir Ali and his cousin, Kadir Ali. Kabir took four wickets in his opening match this season. Kadir has a summer contract.

If you're wondering what the catch is, there isn't one. What there is, though, and what is the key to the unusual scheme's success, is the name of Wasim Akram. Raja is his manager and, when he mentions the name of the Pakistani star, doors open. Some of them don't slam shut, either.

Last season, after a World Cup he would want to forget, Wasim was persuaded to finish the season playing club cricket with Smethwick. It didn't go as well as Raja had hoped. 'I got a bit altruistic, I suppose,' he said.

'I wanted my old club, Smethwick, to play five teams, which would have given places to a whole lot of people who hadn't access to club facilities before, but some of the old guard were wary. There's a Channel 4 documentary coming out soon about the whole politics and shenanigans of it, bringing Wasim Akram in, sponsors pulling out... I was really disillusioned.

'It got to the stage where the club, to all intents and purposes, kicked me out. They were saying, "Raja's trying to make it an Asian club." But all I ever wanted was for Asians to be able to stand on their own two feet. I never wanted an all-Asian club. Everything I stand for is Britain as a multiracial society.'

Even Raja's Cambridge-educated suaveness cannot always melt the stubbornness and suspicion of the county game. This year, though, he will keep the players together at a new club, the Wasim Akram Academy team, playing in the Birmingham League. Wasim arrives to play with these hopefuls next month. Maybe a few will make it.

It will make Raja very happy - Parvez, too, if he's looking down from somewhere.

fields.headline: Dozen from down under
fields.standfirst: Shane Warne and his Aussie pals lead the new wave of imports
fields.trailText: Shane has hit town and we should all welcome him. We could do with some cheering up and, for sure, Warne will bring a smile to our faces.
fields.body:
There has not been such a hullabaloo about the arrival of an overseas player in county cricket since 1968. They were scrummaging in Southampton to grab a sentence or a snap when he arrived. Shane has hit town, even if he's not gracing the Zimbabweans with his presence this weekend. And we should all welcome him. We could do with some cheering up and, for sure, Warne will bring a smile to our faces.

He is already earning his keep. Membership is on the rise at Southampton and in 12 deliveries during a 10-over game against Surrey at The Oval he took 2-6 and Hampshire - or 'Hampshheeer' as Warne calls his new team - were suddenly in the quarter finals of the Benson and Hedges competition. Whether he succeeds or fails this summer, he'll always captivate. He is the biggest star to be attracted to county cricket since Gary Sobers first appeared for Nottinghamshire 32 years ago. And, as the biggest Australian star, he has good company from down under.

Antipodeans are everywhere, it seems. Twelve Aussies altogether, including Warne, plying their trade in the newly split county championship.

There have been some brilliant cricketers from overseas in the years since Sobers' talent lit up Tent Bridge but many of them arrived in the UK as relative unknowns. Barry and Viv Richards, Mike Procter, Andy Roberts, Malcolm Marshall, Courtney Walsh, Joel Garner and Allan Donald were just starting illustrious careers when they made their debuts in county cricket. Warne is somewhere near the peak of his fame (whether he's still at his peak as a cricketer remains - deliciously - to be seen). The hullabaloo is justified just as it would be if Rivaldo agreed terms with Glenn Hoddle at The Dell.

His baptism should be easier than Sobers' in 1968. That was the year overseas players were first allowed into the English game without serving a period of qualification. Sobers was the prime draw, but incomers also included Barry Richards, Procter, Faroukh Engineer, Asif Iqbal, Majid Khan and a 19-year-old Greg Chappell. They reinvigorated an ailing English game.

At Trent Bridge Sobers joined a side that had failed to win one of their 28 Championship matches in 1967, though they drew 22 (whoever believes our current Championship is dead and dull should examine the staleness of much of the cricket in the Sixties). In 1968, with Sobers as captain, topping the batting averages as well as taking 83 wickets, Nottinghamshire won seven matches and surged up to fourth from the previous year's 16th. When they travelled for a Championship match to Derbyshire, Sobers' presence prompted record receipts of £1,686 (how often do they get that much now?)

By comparison Warne's task is much easier. Hampshire bubbled along under the cheerful leadership of Robin Smith last year. They have the odd handy wealthy backer in the background and with Warne and Alan Mullally added to their squad they should be able to bowl sides out. Whatever happens they'll attract the crowds since Warne possesses not only a big leg-break but also that indefinable something sufficient to make you toss the umbrella and hip flask into the car and head for Southampton.

So Warne is one of a dozen Australians here this summer, all of whom are careful not to take the standard Aussie (and Atherton) line on English county cricket - that it's garbage. Such a line would undermine their presence in England.Why are they here? 1) There's a gap in the Australian international calendar. 2) This is the only place where it's possible to earn decent money - anything from £50,000 to £150,000 - playing non-international cricket. 3) They like playing cricket. 4) The counties like them.

The Australians produce and they fit in well. Despite all the blather about the antipathy between Poms and Aussies, they sit happily in the same dressing-room. I discovered this 15 years ago in West Australia; meanwhile countless Aussies have since played English county cricket and I can't recall a bad word said about any of them. A few have struggled to perform, like Michael Slater at Derby, but they liked him and his attitude nonetheless.

There are some who quibble that the 'second grade' Aussies (those who can't make their Test side regularly - such as Di Venuto, Law, Elliott, Harvey, Katich, Cox, Hayden and Lehmann - do not enhance the English game. Look at the averages and the impact that many of these men have already had on their counties; not just their runs, but their example. When we can find a batch of Englishmen who can match their output, then their presence may not be justified - or required.

In some ways the non-Aussie overseas players are more intriguing, partly because (with the exception of Allan Donald) they are not so familiar. We glimpsed the silky skills of Rahul Dravid and Saurav Ganguly in the World Cup, but we'd like to see more. Saqlain's leg-break, though quite familiar, still mystifies and is it possible to play the brisk Anil Kumble as an in-swing bowler? I doubt it.

But Warne apart it will be Shoaib Akhtar at Nottingham that excites the greatest interest of the spectator and the odd opening batsman. Here the parallel with the arrival of Sobers is closer. Nottinghamshire were dreadful last year, languishing near the foot of the table (17th) and their opening efforts in the Benson and Hedges Cup this 'summer' were woeful as well. Sobers managed a revival, but surely it's too much to expect the inexperienced Shoaib to do the same. So much depends on whether the new, though hardly fresh, recruits like Darren Bicknell and John Morris can cobble together enough runs. Now there's a topic for debate. What harms the English game more? The influx of overseas players, who are so often convenient scapegoats, or the recycling of doughty old pros who have passed their sell-by-date?

webTitle: Cricket must introduce the ultimate deterrent

fields.headline: Cricket must introduce the ultimate deterrent
fields.trailText: Like all summit meetings, the ICC gathering at Lord's on Tuesday and Wednesday will produce some fine rhetoric at its conclusion. Vic Marks doubts whether the game will be any cleaner by the end.
fields.body:
Like all summit meetings, the ICC gathering at Lord's on Tuesday and Wednesday will produce some fine rhetoric at its conclusion. The diplomats and the spin doctors will set to work. Whether the game will be any cleaner by the end is a different matter.

The amount of pre-meeting sparring hints at the divide between the Asian nations and the rest. Both Yawar Saeed, the director of cricket operations of the Pakistan Cricket Board and Jagmohan Dalmiya, the ICC president, called for a retraction from Dr Ali Bacher.

Bacher was quoted in Australian papers, saying that two World Cup matches were fixed, one of which was the Bangladesh v Pakistan game, and that the Pakistani umpire, Javed Akhtar, was implicated in match-fixing. Bacher has since replied that he did not mention the name of any country or umpire and there had been some 'mischief' among the Aussie papers, thereby doing his level best to create a constructive atmosphere before Tuesday.

As each day passes our conviction that match-fixing and collusion with shady bookmakers has been rife in cricket grows stronger, yet the absence of proof to back up an ever-increasing catalogue of allegations remains an impenetrable obstacle. After almost a decade of claim and counter-claim during which there have been four inquiries in Pakistan, one in India as well as an ICC commission, what do we have that is beyond doubt? Precious little.

In 1998 Shane Warne and Mark Waugh admitted to receiving money for information from a bookmaker four years earlier in an episode which painted the Australian Cricket Board in a worse light than the players themselves. They were fined Aus$8,000 and Aus$10,000 respectively.

Now we have a warrant for the arrest of Hansie Cronje, who eventually admitted wrongdoing, although no one yet knows quite what he's owning up to (did he, for example, take $30,000 for opening up the Centurion Test against England?). He's still in hiding in South Africa. And a warrant for the arrest of Ajay Sharma, a former Indian international, alleged to be a go-between between players and bookmakers, has also been issued in India. Meanwhile, he is in Lancashire - yesterday he was due to make his debut for Padiham in the Ribblesdale League. Not much progress given the volume of allegations spinning around the globe.

Against this background it is not so surprising that the ICC are unlikely to find a remedy by Wednesday. There will probably be agreement that the stance taken by the chairman of the ACB, Denis Rogers, is the right one: that anyone proven to be colluding with bookmakers should be banished from the game for life. Lord MacLaurin and Dr Bacher have expressed the same view, as has the president of the Indian Cricket Board, AC Muthiah. I'm not sure how far this takes us.

What cricket needs is a deterrent. It may be that Hansie Cronje will provide one in an unwitting final service to the game. If he is proven to be culpable then his punishment will have to be severe - to discourage the others. An example is required to drive home to current players and those of the next generation that toying with bookmakers will lead to the end of their careers.

For in the end it lies predominantly with the players to clean up the game. They are the only ones who can effectively police the game since they are the direct targets of the bookmakers. Each board has to impress on their players the consequence of any alliance with bookmakers or of failing to report any advances. In this regard the Lewis affair has been most unhelpful.

Lord MacLaurin was right to commend Chris Lewis for having the courage to come forward last August. Since then Lewis has not handled the situation so well. Once he - or his agent - were seduced by the tabloids which, admittedly, is not quite as dubious as taking money from bookmakers, then the affair became muddied. Lewis's position was compromised and the threat of ostracism within the game loomed. Thereafter the claims and counter claims of Lewis and the ECB have proved an unwelcome distraction from the main issue of match-fixing.

But the worst consequence of the Lewis affair is this. If in the future any player possesses information of any dubious activity involving bookmakers, he is probably now less likely to come forward. He's witnessed Lewis's discomfort; he's aware of allegations of bungling by the board. Is it worth his while to come forward, even without a sweetener from The News of the World ?

One issue the ICC should and can address this week, which is indirectly linked to match-fixing, is the one day international calendar. A reduction in the number of games is not necessarily the goal, but a reduction in the number of meaningless matches is essential. This might involve an official league structure, which incorporates all one day internationals or the introduction of a World Cup every two years. This type of scheme would be no panacea, but anything that helps at all is worth exploring, in our attempts to preserve the integrity of the game.

Lord MacLaurin was right to commend Chris Lewis for having the courage to come forward last August. Since then Lewis has not handled the situation so well. Once he - or his agent - were seduced by the tabloids which, admittedly, is not quite as dubious as taking money from bookmakers, then the affair became muddied. Lewis's position was compromised and the threat of ostracism within the game loomed. Thereafter the claims and counter claims of Lewis and the ECB have proved an unwelcome distraction from the main issue of match-fixing. But the worst consequence of the Lewis affair is this. If in the future any player possesses information of any dubious activity involving bookmakers, he is probably now less likely to come forward. He's witnessed Lewis's discomfort; he's aware of allegations of bungling by the board. Is it worth his while to come forward, even without a sweetener from The News of the World ? One issue the ICC should and can address this week, which is indirectly linked to match-fixing, is the one day international calendar. A reduction in the number of games is not necessarily the goal, but a reduction in the number of meaningless matches is essential. This might involve an official league structure, which incorporates all one day internationals or the introduction of a World Cup every two years. This type of scheme would be no panacea, but anything that helps at all is worth exploring, in our attempts to preserve the integrity of the game.

fields.headline: Amnesty plan for 'fixers'
fields.trailText: Vic Marks The disgraced Hansie Cronje, the mystery 'England three' allegedly on a bookie's payroll and cricketers world-wide will be offered an amnesty to talk to authorities about corruption in the game.
fields.body:
The disgraced Hansie Cronje, the mystery 'England three' allegedly on a bookie's payroll and cricketers world-wide will be offered an amnesty to talk to authorities about corruption in the game.

That is the radical proposal to be discussed at Tuesday's emergency meeting of the International Cricket Council in London. David Richards, the ICC's chief executive, has acknowledged that such an extreme form of action may be necessary to garner the information required to help solve the problem of match-fixing, which has tarnished the image of the game throughout the world and particularly on the sub-continent where the biggest bookmakers operate.

But slashing the number of one-day international tournaments and fixtures - a move suggested by many cricket observers since the latest match-rigging scandal following Cronje's recent unmasking - is likely to be rejected by the ICC.

Richards says: 'What we must do is get together all the people who have the best interests of cricket at heart and bring forward the evidence, bring it into the public domain. We might have to do that in a discreet fashion; we might have to give an amnesty for people to bring forward that information. I don't have a personal problem with that. We have one day to clean all this up, put it behind the sport and move into the rest of the century in a fine way.'

A possible amnesty opens up several possibilities. It is unlikely to a lead to a stampede to Richards' door at the ICC offices at Lord's, but such a scheme might be of great interest to Cronje, who is currently in hiding in South Africa and keeping whatever information he has to himself.

The 'England three' named by Chris Lewis to the England Cricket Board could also take advantage - notwithstanding the Board's verdict, announced last week, that there is no case to answer.

It is reckoned that if Cronje is proven to be implicated in match fixing, then his cricket career is over. The meeting, to be held over two days on Tuesday and Wednesday, was called specifically to discuss the problem of match-fixing. It will be chaired by Jagmohan Dalmiya, the ICC president.

All the representatives of the Test playing countries will be in attendance, with England being represented by Lord MacLaurin, the chairman of the ECB. This is the second time the ICC have met to discuss the issue . The previous meeting, also hastily convened, was in Christchurch in January 1999. That one was prompted by the revelations that Shane Warne and Mark Waugh had received money from bookmakers for advice on one-day matches.

The volume of one-day internationals played around the globe each year will also be debated. It can be argued that some are so meaningless and held in such low esteem by the players, that the temptation to take easy money is greatly enhanced. This appeared to be the case when South Africa's players dis cussed an offer to 'throw' matches in India in 1996.

But Richards disputes this view vigorously: 'I'd be amazed if any player said any game at international level was meaningless. They're professionals and they're competitive by nature. I'd be absolutely astonished if any player said "Oh it's only a one-day game, I'll just go through the motions".

'To put forward the view that by reducing the amount of one-day cricket you're going to solve the problem - that's not a correct line of thought. I wouldn't support that at all.

'It takes one game of cricket and one person with bad intent and one person on the end of a bribe to accept it to cause the problem.'

Richards' full interview will be screened by Sky Sports tomorrow in their Extra Cover programme during the tea interval of the Hampshire-Warwickshire National League match.

If Richards really believes all the one-day matches played throughout the world each year are memorable and important, here's a challenge for him: can he tell us - without reference to this year's Wisden - who won the Sahara Cup, the Pepsi Cup and the Coca-Cola Champions Trophy in the 1998-9 season?

webTitle: A tuned Escort changing up from second

fields.headline: A tuned Escort changing up from second
fields.trailText: Ed Giddings: When last season ended I checked myself into Lilleshall in an effort to get as fit as I have ever been. I spent a total of 13 weeks there either side of Christmas and I loved it.
fields.body:
It's great to be playing cricket again. Over the last few weeks a lot of column inches have been written about the game but they have all tended to deal with matters off the pitch and that is not a good thing. Cricket is about what happens out in the middle and that is where I'm happiest to be.

The winter seemed to go very quickly but that is because I packed so much in.

When last season ended I had a holiday in Brazil and then I checked myself into Lilleshall in an effort to get as fit as I have ever been. I spent a total of 13 weeks there either side of Christmas and I loved it.

You're very secluded up in the north Shropshire countryside, even out of mobile phone range, and that means it is easy to concentrate on the job in hand.

John Brewer, who runs the National Sports Centre, and Matt Asquith worked out a regime for me that would improve my basic level of fitness and have me start the season in the best shape possible. I've always prided myself on the fact that I kept rumbling along and not breaking down - rather like an old Ford Escort - but it was time to up the ante.

I don't think there is a cricketer in the country who could hold his hand up and say, 'I couldn't be any fitter', and even after the work I've put I could still get fitter still but that isn't the way to go.

The cricket season is a marathon not a sprint. We will be playing 100 days of cricket over a 140 day stretch and so you don't want to run the risk of doing yourself any damage. It's not good for the team and doesn't do you any favours.

When I was at Sussex I played in the same side as Paul Parker, one of the best cover fielders ever. Paul was the fittest guy I've ever seen - he had the perfect six pack - but he was very injury prone. In the course of two years when our careers over-lapped we only played in the same side about twice due to Paul being out of commission. There's no point in having a Ferrari if it spends its life in the workshop.

I'm now as fit and strong as I've ever been and ready for the season to really get going.

I took some time off in December to sell Christmas trees with Nadeem Shahid, the Surrey batsman, and then we headed for Australia. Seeing in the new Millennium in Sydney was quite thrill but we made a pact to get back to work by 3 January. There are worse places to work out than on the thirty-first floor of Sydney's Continental Hotel but Down Under is full of temptations. 50 lengths of the pool or 18 holes of golf is no contest so I headed back to England and checked back into Lilleshall.

People might think that was a strange decision but I loved the routine and put in some serious graft. Hopefully the results will be borne this summer.

Cricketers who don't play cricket in the winter do get up to some curious things. My Warwickshire team-mate Dougie Brown seems to have found himself some gainful employment in the clothing business. He's now sporting a complete new wardrobe of designer gear - all at knockdown prices. In the past, before he was a regular in the England side, Andy Caddick spent his winters being a handyman at Somerset's ground in Taunton and, stranger still, the Wells brothers, Colin and Alan have worked at Newhaven docks. Thinking of them doesn't make Lilleshall seem like such hard work.

Pre-season training was again spent in the delights of Bloemfontein. Our new coach Bob Woolmer, or Lord Bob as he is know in South Africa, has really picked the squad up after a difficult 1999. Although for much of the time we were out there it rained, and rained unbelievably hard, Bob's influence is really starting to rub off. He is a great help to the batsmen in particular since he concentrates so hard on the mental side of the game. Batters respond to that kind of thing.

The weather back here has insured that the new season has only dribbled into life. The rain completely ruined the group stages of the Benson & Hedges Cup and Warwickshire are already out of that competition. I don't know why we play the early stages of a prestigious competition (it does end in a Lord's final) so early in the season when its more likely to be wet. The public love one-day cricket but they aren't going to pay to watch when they are more likely to be soaked than see any cricket.

There is an upside to the downpours. Warwickshire are sitting out the first round of County Championship games and since there's been very little cricket played at all it is more than likely that most fixtures will end in draws. That gives us a chance to steal a march on the others if we get off to a winning start this week.

The main aim for this season is to get out of the Second Division in both the Championship and the one-day league. With three teams being promoted in the County Championship we are good enough to go up but we are aiming to go up as champions.

It will interesting to see how the two division system works this summer. It's certainly going to provide a lot more meaningful matches and that will mean better cricket. There's a host of top quality overseas stars playing here and there are England places up for grabs. It's going to quite a season.

I couldn't have prepared better for the summer ahead and I intend to take every opportunity to show what I can do.

fields.headline: O'Leary 'not going to Celtic'
fields.trailText: Scottish round-up
fields.body:
reports that Leeds United's David O'Leary is poised to become Celtic manager are way off the mark, according to the Leeds chairman, Peter Ridsdale. 'There has been no interest from Celtic and I presume that if there was, they would have had the courtesy to contact me,' Ridsdale said. 'I have spoken with him this morning and he has reaffirmed his commitment to the club. As far as I am concerned, the story is tomorrow's chip paper.'

Ironically, also wide off the mark was Celtic's finishing in the 1-1 draw at Motherwell, although they did get full marks in terms of their fighting spirit. Mark Burchill, who only came into the side minutes before the kick-off after an injury Johann Mjallby in the warm-up, capitalised on a mistake by goalkeeper Stephen Woods to put Celtic ahead after 16 minutes. Celtic, inspired by Burchill, then created a number of good chances. They certainly should have gone further ahead when Mark Viduka went crashing to the ground, somewhat theatrically, under the challenge of Benito Kemble and the referee gave them a penalty, But Woods saved Viduka's kick, and even kept out a follow-up effort from the Australian.

Celtic suffered more injury problems when Jackie McNamara was carried off in the 40th minute after an innocuous looking challenge on Don Goodman; and on the stroke of half-time, they were forced to rue their missed chances when Ged Brannan scored Motherwell's equaliser from a free-kick.

Celtic had their chances in the second half, too. One of the worst misses came from defender Vidar Riseth, who played a neat one-two with Viduka, took the ball around Woods, but blasted it high over the bar. Then it was Viduka's turn - again - to show that players are not infallible. He was played through by Burchill, but shot wide with only Woods to beat.

Hibernian marked their last home match before the redevelopment of their ground with a 1-0 win over Aberdeen. The scorer was Keith Miller, who - ironically - found the net when his team had the advantage of playing down that famous Easter Road slope. Hibs manager Alex McLeish said: 'I felt we passed the ball about very well today. We told them to go out and enjoy the game. Grant Brebner was excellent. He has struggled to find a performance this season but this match will do him the world of good as he tries to find consistency for next season.'

Aberdeen boss Ebbe Skovdahl felt his side were unlucky but agreed that they they looked jaded. 'They only had us under real pressure for 10 minutes of the second half but in the second half we did not create enough chances.'

St Johnstone, also 1-0 winners, at Dundee United, owed their success to a Darren Dods header - his first goal of the season. Unusually for a Premier League match, this one flowed from end to end. But the visitors were the more impressive side. Their breakthrough came in the 67th minute when Dods came in to blast a header in from eight yards after Maurice Malpas had deflected a cross into the defender's path.

St Mirren clinched the First Division championship with three goals in eight minutes against Raith.

George Burley's Ipswich may have kept up the pressure for the second automatic promotion spot in the Nationwide First Division, but Burley admitted that Manchester City remain favourites to finish runners-up. 'They need only a point at Blackburn next weekend,' he pointed out. 'I know it's a tough fixture, but City have got to be favourites.'

fields.headline: Vialli is vindicated
fields.trailText: Chelsea 2 - 0 Liverpool
fields.body:
Goal-shy Chelsea went into the game without a win in four matches, having lost three of them. Liverpool, the team with the best defensive record in the Premiership, had won five of their past six as part of an unbeaten run of 13 games. Wouldn't you know it, football being the perverse game it is, Chelsea strolled to victory, revelling in the sunshine on their backs at the end of their wet April.

Two goals in the opening quarter of an hour, by George Weah and Roberto Di Matteo, kept alive Chelsea's lingering hopes of the third Champions' League place for a second season but Liverpool, who occupy the position, will surely not play so lamely again.

'We were indifferent, sloppy,' lamented their manager, Gérard Houllier.

'I would like to think we played well rather than Liverpool playing badly. The first half was almost as good as we played against Barcelona here,' said the Chelsea manager, Gianluca Vialli, who had given his side an earful after their own surrender to a half-paced Manchester United last Monday but did not cite it as a reason for his team's improvement.

'They were upset with themselves,' he added. 'This result was more because we had time to prepare. The quality is there and when we are rested, focussed, we are difficult to beat.' It is remarkable what a threat to a player's FA Cup final place, or the promise of one, can do, though, and what new energy it can put into ageing legs, of which they are a few pairs in this Chelsea side.

Vialli's team selection initially looked curious; no surprise that a reportedly annoyed Didier Deschamps and Dan Petrescu were left out amid last week's debate about players' commitment to the cause, but Tore Andre Flo? With the second top scorer, Gustavo Poyet, beginning the game on the bench after returning from a match for Uruguay only on Friday, where would the goals come from, since Gianfranco Zola and Weah had only managed five in the league between them?

This was a team with pride stung, however. Mario Melchiot struck the tone immediately by winning the ball in midfield with a forceful tackle and found Roberto Di Matteo. His through ball caught Sami Hyppia uncharacteristically out of position and Weah in space, the Liberian steering it home expertly. Just 124 seconds had elapsed.

Soon it was two. Liverpool were again stretched, Zola pulling wide and his ball infield to Weah was ferried on to a revitalised Di Matteo who was left unmarked to side-foot home. This was more the Liverpool defence of previous seasons, porous early on and the side left chasing the game.

They never looked likely to catch up, with Chelsea's fluency fuelled by the mobile Dennis Wise and Jody Morris in the centre of midfield, where Steven Gerrard and Dietmar Hamann were unusually submissive. It helped when Jamie Redknapp, feeling his way back to fitness, came on to replace Gerrard, victim of a groin strain, with his range of passing finally getting Michael Owen and Emile Heskey moving- but still there was little doing for them, Marcel Desailly dominant.

Mostly there were restricted to long shots, Hamann wide several times, and unconvincing penalty appeals, notably when Ed de Goey brought down Patrik Berger, the referee, Graham Barber, ruling that the Czech had fouled the goalkeeper earlier, however. It was late in the game, Houllier by then having thrown on Robbie Fowler to form a four up front, before they even went close, De Goey touching away Heskey's shot from Jon Harley's weak header back.

Chelsea created little more after their early surge, save for Di Matteo's cross-shot tipped over by Sander Westerveld and another that he drove wide, but then they had little need to, so ineffectual were Liverpool. 'My one regret is that this was not the true face, the true football, of my team,' said Houllier.

One man's meat is another's poisson, he might muse. Houllier cited Chelsea's experience as a factor in their superiority over his young team; Vialli pointed to his team's 61 games compared with Liverpool's 43 as a reason for his team's recent run and the opponents' surge. Houllier said he still needs more nous to compete consistently at the top, Vialli that he would be looking to lower the average age of his squad in the summer.

Even allowing for this aberration, Liverpool's looks the more likely third way.

Liverpool were again stretched, Zola pulling wide and his ball infield to Weah was ferried on to a revitalised Di Matteo who was left unmarked to side-foot home. This was more the Liverpool defence of previous seasons, porous early on and the side left chasing the game. They never looked likely to catch up, with Chelsea's fluency fuelled by the mobile Dennis Wise and Jody Morris in the centre of midfield, where Steven Gerrard and Dietmar Hamann were unusually submissive. It helped when Jamie Redknapp, feeling his way back to fitness, came on to replace Gerrard, victim of a groin strain, with his range of passing finally getting Michael Owen and Emile Heskey moving- but still there was little doing for them, Marcel Desailly dominant. Mostly there were restricted to long shots, Hamann wide several times, and unconvincing penalty appeals, notably when Ed de Goey brought down Patrik Berger, the referee, Graham Barber, ruling that the Czech had fouled the goalkeeper earlier, however. It was late in the game, Houllier by then having thrown on Robbie Fowler to form a four up front, before they even went close, De Goey touching away Heskey's shot from Jon Harley's weak header back. Chelsea created little more after their early surge, save for Di Matteo's cross-shot tipped over by Sander Westerveld and another that he drove wide, but then they had little need to, so ineffectual were Liverpool. 'My one regret is that this was not the true face, the true football, of my team,' said Houllier. One man's meat is another's poisson, he might muse. Houllier cited Chelsea's experience as a factor in their superiority over his young team; Vialli pointed to his team's 61 games compared with Liverpool's 43 as a reason for his team's recent run and the opponents' surge. Houllier said he still needs more nous to compete consistently at the top, Vialli that he would be looking to lower the average age of his squad in the summer. Even allowing for this aberration, Liverpool's looks the more likely third way.

fields.headline: Sky Blues' travel sickness
fields.trailText: Newcastle 2 - 0 Coventry
fields.byline: John Wardle at St James's Park
fields.body:
A trip to Watford represents Coventry's last chance to avoid the ignominy of going through the Premiership season without winning an away game. The omens are not encouraging for Gordon Strachan's team.

The manager now speaks of a massive mental barrier confronting his players, who were heading towards a morale-boosting point yesterday before late goals from Alan Shearer and Diego Gavilan.

Strachan said: 'It looks like a psychological problem. With the talent in the team, you would think we would make more chances and make it more exciting.

'There are good players out there, but individuals have got to say it's my day and I'm going to change things. Until then, we will always be up against it.'

Strachan should be mildly encouraged that some of his players did yesterday accept responsibility, after Coventry emerged unscathed from an immensely awkward opening 15 minutes when Newcastle went close on four occasions.

With striker Robbie Keane soon withdrawn into a midfield role to stifle United, City only threatened with two long-range shots from Moustapha Hadji.

Yet they were just 13 minutes away from ending a run of seven away defeats when luck deserted them and referee Peter Jones harshly decided Noel Whelan had handled inside the area.

'I didn't see it, but my players didn't think it was a penalty,' said Strachan, forsaking his normally abrasive reaction when decisions go against him. 'He's not going to change his mind. There's nothing we can do about it.'

Even Newcastle manager Bobby Robson displayed some sympathy for Whelan. 'It looked a bit fortuitous, but I still think we edged the game,' he said.

Shearer drove in the penalty for his twenty-ninth goal of the season - his best tally for Newcastle - and is now one away from the 300th of his career.

At the other end of the scoring scale, Paraguayan international Gavilan calmly accepted his first goal in England when Temuri Ketsbaia's angled pass presented him with an 84th-minute opening.

The Paraguayan winger is a player much admired by Robson and it was obvious why when he set up two of those early openings for Shearer. 'Diego's refreshing and positive,' said his manager. 'There's a bit of Beckham in him when he crosses the ball.'

Gavilan, just 19, eventually faded, along with most of the forwards on both sides. Robson said: 'Defenders subdued the attackers in both areas. There was no cutting edge. I said at half-time that the game would be won by a set-piece.'

To cap Coventry's latest unhappy experience on their travels, Cedric Roussel was carried off with a knee injury that will keep him out of the final two games.

fields.headline: Quintessential Niall
fields.trailText: Aston Villa 1- 1 Sunderland
fields.body:
With the stage set for Kevin Phillips to make history by becoming only the third player in Premiership history to score 30 goals in a season, up popped Aston Villa's Gareth Barry to steal his thunder with his first strike of the campaign.

The fact Sunderland salvaged a point to keep their Uefa Cup ambitions alive was thanks to Niall Quinn, the less celebrated half of the partnership, who hit his side's 85th minute equaliser.

On the day Phillips had been voted runner-up in the Football Writer's Footballer of the Year award, he had probably his most anonymous game of the season.

Kept quiet by Gareth Southgate, returning to action after six matches injured, the Sunderland striker was left beating the turf in frustration as he failed to get even an opportunity to add to his 29 goals.

Along with the announcement of the FWA award, the blossom swirling around nearby Aston Park was another reminder that the sea son is drawing rapidly to a close. Both sides, however, still have plenty to look forward to. For Villa there is the prospect of their first FA Cup Final for 43 years while Sunderland are chasing a top 10 finish in England's top division for the first time since 1956.

Villa's manager, John Gregory, continued his recent policy of rotation to give everyone the opportunity to stake a Wembley claim. 'One or two said "I'm not bothered if I play or not",' he said, indicating his disgust with some of his players' attitudes.

Indeed, for most of the first half, the mood of depression that has settled over Birmingham in recent days appeared to envelop Villa, who acknowledged the mood in the city with a giant hoarding declaring: 'Villa support Rover workers'.

Paul Merson, who as a former Middlesbrough player was made to feel as welcome by the Sunderland fans as a BMW executive down the Hagley Road, was particularly disappointing. The turning point came after half an hour when he was off the pitch receiving treatment for an injury and took a telephone call in the dug-out from Gregory. It was unlikely he was asking who won the 3.30 at Sandown but, whatever was said, he was a different player after it. Merson turned Sunderland inside out throughout the second half as Phillips could only watch and admire.

Yet when Villa did take the lead it came from a most unlikely source. For Phillips a game without a goal is like a day without a drink for an alcoholic, but for Barry a goal is like your great aunt's small sherry at Christmas - a once a year experience.

Not that Sunderland joined in his joy. They claim their keeper, Thomas Sorensen, was blocked as he came for Alan Thompson's corner, leaving Barry a relatively simple task of heading the ball past Michael Gray on the line.

Therefore, they will have seen justice in Quinn's equaliser. The 6ft 4in Irishman once more belied the myth that he has no skill by collecting Nicky Summerbee's corner and driving a low shot into the corner for his 14th goal of the season.

webTitle: Ince still the Guv'nor in old manor

fields.headline: Ince still the Guv'nor in old manor
fields.trailText: West Ham 0 - 1 Middlesbrough
fields.body:
Paul Ince returned to his former club and helped inflict a defeat that leaves West Ham's hopes of European football in the balance. Ince never expects a warm East End welcome and the self-styled Guv'nor certainly was afforded little respect on his former manor.

His attempts to dominate the midfield battle were stifled by Frank Lampard, whose service to Frédéric Kanouté was the catalyst to the Hammers' early dominance. However, Brian Deane's 60th-minute penalty ensured Ince had the last laugh.

'Paul's been playing very well recently. He knows the reception he'll get and it doesn't bother him,' said the Boro manager, Bryan Robson.

'Compared with how he was treated by West Ham fans when playing for Manchester United, today was quite placid. Perhaps the Hammers fans are beginning to forget.'

The defeat left Harry Redknapp pondering the remote possibility of a Uefa Cup place. 'It's going to be very hard now,' said the West Ham manager.

'I've got two keepers out through injury and my current keeper is carrying an injury. I don't have a left or right full-back either.

'It certainly won't be easy but let's be positive. This club has only finished in the top half of the table 15 times in its entire history. This year we'll be in the top half for the third year in succession, so that can't be bad. People get very carried away about Europe. We've got a good side, built on a shoestring, and we are up there challenging. I don't see any real reason for disappointment.'

He had no problems about the match-winning penalty and said: 'We had a lot of chances but didn't convert them - that was the difference.'

Despite the promptings of Kanouté - with an attention-grabbing first-half performance - chances remained thin on the ground in the first half. A well-worked training ground combination between Ferdinand, Foé and Lampard presented the Hammers with their best scoring opportunity but in a crowded penalty area Lampard failed to steer his header on target.

West Ham continued to dominate after the break but against the run of play Mark Summerbell split the Hammers defence with a beautifully-weighted pass to Andy Campbell.

The striker chased down the loose ball but his attempt to turn and shoot was curtailed by a rash challenge from Ian Feuer. The keeper was cautioned and Boro seized the lead with Deane's thundering penalty.

fields.headline: Europe lure for Wales
fields.trailText: Kilmarnock 0 - 1 Hearts
fields.body:
Gary Wales' cool finish made Hearts hot favourites to triumph in the last issue that remains to be settled in the Scottish Premier League - the third place that offers qualification for the Uefa Cup. The young striker's goal took his team seven points clear of Motherwell with three matches remaining.

This prospect of a worthwhile reward - as well as the home side's commitment to ending the season well removed from bottom place - may not have been essential to give an edge to a fixture that is always diligently contested, but these elements did ensure that neither manager would contemplate anything other than formations designed to go for the jugular.

It is Kilmarnock's curse, however, that whatever goals they may produce will be in numbers entirely disproportionate to the opportunities they contrive.

Particularly during a first half in which they kept the Hearts defenders and goalkeeper Antti Niemi busy and in a mild state of alarm for sustained periods, Kilmarnock supporters were subjected once again to the cruel experience of leaping from their seats in anticipation only to land with a heavy thump.

Niemi was to blame for most of their disappointment, the Finnish goalkeeper effecting a string of saves that allowed the home players off the charge of incompetence.

Niemi would have difficulty in improving on the effort he produced shortly before the interval, when Ally Mitchell's slick work ended with a flick back to the incoming Gus MacPherson. The vet eran full-back hit the drive sweetly and the ball would have hurtled into the top corner but for Niemi's leap and interception.

The goalkeeper was summoned again from Ian Durrant's corner kick - played to Tosh McKinlay who curled the ball towards the near corner of the net. As the realisation dawned on Niemi that the orthodox centre had been abandoned in favour of a surprise, he flew across his goal in time to push the ball wide of his right-hand post.

Kilmarnock's sustained aggressiveness before the interval also brought regular menacing crosses into the visitors' box, some scrambled to safety, others missed by their intended recipients, but all hinting at the probability that the home team would be first to score.

Football's infinite capacity for torture ensured that it would be Hearts, whose most convertible chance had come from a mistake by young Sean Hessey. His header back to Gordon Marshall dropped at the feet of Gary McSwegan, who dragged the ball wide of the goalkeeper and to the left of goal. The Hearts forward's scoring attempt was feeble, his shot trundling towards the line and allowing Chris Innes time to drive it clear.

It was naive defending that helped Hearts to their goal, too, early in the second half. Having formed an inflexibly straight back line, the home defenders remained static as Lee Makel's pass released Gary Wales into the penalty box on the left and the under-21 international slid the ball under Marshall as the goalkeeper made his challenge.

But whatever demon sometimes possesses the Kilmarnock players faced with the unmissable chance took over Paul Wright in the 69th minute. Unchallenged as he met a low centre from Mitchell on the right, the striker accomplished the seemingly impossible by lifting the ball over the crossbar from a range of two yards.

fields.headline: Buy, buy buy in Dubai
fields.standfirst: Marjorie Yue visits a desert state that's become a shopper's paradise and a place where architects' imaginations are running wild and creating a skyline which threatens to put Hong Kong in the shade
fields.trailText: Marjorie Yue visits a desert state that's become a shopper's paradise and a place where architects' imaginations are running wild and creating a skyline which threatens to put Hong Kong in the shade
fields.body:
To the shopping cognoscenti it may not have the crowning chic of Paris, or the halo of hipness of New York but what Dubai does have in bucketfuls is three seductive S's, desertsand, ceaseless sun and the Arabian sea. Last month, tourists to this United Arab Emirates city would have bagged the ultimate bargain - the combination of a festival wholly dedicated to retail therapy with a spot of 'thalasso' therapy at one of the burgeoning number of Dubai's beach hotels.

Its fourth annual Shopping Festival was deemed a runaway success when more that 2.4 million visitors went on a spending spree estimated at some £235 million at a multitude of malls (shopaholics should consult the Dubai Shopping Centres Directory) and stalls set up alongside the Creek - the watery divide bisecting Dubai into Deira and Bur Dubai.

Judging from the number of skyhigh structures dotting the horizon, there is an architectural spree of similar proportions. Attracted by the magnet of enormous wealth coupled with the clearance to let imaginations run wild, architects worldwide have been drawn like bees to the honeypot. It seems only a matter of time before its eclectic buildings will be giving the Hong Kong skyline a run for its money.

Of the many buildings vying for attention the jaw-dropping outline of the Burj Al Arab reigns supreme. Closer inspection of this gigantic billowing sail on its very own manmade island reveals the tallest hotel in the world, standing at 321 metres of 60 floors, complete with its own helipad and underwater restaurant and registered at an unofficial six stars rating. Echoing the form of a breaking wave, its sister property the Jumeirah Beach is equally breathtaking. The architects' brief was to create a structure that would be iconic, incorporating the Arabian seafaring heritage using a high-tech modern sail.

The opening of the Arabian fantasy-themed Royal Mirage Hotel on Jumeirah beach may signal a return to the traditional.The city total stands at 266 hotels and still counting - another five are due to open next year. This high-tech flow of glass, concrete and steel throughout Dubai, serves to mirror the moneyed international mix of largely non-national residents here to make their fortunes and tourists eager to spend theirs.

Pickings for culture vultures may not be plentiful in a city so firmly focused on the future but first-time visitors should not bypass the Dubai Museum. Housed in the restored Al-Fahidi Fort dating back to 1799, on the Bur Dubai side of the Creek, the mix of hands-on exhibits, static displays and hologram films presents an easily digested insight into the history, customs and life in the desert. Not far from the museum is the Bastakia quarter containing the few remaining examples of houses that were the residences of wealthy Iranian merchants with their unique windtowers - a pre-electric method of air-conditioning.

Board an abra, one of the water taxis that crisscross the creek, to get your bearings or just walk along the dhow wharfage to get a flavour of the cargo being unloaded from India, South Africa and South East Asia.

The second largest of the seven Emirates has historically traded lucratively on its location at the crossroads of Europe, Asia and Africa, bringing exotic woods and spices from India and silks from China.

But Dubai's development suffered a hiccup in the 1930s when its pearl industry plunged into decline with the development of the cultured variety by the Japanese. Gold quickly replaced pearls as the precious commodity for trade when the enterprising Sheikh Rashid (Dubai's ruler at the time) sought other resources. Stroll along Deira's Sikkat Al Khail Street, the main artery of its renowned Gold Souk and be dazzled by window display upon window display of the metal in every shade and description, from intricate works of art to plain ingots. Here all that glitters with the lustre of gold will be genuine - stringent laws operate to vouchsafe authenticity.

If you're not content with just window-shopping be prepared to play the game of bartering as part of the shopping experience and don't be surprised when scales are produced - gold is normally sold according to weight - design is usually immaterial.

For light retail relief away from the malls, head for cooler climes of Hatta village, a favourite retreat in the Hajar Mountains with the urban crowd. Tours offer plenty of scope to go dune riding in a 4WD, explore the wadis (dried riverbeds) and rockpool oases and even try sandskiing.

Having shopped until you drop during your stay and checked in more luggage than you recall bringing with you, Dubai airport's duty free shops will still beckon.

Marjorie Yue travelled with BA Holidays 0870 24 24 245; www.baholidays.co.uk which features five nights b&b at the Royal Mirage starting at £745 including return scheduled flights from Heathrow (free flight connection to Heathrow available from selected regional airports) and transfers.

Tours offer plenty of scope to go dune riding in a 4WD, explore the wadis (dried riverbeds) and rockpool oases and even try sandskiing. Having shopped until you drop during your stay and checked in more luggage than you recall bringing with you, Dubai airport's duty free shops will still beckon. fields.headline: All things Brighton beautiful
fields.standfirst: Whether it's visiting an artist's home or meeting China's most famous transsexual, the south coast festival has it all, writes  Jeremy Novick
fields.trailText: Whether it's visiting an artist's home or meeting China's most famous transsexual, the south coast festival has it all, writes Jeremy Novick
fields.body:
'Medieval fools hatched from eggs, pigs roasting butchers on spits, dwarves wielding enemas, a sixteenth-century mock-religious diptych that opens to reveal a grimacing face and a naked bottom, horses riding in man-drawn carriages, women riding on cockerels, battles between pots and pans, a transvestite performance artist and a tattooed lady.' It's that time of year again when England's biggest arts festival kicks off and, for the best part of a month, arty, tarty Brighton becomes the happening place it thinks it is. Somehow it's fitting that the curtain-raiser to the summer should happen in Brighton.

The story of Brighton is well-known: people who want to be cosmopolitan but not metropolitan, people who want a cool hippie vibe but don't want to live in a head-shop like Totnes. People who want a good cup of coffee, an arts cinema and a beach. London by the sea? It 's a cliché, but probably a fair assessment. Brighton is characterised and shaped by its refugees, from the students to the new parents determined that responsibility shouldn't mean the end of life. It's no surprise that the first of the Juicy Guides, a new series of hip guide books aimed at people who've grown up but don't want to grow up, is being launched in Brighton.

'Brighton's always been a town which revels in its diversity and its extraordinary culture of differences,' says Lucy Shuttleworth, co-writer of The Juicy Guide to Brighton and Hove. 'I don't buy that London-by-the-sea idea because it's not elitist. It's just people who want to live in a civilised place where you're not judged by what you do but on who you are.'

Maybe the best way of explaining the spirit of the Brighton Festival is this. At other festivals you might see people from such different worlds as American opera star Willard White, Chinese choreographer Wang Jianwei, Azerbaijani 'mugham' singer Alim Qasimov, Alan Titchmarsh and Jah Wobble. After all, that's what arts festivals are for, to cross-pollinate ideas and experiences. But where else could you see all of the above and then hit the beach to join in the Mackerel Fair and celebrate the Blessing Of The Nets? Really, go to the beach between the two piers on Sunday May 21 at 11am and you can join in the hymns ('For Those In Peril On The Sea') as the boats sail in with what is traditionally the year's first mackerel catch. It 's different, no? Boats and beats. Brighton's idea of a good time.

This year's festival, the 34th and the most ambitious yet, kicks off next Saturday with a children's parade along the beach and through the town to the Pavilion. Christopher Barron, the festival's artistic director and chief executive, has put together a diverse programme where you can see international art stars like Bill T. Jones and Hugh Masekela and then pop along to a local artist's house. The Open Houses, where artists turn their homes into living art galleries, is unique to the festival. Since local artist Ned Hoskins first thought of the idea 17 years ago, it has become the biggest show of contemporary art in the South-east. This year, more than 250 homes will be exhibiting paintings, sculptures, ceramics, photography and furniture, with everything for sale.

Barron, an associate director at Edinburgh for eight years, is particularly proud of the Chinese acts, which were arranged over two years and include the Guangdong Modern Dance Company, mainland China's first contemporary dance company, the theatre director Wang Jianwei and Jin Xing, once a male colonel in the People's Liberation Army but now China's first high-profile transsexual, a prize-winning dancer and the owner of what is apparently Beijing's hottest night club.

In terms of music, the attitude is summed up in the festival brochure. 'It seems odd that we parcel up our music into classical, contemporary, rock, world and many other distinct areas. The connections between each are increasingly obvious as musicians blur the lines.' So we get mesmeric New York art-rockers Yo La Tengo, South African trumpeter Hugh Masekela and American pianist Brad Mehldau. The best-known name is Jah Wobble, who's launching his new album Molam Dub , a record that finds Wobble taking in sounds from China, Laos and Thailand.

The Chinese State Circus, Simon Callow's one-man show, a fusion opera by New York composer John Adams; Roy Hattersley and Ann Widdecombe - we could go on. On The Streets Of Brighton weekend (May 12 and 13), the streets come alive with parades, impromptu shows, music and performance art in all its various guises. Stand in one spot for too long and before you know it there'll be people taking photos and you'll have a booking for Edinburgh.

Carnivalesque we've talked about. The medieval fools being hatched from eggs, remember? Carnivalesque? Brightonesque more like.

The Juicy Guide To Brighton and Hove (Juicy Books) by Gilly Smith and Lucy Shuttleworth is out now, £6.99
