fields.headline: Devilishly beautiful
fields.standfirst: The screeching scavenger that is Tasmania's best known mammal was the only thing less than perfect that  Euan Ferguson saw in a week on the edge of the world. Well, that and the compost toilets...
fields.trailText: The screeching scavenger that is Tasmania's best known mammal was the only thing less than perfect that Euan Ferguson saw in a week on the edge of the world. Well, that and the compost toilets...
fields.body:
You get a lot of thinking done on a three-hour walk along a beach, especially if it happens to be empty and absurdly beautiful and soft as talcum and every cloud in the sky is off annoying the idiots who choose to live up in mainland Australia. Random thoughts: some big, some small.

Thoughts such as: isn't this wonderful. Or: I wonder if this wave's going to reach my shorts. Or: maybe this one, then. Or: whee, yes! Or: I wonder if countries get the beaches they deserve (answer: probably. Think Austria, or Rwanda). And: how many oysters I can eat tonight - 30? 40? And: if only the buggers could see me now, the grim work buggers, who would seethe at my happiness. And: Tasmania is the most perfect country on God's earth. And, finally, the big one: why don't I just move here? It's been a week of unalloyed joy - why not keep it going?

I won't, of course. They were beach thoughts, wet-foot thoughts. But there was nothing I could come up with, that day or since, which was not completely in Tassie's favour as a retreat. One, I suppose: it takes a long time to get there: another hour or two's flying after Melbourne. And, believe me, you don't want to come back. Sitting on the last night on the dockside in Hobart - prawns, sunset, boats, clinking bottles of the marvellous Pipers Brook Chardonnay - I was contemplating the trip home with the same grim horror which 1830s convicts must have felt on leaving England .

In fact, I had already caught myself thinking naughtily, days before, as we blinked in the high hot sun over the gauzy and grandiose sweep of the bay at Stanley, which was the major northern port during the years of transportation - well, look, can it really have been that bad? I mean, your convicts would have come off the ship, grumbling queasily about the lack of proper entertainment or the annoying number of their relatives who had died nastily at sea or whatever, and seen this. Majesty. Sunshine. Green, green fields; mountains and forests; luscious sands, stretching impossibly. Wouldn't that have beaten whatever dank grey stinking northern dump they'd just been deported from?

A stupid thought, of course. Obviously the land was a living hell. Read just half a chapter of Robert Hughes's magnificent The Fatal Shore , and you will be in no doubt about perhaps the most shaming period in Britain's not noticeably shame-free history. Not only did we use the experiment of an island jail to deport and beat and kill and enslave many thousands of our own; we wiped out the locals too. Every single native aborigine in Tasmania died. They were hunted down for sport. Today, a team of scientists from Hobart is spending its time in the interior trying to work out which roots and berries are poisonous or medicinal: thousand upon thousand of years' knowledge which whitey could have had for free had we bothered to let one native stay alive. You get hot flushes of retrospective anger and mortification.

So, a stupid thought, but one that didn't go unthunk. Because Tassie is, today, close to paradise. It's the size of the Irish Republic but with the population of Croydon, which means it's deserted; but because of its situation, off the south coast of Oz, it's a bit more interesting than Ireland (though not, obviously, than Croydon; perish the thought). It's as if someone had taken Australia and crammed all the best bits into a bite-sized chunk; so you get rainforests, mountains, beaches and bars, impenetrable jungle waterways and lush, vivid meadows, all cosying up to each other and nothing over a couple of days' four-wheeled drive away.

First stop, high in the hills, was Cradle Mountain and Dove Lake, around which we dragged our jet-lagged bodies with a reluctance soon dissipated by the magnificent surroundings. I had thought I would never eat again, having had about 17 airline meals in the past 12 hours, but we did, heartily, at both the Cradle Mountain and that night's retreat, the isolated Lemonthyme Lodge, learning swiftly that Tassie food and wine is, frankly, too good to leave to the Tasmanians. Pausing only to watch the the nightly feeding at the back porch, where possums, wallabies and wombats gather to be thrown scraps, we lumbered off to lovely beds the size of aircraft hangars and slept the sleep of the absolutely zonked. But in the morning all jet lag had fled, the sun was high and magnificent, a gargantuan breakfast was beckoning, and there then began seven of the best days of my life.

The mountains had seemed impressive from below; skimming their tops from 5,000 feet in a little Cessna, they were awesome. The space, the emptiness, are almost scary; gazing down on some remote waterfall or forest, you think back on this island's history and you just know that man has never set foot on that spot, and possibly never will.

Back on the ground, having skirted the rich farming country around Stanley and the old, old forests, where logging - the careful, sustainable stuff, for the whole eco thing is huge down here - provides the only roads, we filled up with yet another fine steak and fish barbie and several gallons of the wonderful Spring Vale wine (not available, tragically, in Britain, unless I decide to make my fortune by starting to import it), we turned a corner, bumped over dunes, and were confronted with one of the most glorious (and gloriously named) coastal panoramas on the planet.

This little settlement, its white beaches pounded by grandiose seas which have run wild and unceasing from South America, is called The Edge of The World. Big seas, big space, big thoughts - this was where I first began entertaining bad thoughts about, basically, running away and coming here to live. Peace, freedom, beaches, sun, manic seas, a pub just up the road - and I mean, it's an address to die for. By now I was falling in love with this wild country.

And the whole of that western coast is similar in scale and raw power, as the Pacific - Tasmania is bounded by no fewer than four oceans, each with its distinct character - keeps on keeping on, forever. Way up on the very north-west tip, where the Pacific meets the Bass Strait, lies Cape Grim, one of the most inspiring pieces of plungy-cliff architecture in the world, which reminded me strongly of Scotland's Cape Wrath and is equally swept with wind and history.

Here, at the cape, sits the weather monitoring station that proves Tasmania does, literally, have the cleanest air in the world. (Tasmanians, normally so laid back as to make mainland Aussies look like screaming uptight anal retentives, will tell you of this fact slightly too often, along with the related one that they have the cleanest water in the world. It should irk, but, frankly, as long as they keep the good clean oysters coming they can be reading out lists of plankton counts in Welsh).

The squat little station, perched by the very edge of the cliffs, has arrays of insanely sensitive monitors, designed to pick up one part of pollen in a million or whatever as the wind hits them fresh from Antarctica or the Americas. It is apparently a marvellous feat of engineering, a fact which I stupidly celebrated by lighting a cigarette about 20 feet away. I like to think of half a dozen technicians, fathoms below, suddenly ripping off their headphones with cries of fear as the monitors went loco, as if someone had begun pumping anthrax down the tubes, or someone in Tierra del Fuego had startedto play something by Andrew Lloyd-Webber.

My only problem with the cape lies in the fact that it is 'owned' - how can someone 'own' a wild place like this? - by the Van Diemens Land Company, the conglomerate which farms the area and, basically, charges you to come in and stay at its ranch house and take its Land-Rover up to the cliffs. Very nice accommodation it was, too, but I couldn't help feeling this stuff should be free. Stephanie, the pleasant PR for the area, didn't seem to understand my increasingly guttural Marxist ranting, loyally repeating the words of the corporate mantra. The argument was truly going nowhere. So I waited until no one was looking, then pushed her off the cliff.

Later that night, things got seriously good again, as we saw our first Tasmanian devils. The two-hour silent wait in the hide was well worth it, when finally, shockingly, alerted by the wet snuffles, our guide flicked on a low light to reveal two of the beasts ripping the bejesus out of a dead wallaby. The devils are truly horrible animals. They look like a cross between a pig and a dog. Nearly blind, they come out only to scavenge, and they will eat every bit of anything - each other, human babies - including bone and fur, crunching down with jaws which, pound for pound, have the same force as those of the Great White. Then they will let out the most terrible, guttural, blood-turning, buttock-clenching screams, the genesis of their name.

On we went, through the warm and lazy vineyards around Launceston (where we had been shocked to see - yes - a traffic light) to the most memorable two nights of the trip.

The Bay of Fires Lodge, reached after a long and bumpy four-wheel ride, sits above the Tasman Sea, high on the north-east corner. I almost don't want to give away any more; it's so remote, and so beautiful, that I don't want anyone else to know the precise location. Here, anyway, for the next two days, we swam, and walked, and walked, and swam, and body-surfed, and walked some more, retreating each evening to the magnificent new timbered eco-lodge, where the guides - all young, all apparently supermodels, all intensely knowledgable about the wildlife and history but, crucially, fun with it - would prepare groaning galleys of seafood and ply us with ludicrous amounts of Spring Vale until we passed out, replete, high above the midnight surf.

The eco stuff is big here, but it's not in-your-face. So there are composting toilets, and you pump through your own water for the showers, but apart from that you don't notice; you simply seem to learn more about it all, through osmosis. By the end of our stay I had even begun picking up my cigarette butts. But by then I was a changed man; I was Mountain Boy. Surf Boy. Nature Boy. Bronzed and happy, and I had walked bloody miles the previous day, and felt better than for years. And I'd had the Big Thoughts.

We practically had to be dragged away from the Bay of Fires. The memories swim back instantly, many weeks later; it's like finding summer sand in your shoes at Christmas. But we had another appointment, down at the world-famous Wineglass Bay, which sounded good, featuring as it did the words 'bay' and 'wine'. And 'glass'.

There should be a word - there must be a word - for that awful moment when, having spent two baking hours lugging your body and half a dozen bottles of chilled beer up and over a huge hill to one of the most secluded, beautiful beaches in the world, sweating throughout like a politician on Judgment Day, and then, having slumped dugong-like on the beach's sublime emptiness in the knowledge that you not only want and need the beer but for once actually deserve it, you find you've forgotten a bottle-opener.

Fortunately this didn't happen as I'd bought one earlier, this seeming easier at the time than making up a new word. So we slaked and swam and lolled about, facing inland, for the beach was the wrong way round that day, which is to say both the sun and wind were coming from behind, which was odd but interesting, like having the taps at your back. This is the most famous beach in Tasmania, one of the most famous beaches in Australasia, and there were only the four of us on it. Count us: four. The Freycinet Lodge looked tempting, in a comfortable four-star way, and it did provide us with a fine lunch and an excellent bottle-opener, but we were too close to nature now to go back, so that night was spent at the Bluestone Bay camp - more fine guides, bush showers all round, wine and food and kookaburras, and a good long hike the next day to the Friendly Beaches Lodge, Bluestone's parent camp, lying at the end of, yes, yet another long and beautiful beach (yawn), and another evening of fine food and conversation and gentle surf (snore).

Also, in a way, you don't really want five-star accommodation when you're here. It was good, on the last night, to stay, in Hobart, in suites at the Oakford on Elizabeth Pier, to wash clothes and shave and preen and dress up for the last evening; but I would have forgone it all just to know that it wasn't our last night. We had run out of time, just as I have, infuriatingly, run out of space. I didn't even mention the dolphins - swimming with the dolphins in the last of our four seas, the Great Southern Ocean, after a marvellous roar of a day exploring at sea with Robert Pennicott's charter-boat Albatross. I seem to have left out half a dozen fine bays, and a range of mountains or two, perhaps even an ocean. There's too much to say, too much to write, too much to do. Go. Simply go. And look me up if you make it to the Edge of the World.

Tasmania facts

Euan Ferguson flew to Tasmania via Melbourne with Singapore Airlines and Ansett Australia. Singapore Airlines has fares to Melbourne priced from £655 plus tax. A round-trip fare from Melbourne to Launceston with Ansett Australia is £122 when booked in conjunction with the international flight. For reservations call Singapore Airlines (0870 608 8886).

Austravel is a leading specialist in travel to Australia, and can organise tailor-made holidays. Return flights and a 14-night accommodation pass valid at more than 50 properties cost from £1,231. For further information call Austravel (0870 055 0206).

Bay of Fires The four-day Bay of Fires walk costs A$ 1,050 (approx £405 subject to exchange rate) per person including transport to and from Launceston, three nights' twin-share accommodation and all meals. For further information on Bay of Fires look at www.bayoffires.com.au or call 00 61 3 6331 2006.

My only problem with the cape lies in the fact that it is 'owned' - how can someone 'own' a wild place like this? - by the Van Diemens Land Company, the conglomerate which farms the area and, basically, charges you to come in and stay at its ranch house and take its Land-Rover up to the cliffs. Very nice accommodation it was, too, but I couldn't help feeling this stuff should be free. Stephanie, the pleasant PR for the area, didn't seem to understand my increasingly guttural Marxist ranting, loyally repeating the words of the corporate mantra. The argument was truly going nowhere. So I waited until no one was looking, then pushed her off the cliff. Later that night, things got seriously good again, as we saw our first Tasmanian devils. The two-hour silent wait in the hide was well worth it, when finally, shockingly, alerted by the wet snuffles, our guide flicked on a low light to reveal two of the beasts ripping the bejesus out of a dead wallaby. The devils are truly horrible animals. They look like a cross between a pig and a dog. Nearly blind, they come out only to scavenge, and they will eat every bit of anything - each other, human babies - including bone and fur, crunching down with jaws which, pound for pound, have the same force as those of the Great White. Then they will let out the most terrible, guttural, blood-turning, buttock-clenching screams, the genesis of their name. On we went, through the warm and lazy vineyards around Launceston (where we had been shocked to see - yes - a traffic light) to the most memorable two nights of the trip. The Bay of Fires Lodge, reached after a long and bumpy four-wheel ride, sits above the Tasman Sea, high on the north-east corner. I almost don't want to give away any more; it's so remote, and so beautiful, that I don't want anyone else to know the precise location. Here, anyway, for the next two days, we swam, and walked, and walked, and swam, and body-surfed, and walked some more, retreating each evening to the magnificent new timbered eco-lodge, where the guides - all young, all apparently supermodels, all intensely knowledgable about the wildlife and history but, crucially, fun with it - would prepare groaning galleys of seafood and ply us with ludicrous amounts of Spring Vale until we passed out, replete, high above the midnight surf. The eco stuff is big here, but it's not in-your-face. So there are composting toilets, and you pump through your own water for the showers, but apart from that you don't notice; you simply seem to learn more about it all, through osmosis. By the end of our stay I had even begun picking up my cigarette butts. But by then I was a changed man; I was Mountain Boy. Surf Boy. Nature Boy. Bronzed and happy, and I had walked bloody miles the previous day, and felt better than for years. And I'd had the Big Thoughts. We practically had to be dragged away from the Bay of Fires. The memories swim back instantly, many weeks later; it's like finding summer sand in your shoes at Christmas. But we had another appointment, down at the world-famous Wineglass Bay, which sounded good, featuring as it did the words 'bay' and 'wine'. And 'glass'. There should be a word - there must be a word - for that awful moment when, having spent two baking hours lugging your body and half a dozen bottles of chilled beer up and over a huge hill to one of the most secluded, beautiful beaches in the world, sweating throughout like a politician on Judgment Day, and then, having slumped dugong-like on the beach's sublime emptiness in the knowledge that you not only want and need the beer but for once actually deserve it, you find you've forgotten a bottle-opener. Fortunately this didn't happen as I'd bought one earlier, this seeming easier at the time than making up a new word. So we slaked and swam and lolled about, facing inland, for the beach was the wrong way round that day, which is to say both the sun and wind were coming from behind, which was odd but interesting, like having the taps at your back. This is the most famous beach in Tasmania, one of the most famous beaches in Australasia, and there were only the four of us on it. Count us: four. The Freycinet Lodge looked tempting, in a comfortable four-star way, and it did provide us with a fine lunch and an excellent bottle-opener, but we were too close to nature now to go back, so that night was spent at the Bluestone Bay camp - more fine guides, bush showers all round, wine and food and kookaburras, and a good long hike the next day to the Friendly Beaches Lodge, Bluestone's parent camp, lying at the end of, yes, yet another long and beautiful beach (yawn), and another evening of fine food and conversation and gentle surf (snore). Also, in a way, you don't really want five-star accommodation when you're here. It was good, on the last night, to stay, in Hobart, in suites at the Oakford on Elizabeth Pier, to wash clothes and shave and preen and dress up for the last evening; but I would have forgone it all just to know that it wasn't our last night. We had run out of time, just as I have, infuriatingly, run out of space. I didn't even mention the dolphins - swimming with the dolphins in the last of our four seas, the Great Southern Ocean, after a marvellous roar of a day exploring at sea with Robert Pennicott's charter-boat Albatross. I seem to have left out half a dozen fine bays, and a range of mountains or two, perhaps even an ocean. There's too much to say, too much to write, too much to do. Go. Simply go. And look me up if you make it to the Edge of the World. Tasmania facts Euan Ferguson flew to Tasmania via Melbourne with Singapore Airlines and Ansett Australia. fields.headline: 'In Britain I don't fit in'
fields.standfirst: Akin Ojumu  interviews the star of the controversial  Claire Dolan
fields.trailText: Akin Ojumu interviews the star of the controversial Claire Dolan
fields.body:
'I'm terrified of flying,' says Katrin Cartlidge. 'Sometimes I'm all right, but sometimes it's so hard, it's so difficult to get on to a plane, but if I didn't I'd be finished. We've already established that there's not many people who want to work with me here.'

That's not quite what was said about her domestic profile, but we both agreed she was a bit of an anomaly. She doesn't work or play with the Britpack crowd and the likes of Messrs Merchant and Ivory wouldn't know what to do with her. Apart from Mike Leigh (Naked, Career Girls), she has worked mainly for foreign directors. And that's the way she likes it. 'I think the thing is that I don't fit and I don't see how I ever will. I think my work is much more appreciated abroad than over here.' She wanders incognito around London but in New York she gets 'stopped in every café'.

Cartlidge is early for our appointment at her unfashionable Soho club. It's difficult to know what to expect from the rangy actress. On screen she can seem plain or project a fiery beauty. She has been a dishevelled nymph (Naked), a cautionary voice (Breaking the Waves), a spiky Yuppie (Career Girls). Perhaps surprisingly, she is unmannered and talkative.

In Lodge Kerrigan's Claire Dolan she plays an apparently dispassionate high-class prostitute struggling to get out of debt from her pimp. The role required nudity and includes some explicit scenes, but it is far from titillating. 'I think it's an incredible achievement to show sex as a narrative and not just as a sort of background music,' says Cartlidge. At the Cannes Film Festival, Claire Dolan caused uproar. Some people walked out, which bemused Cartlidge. 'I think a lot of people thought Katrin Cartlidge is playing a prostitute, great, let's go and see it. But I think they were disappointed.'

Cartlidge has never gone for the soft option. She bypassed drama school, instead serving her apprenticeship in youth theatre and Brookside . At school she was so bored 'I could have hit my head on the wall.' It wasn't until her twenties that her career flourished and in her early thirties Mike Leigh gave Cartlidge her first major film role in Naked . Since then she has worked steadily but hardly prodigiously, dodging overdrafts while working for mavericks such as Lars von Trier (Breaking the Waves). She has just finished filming Kathryn Bigelow's The Weight of Water , an eighteenth-century mystery about Norwegian settlers in America.

'People aren't queuing round the block for me because the sort of project I do, they're quite specialised. They're not ten-a-penny.'

But Cartlidge, 38 (she drops it into the conversation), has high hopes for the future. As I get ready to leave her in front of a roaring fire at the club, she remarks: 'I love getting older, things get richer as an actress. Sometimes I still feel fantastically immature. I felt old as a child so maybe I'm feeling the childhood I never had.'

 Claire Dolan opens 5 May

webTitle: Turning a trick with the oldest profession in film

fields.headline: Turning a trick with the oldest profession in film
fields.standfirst: Film-makers' continuing fascination with prostitution is highlighted by a new film.  Andrew Collins examines the 'fallen woman' in movies
fields.trailText: Film-makers' continuing fascination with prostitution is highlighted by a new film. Andrew Collins examines the 'fallen woman' in movies
fields.body:
Prostitute, hooker, whore, call-girl, harlot, streetwalker, woman of the night, concubine, trollop, tart - Don Simpson liked a whole range of different women. But the doomed larger-than-life producer's predilection for paid sex was endemic of Hollywood's age-old obsession with the oldest profession: the movie whore has always been with us (and I'm not talking about film critics).

Few were surprised when Simpson was revealed to be a serial employer of prostitutes in 1995's You'll Never Make Love In This Town Again by hooker Tiffany ('The dominatrix forced the girl to lean over the toilet - etc.'). You see, the busy boys that run Hollywood do not always have the time to develop meaningful relationships with women, poor things. In the Eighties, it all got out of hand, of course, and call-girls became as common at Hollywood parties as trays of nibbles (in the Simpson biography, High Concept, producer Steve Roth says: 'We were so hot and so rich and there was nothing but cocaine and hookers and millions of laughs.')

Prostitution went very much legit in 1990 with that kerbside Pygmalion, Pretty Woman . Julia Roberts, Oscar-nominated for her Sunset streetwalker Vivian Ward, was a landmark in the portrayal of the profession on screen: she was a Disney prostitute - the clearest sign yet that under Michael Eisner and Jeffrey Katzenberg the studio was finally moving out of the 1930s.

The idea of a white knight (Richard Gere) 'rescuing' a fallen woman may not have been new, but the film's slick, smart, pop-soundtracked presentation was. It was very good box office but not everyone approved. That year, Meryl Streep delivered an inflammatory keynote speech at the Screen Actors Guild's first-ever women's conference. The success of Pretty Woman, she said, seemed to indicate that 'the chief occupation of women on earth was hooking. And I don't mean rugs'.

There's little of the Disney prostitute about Katrin Cartlidge, the lead in Claire Dolan , the assured new film from young American director Lodge Kerrigan. Dolan's business is tracked by Kerrigan with a steely gaze, and a deal of wit, and the woman herself has no choice but to be her own white knight

Back in the Thirties, when prostitution was unmentionable by name, the movies were full of ladies of ill-repute, from the literary - Joan Crawford as Somerset Maugham's Sadie Thompson in Rain; Greta Garbo as the eponymous ex-whore on a barge in Anna Christie and Clara Bow as the half-breed Indian in Call Her Savage . In 1932, Josef von Sternberg's Shanghai Express made Marlene Dietrich a legend, playing Shanghai Lily, 'the White Flower of the Chinese Coast', a woman who, in Alexander Walker's book Sex In The Movies, is described as having a 'soiled soul' (even critics resort to euphemisms).

Screen prostitutes quickly fell into two types: those who were trying to get out of the game (cue: helping hand from benevolent Richard Gere figure), or those who were forced into it by circumstance, such as Vivien Leigh's respectable Myra Lester in the 1940 World War II romance Waterloo Bridge . A ballet dancer fired for taking time off to say goodbye to her conscripted lover, Leigh turns to prostitution to make ends meet - the story was filmed again in 1956 as Gaby with Leslie Caron, and the blueprint later served Paris, Texas, with its moving climax in which Harry Dean Stanton pays to see his estranged wife Nastassja Kinski.

It took an arthouse comedy from Greece to really turn the screen prostitute stereotype on its head. In 1960, Never On Sunday proved an unlikely hit in America; Melina Mercouri plays Ilya, the whore who's proud of her work and who keeps Sundays free for going to the theatre (This sense of empowerment was echoed in Belle De Jour by Catherine Deneuve, who only worked afternoons). European cinema was, naturally, way ahead of Hollywood. Sophia Loren couldn't stop playing prostitutes, whether in Lady L , Marriage Italian Style , Boccaccio 70 , Man Of La Mancha or Yesterday, Today And Tomorrow (Vittorio de Sica's trilogy, of which the third segment concerns a Roman prostitute with whom a priest has fallen in love). Mind you, Shirley MacLaine was also prolific in this area, playing a floozy in Some Came Running in 1958 and a Paris streetwalker (pictured) in Irma La Douce (with Jack Lemmon as her saviour).

At the beginning of the Sixties, MGM were still worried that Elizabeth Taylor's loose woman Gloria Wandrous in Butterfield 8 was showing too much cleavage (director Daniel Mann sent back a memo saying, 'She's a hooker, for Christ's sake, not a Mother Superior'), but by the end of the decade, things loosened up, and in 1969, the male prostitute arrived, in the form of Midnight Cowboy and John Voigt's Texan stud Joe Buck. The lingering censoriousness of the swinging decade can be seen in the tagline for 1962's Walk On The Wild Side, about a New Orleans brothel: 'A side of life you never expected to see on the screen!'

In the Seventies and Eighties, prostitutes became icons, such as Jodie Foster's Iris in Taxi Driver, Jane Fonda's Bree Daniels in Klute and Teresa Russell's China Blue in Crimes Of Passion. Taxi Driver paved the way for further teen prostitutes, such as George C. Scott's daughter in Paul Schrader's Hardcore, and Kate Hardie in Mona Lisa, with Brooke Shields's decorous 12-year-old Violet in Pretty Baby another can of worms altogether.

In the Nineties, post- Pretty Woman , prostitutes could even be offbeat heroines, such as Quentin Tarantino's fantasy female Alabama (Patricia Arquette) in True Romance, who, after just three days on the job, brazenly aspires to become a high-class call-girl ('They drive Porsches, live in condos, have stockbrokers, carry beepers, you know like Nancy Allen in Dressed To Kill ').

In Leaving Las Vegas , Sera, played by Elizabeth Shue, is Nicolas Cage's angel, thus confirming that the 'tart with a heart' stereotype is an enduring one. This month's American Psycho also proves that the prostitute as serial-killer fodder is alive and well, if not for long, and the latest Saturday Night Live spin-off Deuce Bigalow, Male Gigolo at least reminds us that there is humour to be had in this area, albeit limited to Jamie Lee Curtis's wig in Trading Places, Michael Palin's fallen women in The Missionary, and Joan Sims's travelling brothel, 'Les Oiseaux des Paradis' in Carry On Dick .

And what of Burt Reynolds and Dolly Parton in The Best Little Whorehouse In Texas ? Well, Don Simpson probably found it 'a million laughs'.

fields.headline: Musical gamble
fields.standfirst: The Coens brothers are set to revive an ailing genre
fields.trailText: Screenwriter William Goldman famously said that in Hollywood 'nobody knows anything'. He was almost right. However, a few Tinseltown truths are indisputable. For instance, all Kevin Costner films last three hours (or at least they seem to), real-life couples shouldn't act opposite each other and the musical is dead.
fields.body:
Screenwriter William Goldman famously said that in Hollywood 'nobody knows anything'. He was almost right. However, a few Tinseltown truths are indisputable. For instance, all Kevin Costner films last three hours (or at least they seem to), real-life couples shouldn't act opposite each other and the musical is dead.

On the last point Hollywood still makes the occasional all-singing, all-dancing movie but really their heart isn't in it. A few years ago James L. Brooks ( Terms of Endearment, As Good as it Gets ) produced a lengthy romantic comedy called 'I'll do anything' about a Hollywood actor, played Nick Nolte at the height of his A-list fame. It was a throwback to the Technicolor golden age of musicals. Predictably, preview audiences loathed the Prince-penned songs and they were removed. Ironically, the film still flopped.

Now, two very different movies in competition at next month's Cannes Film Festival could breathe life into the tuneful films. The quixotic Coens Brothers have made O Brother, Where Art Thou, a depression-era musical set in the Deep South and based, allegedly on Homer's Odyssey. The Coens, fond of irreverent homage, seem an unlikely pair to revive a tired genre, but they've done it before and their period films: Barton Fink, The Hudsucker Proxy and Miller's Crossing and have endless fun with Hollywood traditions.

George Clooney, who has an eye for a good script these days, heads a trio of escaped convicts searching for a fortune. His character is called Ulysses Everett McGill. As you would expect there is an array of idiosyncratic southern folk and Coens' regulars such as Holly Hunter and John Goodman also appear. Expect a bevy of references and visual sleight-of-hand, which should keep movie buffs buzzing as they strive to find hidden meanings.

If anyone can make the musical relevant it will be the Coens, or perhaps Lars von Trier's latest effort. The original Dogma 95 back-to-basics adherent has made a kaleidoscopic musical called Dancer in the Dark about a combative factory worker. It has an eclectic cast: Bjork, Catherine Denueve and Peter Stormare and is inspired by von Trier's love of American movies. Early indicators suggest both films have a chance of winning the Palme d'Or. That would be something to make a song and dance about.

webTitle: The reinvention of former soap star Tori Spelling

fields.headline: The reinvention of former soap star Tori Spelling
fields.trailText: When Hilary Swank picked up the Best Actress Oscar recently she struck a blow for former soap stars everywhere. The Boys Don't Cry star was previously best known for her recurring role in the forever young saga Beverly Hills, 90210. Now her erstwhile cast mate Tori Spelling is striving to reinvent herself as a credible thespian.

It's no easy task. A flick through her colourful magazine profiles reveals that Spelling has had as many dye jobs as Dame Edna Everage. Apart from her 10-year stint in America's most mocked show, during the off-season she starred in a string of banal TV movies with titles such as Mother, may I sleep with Murder and Co-ed Call Girl . She was a fixture on the 'Worst Dressed' list and her acting ability became a standard chat show joke.

She epitomised the spoilt Valley Girl on and off screen, but now the daughter of TV mogul Aaron Spelling wants to be taken seriously. No surprise there, but against all odds Spelling is shaping up as a fine indie actress. In her breakthrough movie, the offbeat family drama The House of Yes (1997), she held her own as a much put-upon fiancée in an ensemble cast led by indie queen Parker Posey.

Now in Trick, a post-Aids gay comedy about a couple of young men desperate to find a place for a one-night stand, Spelling steals every scene as the irrepressible best friend of one of the would-be lovers. Her character is an inept aspiring actress and she even pulls off a hilarious song and dance routine. It's a brave step for the actress in light of her own career. But Spelling has always been up for a bit of ironic typecasting.

In Scream, Neve Campbell quipped that her life was worthy of a clichéd TV movie biopic starring Tori Spelling. So, in Scream II, Spelling made a guest appearance as herself. It was, she claimed, the natural thing to do especially after she had actually failed an audition for the lead in Scream. 'When it came down to Scream II, and they gave me an offer to do that, I thought: "Oh, if people did respond to it negatively, I'm getting the last laugh inevitably because I'm going to be in the movie".' So began the transformation from a pop culture joke into a cult figure.

Beverly Hills, 90210 was finally pulled off the air in January, but Spelling is unlikely to rue the end of her 10-year stint on the programme. Alongside her famous father, it's defined her public image. She denies her career is due to her father's clout, but his status is an issue. When The House of Yes met financing problems in pre-production, she approached her father's company, Spelling Films, to help. Their involvement was downplayed and 'A Spelling Films Production' was moved from the opening credits to the end credits.

These days she barely needs his help. After the Sundance Film Festival acclaim for Trick, she confessed an unlikely source of inspiration. 'I watch all my old TV movies. That gives me another inspiration to do good work.' Well, someone has to watch them and their effect is to be applauded.

Five things you should know about Tori Spelling

1 She began acting when she was five.

2 Her favourite films are Splendour in the Grass, Breakfast at Tiffany's and Sixteen Candles .

3 She lives alone with her dog Audrey.

4 Of her hair, she says: 'You start off dark and then you go blonde and blonder and blonder, it's like a sickness. So I got to platinum and then I just got really bored with it and I wanted to go darker.

5 She received the Youth Leadership Award from the Washington DC Holocaust Memorial Museum for her support of a variety of charities.

webTitle: Lothar finds New York is no Hollywood

fields.headline: Lothar finds New York is no Hollywood
fields.trailText: High in the Trump Tower at 721 Fifth Avenue lives an angry German. Lothar Matthäus complains that apartments in New York are tiny, the kitchens even smaller, and the streets clogged with yellow taxis.
fields.body:
High in the Trump Tower at 721 Fifth Avenue lives an angry German. Lothar Matthäus complains that apartments in New York are tiny, the kitchens even smaller, and the streets clogged with yellow taxis. One of the few things he has in common with other New Yorkers is that he speaks almost no English.

Only six weeks since moving here to play for the New York/New Jersey MetroStars, he seems to think he made a mistake. Matthäus is, as they say in America, in a bad place, living a bizarre inversion of the American Dream: arrive a millionaire, work very little and end up with nothing. It all adds up to terrible news for Germany.

Just before he left Bayern Munich, I asked Matthäus how he would cope in a team of not very good players. Last season the MetroStars ran up the worst record in Major League soccer history, winning seven, losing 25 and earning the moniker of 'the worst team in the world'. Matthäus replied that although they might not be the most gifted footballers, as long as they worked hard, that was OK.

Last week I went to watch them play the Kansas City Wizards. The first eight cab drivers I asked to take me refused, explaining, in a sort of English, that they had never heard of Giants Stadium. Finally I found an Indian who had also never heard of it but was willing to look. I arrived to find Matthäus charging around the pitch acting, as they say in New York, like a crazy. Every time a team-mate touched the ball, he waved his arms and screamed.

When the MetroStars scored, his team-mates understandably cheered, and on the big screen a pair of Thirties comedians danced around a table, but Matthäus simply grew angrier.

Things got worse when the Wizards, featuring the virtually moribund 37-year-old Scotsman Mo Johnston, scored twice. Matthäus, as they say here, freaked. At one point he threw his captain's armband at the linesman, a tough-looking individual named Chip Reed, who simply threw the thing back.

A few minutes later Matthäus ran over to the touchline to eyeball Reed, but Reed just eyeballed him back. Matthäus spent most of the rest of the match wandering around the pitch muttering to himself like a bum in the subway.

When the game ended with the score still 1-2, he kicked the ball away, chucked his shirt at the 20 or so youths behind one goal who constitute the MetroStars' self-conscious hard core, and stalked off.

After the game, he explained that his tantrum had been a ploy to motivate his team-mates. Their coach, Octavio Zambrano, showed the German superstar who was boss: 'If he genuinely believed that he was trying to wake up the guys, then what can I say? I can't punish him for that.' The team's keeper, Mike Ammann, veteran of English soccer, said he saw Matthäus's point: if certain guys in the team were too dumb to listen, what could you do?

However, if things continue like this Matthäus will soon be as dumb as his team-mates. That could be embarrassing. In June he is due to play libero for Germany in the European Championship, arguably the toughest football tournament in the world. The MetroStars are ruining his game.

Matthäus is 39 now, and for years, playing for Bayern Munich and Germany, he has barely touched the ball or tackled anyone. His role is chiefly administrative. But it remains crucial. He makes German football tick.

Better than any other team, Germany can alternate the pace of the game. If they go a goal down they double the pace, forcing the other team into errors, and committing fouls to ruin their opponents' concentration.

Conversely, if they go a goal up, they take all pace out of the game: whenever they win a free-kick they wait 30 seconds before taking it, and if their riled opponents then commit fouls, the Germans dive to win more free-kicks, or, ideally, get someone sent off.

Matthäus initiates these changes of pace, grabbing the ball when the opposition wants to take a corner or a free-kick, determining the tempo like an orchestra conductor.

But playing no-good football with big-time losers dulls your sense of the game. Watching Matthäus at the MetroStars, I was reminded of seeing Ruud Gullit play for the fifth team of an Amsterdam amateur club in January.

Gullit, only 37 years old, looked as if he had forgotten how to play football. At half-time, his side were 5-0 down. Matthäus seems to be descending almost as fast. New York is no place for this hick from the German sticks who likes being a hick. As he gazes down at Central Park from his four-room apartment, he might think of a song for guitar that another immigrant to this city wrote 25 years ago:

Open the gate,

I want to return,

Here I don't have

What I had there.

Open the gate,

I want to return,

New York is making me cry.

The words, originally written in Portuguese during his spell at the Cosmos, are by Pele.

fields.headline: United deny Veron move
fields.trailText: Alex Ferguson has denied reports from Italy that Manchester United have made a bid for Lazio's Juan Sebastian Veron - and he also says United are not seeking another striker after the collapse of the deal for Ruud van Nistelrooy.
fields.body:
Alex Ferguson has denied reports from Italy that Manchester United have made a bid for Lazio's Juan Sebastian Veron - and he also says United are not seeking another striker after the collapse of the deal for Ruud van Nistelrooy.

According to reports from Rome, both United and Real Madrid have faxed official bids of about £9 million for Veron, the Argentine who rates among the world's top midfield players. Veron said he wanted a move after Lazio crashed out of the Champions League in the quarter-finals.

Asked if there had been contact, Ferguson said, 'No.' He added that the club were no longer looking for a striker and indicated that United might make another bid for Van Nistelrooy, the PSV Eindhoven goal-scorer whose move was called off because of knee trouble. The Dutchman will be out of football for at least eight months.

'The need for a striker is no longer so urgent but we would consider going back for him in six months,' said Ferguson.

There was recognition for United's top midfield player, Roy Keane, yesterday when he was named Footballer of the Year. He won the award comfortably from Kevin Phillips and Harry Kewell.

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Racist crowd violence in Italy, Baggio in not coming to London shocker, plus all the tales from the tabloids.
fields.body:
Italian strike threat as violence increases

James Richardson, Channel 4's Football Italia presenter, has joined the criticism of Serie A after racist crowd violence prompted Italy's top players to threaten strike action.

'There hasn't been the concerted effort that there has been in England to combat the problem,' says Richardson. 'For the police it is a culture of not getting involved.' The players' union president Sergio Campana threatened action earlier this month after Torino midfielder Fabio Pecchia was attacked by his own fans with a concrete block: 'Violent assaults on players by fans have become an alarming norm,' said Campana.

'Within a fortnight, we want some serious answers, otherwise we'll take suitable action.' But, according to Richardson, the problem is growing unchecked by politicians - and by the press. 'It's not helped by the fact that the Italian press, in a way, are very docile. Italy has three sporting newspapers, which are ultimately dependent on clubs and are very careful not to upset them.'

Similar strike action is taking place in Argentina this weekend.

Lapping it up: Del Piero heads the fat cats

Although the average English footballers' salary is over £400,000 a year, the biggest of the big money remains abroad. A new survey published in France Football magazine this week revealed Juventus's Alessandro Del Piero to be the world's best paid player - with David Beckham and Alan Shearer the only English-based players to make it into the top ten.

Del Piero nets £5.8m a year in salary, bonuses and advertising revenue - overtaking Ronaldo, last year's top earner, on £4.8m. His wages at Juventus alone are £2.98m a year - or £57,000 a week. Inter's Christian Vieri is third on £3.4m - with Beckham (£3.2m), Gabriel Batistuta (£3.1m) and Shearer (£3.05m) next in the list. Young Nicolas Anelka, incidentally, comes a deserving seventh. (£2.9m)

Baggio: London move off

Roberto Baggio has confirmed his plans to leave Inter in the summer - but now says he wants to stay in Serie A. Baggio had been expected to seek a move to London after a miserable season at Inter, where he has played in fewer than half the games, often as a late substitute. 'There haven't been many moments of joy for me this season,' Baggio said last week. 'If Inter had wanted to renew my contract, they would have done so already. In a month's time, I'll be a free agent and I'll have time to pick the club I want to play for. But my first choice will be a team in Serie A.'

Liberian MPs in World Cup get-together

Liberian President Charles Taylor has ordered his entire cabinet to attend today's World Cup qualifier against Chad, or be sacked. 'Any government minister who is not at the field that day will be in trouble,' Taylor said at a lunch given at his Executive Mansion last week. He refused to say, when pushed,what would happen to ministers who failed to turn up, but the threat was serious. Last May, Taylor dismissed 11 cabinet ministers for not attending a prayer meeting.

Other World Cup qualifier highlights this week: All Kenyan national team players and staff have been sacked after the side lost in disgrace to Malawi; Eritrea hosted Nigeria on a bumpy school pitch after realising their own stadium was closed for renovation; and the Ugandan team, the Cranes, crashed out in Guinea having been stranded for a night after their cheque, payable to Kenyan Airlines, bounced. More next week.

Keeper caught short in Norway

Two weeks after cricketer Matthew Brimson exposed himself in Wisden 2000, Norwegian goalkeeper Olav Kre Fiske has gone one better. The incident came after Surnadal's cup-tie against rivals Sunndal went into extra time. Fiske, who was seen consuming several pints of water before the game, had grown increasingly uncomfortable during the tie, and, in the second half of extra time, couldn't contain himself any longer. As the game kicked off, Fiske dashed to the touchline to urinate. The referee didn't notice - but opposition striker Tor Oddvar Torve did. Midstream, Fiske could only watch in horror as Torve lobbed the ball 40 yards into the net. The match finished 1-0 - Surnadal plan to appeal.

SPURS REV UP £10m REV CHASE George Graham has made a fresh £10m move for Ukrainian superstar Sergei Rebrov. Spurs officials flew to Kiev last night to offer a £25,000-a-week deal.

fields.headline: Explain...
fields.trailText: Simon Burnton Tomorrow, the Doncaster Belles go into their twelfth Women's FA Cup final since 1983. Theirs is a fairly astonishing success story. Especially if you consider the fact that their town is also home to a men's team which, despite being created fully 90 years earlier, has won nothing of note since the Fourth Division in 1969, the year Doncaster Belles were born.
fields.body:
Tomorrow, Doncaster go into their twelfth Women's FA Cup final since 1983. Even if their fortunes have waned somewhat since their late Eighties and early Nineties heyday (their last major honour was won in 1994), theirs is still a fairly astonishing success story. Especially if you consider the fact that their town is also home to a men's team which, despite being created fully 90 years earlier, has won nothing of note since the Fourth Division in 1969, the year Doncaster Belles were born.

For this is truly a town where women are on top. According to their mayor, Margaret Robinson (pictured), 'Most of our women are successful at everything they try to do, because they put 100 per cent effort into it... I don't really know a lot about football, but I know that the girls are a credit to Doncaster.'

Rosie Winterton, MP for Doncaster Central, is similarly proud. 'When I was growing up in Doncaster I remember having the best women's team in the country,' she says. 'Now most areas have women's football teams and the talent is more spread.' webTitle: The poor still get the blame

fields.headline: The poor still get the blame
fields.trailText: Two clubs, two strikes, two different excuses and two very different results. How Barcelona and the Accies were treated after refusing to play.
fields.body:
Two clubs, two strikes, two different excuses and two very different results. When Scottish minnows Hamilton Academical and Spanish giants Barcelona went on strike one club was docked 15 points and, effectively, relegated; the other got off Scot-free. And, sadly, in these days when the rich have inherited the earth, there are no prizes for guessing which club received which punishment.

Hamilton's players refused to turn out against Stenhousemuir due to a wage dispute. Now, you would have thought that in the Twenty-first century it was a democratic right to withdraw your labour without penalty when in dispute: even New Labour have changed the draconian law that allowed bosses to sack the entire workforce for going on strike.

Given that the team refused to play because the club had failed to pay their wages you could also have been forgiven for thinking that the Scottish League bosses would have had some sympathy for their plight. Not a bit of it. They docked the Accies 15 points and condemned them to the bottom division.

Football bosses have never been known for their liberal attitudes towards players, for many years treating them more as slaves than free human beings. Footballers, like other workers, had to fight every inch of the way to win their democratic rights, having to wait until a recent ruling from the European Court for freedom of contract.

And while Hamilton Academical fans are rightly furious with the League administrators, they are also totally disillusioned with the club owners, who face an Inland Revenue inquiry for alleged tax irregularities. In order to help win support for the club the fans ran a candidate in the recent Hamilton by-election and won more votes than the Liberal Democrat candidate.

So they have plenty of support, but for all their loyalty the club no longer have a ground of their own and now face life in the Third Division, where they will almost certainly have to go part time. As recently as 13 years ago they were in the Scottish Premier League.

Hamilton have appealed and had their 15 points temporarily restored, but the fans will have little faith in the SFA, who make the English FA look positively progressive. The SFA appear to have one key role: not to upset Celtic or Rangers.

Smaller clubs are treated with contempt. If you thought that the Accies' punishment was an isolated case of a small club being treated badly you would be wrong. Falkirk fans whose team are in a promotion winning position won't see them play in the Premier League next season because the SFA top brass have decreed that they don't have a big enough ground.

This is despite the fact that they have offered to play their home games at the home of Scottish rugby, Murrayfield, a ground that holds as many spectators as either Celtic Park or Ibrox. Even the negotiating skills of their most famous director, Campbell Christie, the former general secretary of the Scottish TUC, haven't been enough to convince the SFA to change their mind.

Falkirk may have their problems but at least they aren't in liquidation like Airdrie or up for sale like Clydebank. But the team who were refused admission to the Scottish League this year, Huntly, are apparently set to buy Clydebank and so gain a league place through the back door, making a mockery of the whole admissions process. The very small clubs are not the only ones who have a gripe. Aberdeen have been incensed at the decision to give more tickets to Rangers fans than their own for the Scottish Cup final.

Given their obvious favouritism towards the biggest clubs one can't help wondering what the SFA would do if they were in charge of Spanish football and had to take a decision on Barcelona's failure to turn up for the second leg of the semi-final of the Copa del Rey, their equivalent of the FA Cup.

Barcelona claimed that they could not fulfil the fixture because half their players were away on international duty. They were forced to apologise to the King because the cup is named after him but not to the Spanish FA. Like Rangers, Celtic and Manchester United, Barcelona seem to be a law unto themselves.

The fact that they bought so many foreign players, knowing they would have to release them for internationals, doesn't seem to bother Barca. They don't mind that the Spanish FA kicked them out as they were 3-0 down to Atletico Madrid and, like Manchester United, aren't interested in little domestic competitions. The fact that they have been banned from next year's Spanish cup will allow them to concentrate on the Champions League.

Effectively the Barcelona players did what the Hamilton Academical players did: refused to play a game. The difference is that the Accies players had a very good reason for their protest, and Barca's did not.

webTitle: Travellers beware, it's up to you to avoid the terrorist

fields.headline: Travellers beware, it's up to you to avoid the terrorist
fields.trailText: Travel experts are not expecting the kidnapping of 21 people, including ten tourists, from a diving resort off the Malaysian coast to deter travellers from wanting to visit the region.
fields.body:
Travel experts are not expecting the kidnapping of 21 people, including ten tourists, from a diving resort off the Malaysian coast to deter travellers from wanting to visit the region.

Jennifer Cox of Lonely Planet guides, said Malaysia was a popular stop for independent travellers, but there had already been heightened awareness of tension in the region which had led to a fall in visitor numbers. 'People are aware there are problems in Malaysia and Indonesia, but the chances are they will probably be fine,' she said.

Independent travellers were taking more time to find out about their destinations now than a few years ago, she added.

Cox said increased access to the Internet was helping travellers to research their destinations as they planned trips.

Travellers had to take responsibility for finding information about the political situation in any country before visiting and making their own decision, she said, adding that there was also a responsibility amongst travel and tourism organisations to provide information.'Malaysia is a perennial and beautiful destination,' Cox said, predicting that many travellers would continue to visit, despite the kidnapping.

The captives, among them tourists from France, Germany and the US, were kidnapped from a resort on Malaysia's Sipadan island, off the coast of Sabah, last Sunday by armed men. Sabah, on the tip of the island of Borneo, which includes Brunei and part of Indonesia, and is popular with divers and turtle watchers.

It is believed the kidnappers are from the Muslim fundamentalist group Abu Sayyah, who are using the attack on tourists to raise their international profile. Reports have suggested that the captives have been taken to the Philippines. Following the attack the Malaysian Government said that security had been stepped up in the area.

Andy Telford, managing director of UK diving specialist Regal Holidays, has taken tourists to Sipadan in the past. He said it had been a dream destination, and the volume of visitors was kept low, due to worries about the environmental impact. The attack on tourists had 'come out of the blue', he said. 'We have never had a problem there.'

Mr Telford said he did not think tourism to the rest of Malaysia or Indonesia would be affected by the attack. 'These incidents happen all around the world. There are so many different factions out there. People continue to go to Yemen even though there was that dreadful incident there.'

Other tour operators including British Airways Holidays and Kuoni, who run holidays to parts of Malaysia, said they did not feel travellers would be put off travel to the country.

Last week callers to the Tourism Malaysia office in London who asked about safety of travel in the country were being advised that 'this is probably a one-off incident and the mainland is safe'.

The Foreign Office updated its travel advice on Thursday to add details about the kidnapping. The Foreign Office also warns of 'increased threats to British interests from global terrorism' in Malaysia.

webTitle: Netbuster still a hit in players' bar

fields.headline: Netbuster still a hit in players' bar
fields.standfirst: As Shrewsbury face loss of League status and their Gay Meadow home, record scorer Arthur Rowley remembers the glory days
fields.trailText: As Shrewsbury face loss of League status and their Gay Meadow home, record scorer Arthur Rowley remembers the glory days.
fields.body:
With a record of 434 League goals, 27 hat-tricks and 52 penalties, it's little wonder that G. Arthur Rowley was known as 'The Netbuster'.

For 20 seasons, the 'King of Goals' banged the heavy, old-fashioned, leather ball into the net from every angle, often from more than 20 yards. In 1961, 18,917 turned up at Gay Meadow to watch him equal Dixie Dean's record of 379 League goals with a first-half penalty against Walsall.

Three days later, at Valley Parade, the record was his. Asked at the time how he felt, he replied: 'Has it helped my club?' Asked last week, he replied: 'The team came in front of my record. Obviously if I scored goals it meant the team were doing well. But the team were always more important.' Two seasons later, he broke Jimmy McGrory's British record of 410 with a goal against Millwall.

His epic scoring feats are the stuff of comic books, but Rowley - thick-set with huge hands and wonky knees and a carefully sculpted hairstyle that hasn't changed for half a century - would not fit comfortably alongside flamboyant characters such as Roy of the Rovers, Jimmy of the City and Bobby of the Blues. Arthur of the Town belongs more to Arnold Bennett than Tiger or Scorcher and Score.

He could have scored a lot more, of course, if it hadn't been for the War. 'I'd work in the factory all Friday night and the Wolves would ring up on Saturday morning and ask if I would come along and play. I was only 15,16. It was when the old Major [Frank Buckley] was there. You used to have to march to attention underneath the stand. He thought he was still in the army.'

Rowley joined the Duke of Cornwall's Light Infantry, played alongside Wilf Mannion and Alf Ramsey in a team that beat an Arab representative side 9-1 in Haifa, then captained the Army Cup winning side. On his return, in 1947, he went to West Brom. 'I was just out of the army, just had my tonsils out and the chairman said, "You're not doing very well." That was that.'

Then to Fulham, for whom he scored 19 in a 22-match run - to give them the Second Division championship and promotion to the First Division for the first time in their history. He was transferred to Leicester City for £14,000. 'I got nothing,' says Rowley. 'You'd get more than 10 per cent now.'

Leicester proved to be his golden period - 251 goals in 303 games - and twice they won promotion to the First Division. Despite this success, he was never selected for England. 'I played for the wrong club,' says Rowley. 'The England team were chosen by the club directors from different clubs so it helped if you were at the right club. But when I was at Leicester I played for the Football League XI which was better than the England team.'

Does it bother him? 'You think about these things, but you were getting paid to play for your club and that's what you did. If I had been chosen for England it would have been a great honour. But it didn't happen.' Who set up the goals for him at Leicester? 'I set 'em up myself, although Mal Griffiths was a great crosser of the ball.'

Despite his scoring record, it became obvious that 'Leicester didn't want me. So I got the club secretary to ring up Shrewsbury to see if it was worth applying and came up for an interview. I knew the area. I was in the army at Shrewsbury and I can still see the huts from where I live now'.

He was appointed player-manager. He stayed for 10 years - four as inside-left, three as centre-half, three as manager - and took the Town to the brink of Division Two. Then he made 'the worst mistake I ever made' by going to manage Sheffield United.

'I happened to pick the wrong club,' he says. 'Some one offers you a better job and you try and take it. I didn't enjoy my time there. The team I left got promotion the following year.' He briefly managed Southend but, after relegation, he left under a cloud.

Since then, he has stayed in Shropshire and supported The Town. 'They've named the players' bar after me and I appreciate that because it shows they appreciate what I've done.' In a supporters' poll for Shrewsbury's player of the century, Rowley won by a country mile.

These are dark days for The Town, who were founded in 1886 and elected to the Third Division (North) in 1950 - but are now perilously close to dropping out of the League.

The Seventies and Eighties were good but the Nineties less good,' says Freddie Fry, Shrewsbury's president.

Fry, who looks like Mr Rumbold merged with Dick Emery, was on the Shrewsbury board for 30 years from 1965 and has been president ever since. 'The big change is that we were in the old Second Division and playing Newcastle, West Ham, Sunderland, Leeds and Man City. And at that time we shared the gate money so an away game at Roker Park, say, might bring in four times as much as a home game.'

This change, along with the injection of Sky money and the Bosman ruling, has rid football of any redistributive element. The rich get richer; the poor get poorer.

'It's very difficult to balance the books and persuade players to stay because they can always do better somewhere else. There are too many sheep around here and they don't watch football,' says Fry.

The proliferation of sheep has meant the directors have had to dip into their pockets. 'I don't agree with people having to put money into a football club. It should stand on its own two feet. Every club I managed I always left in the black,' says Rowley.

Despite the board subsidising the club, the debts persist and even if they maintain their League status Gay Meadow will have to be sold.

'I'll be sorry to see it go because I more or less built it while I was here with the proceeds from transferring players and cup runs,' says Rowley.

'We will all be very sad,' says Fry. 'The new ground will be called The Meadow. We will drop the word "Gay" and I think you can see why,'

It will be a shame. Walking over the English Bridge and seeing Gay Meadow nestling between the Severn and the Abbey is to go back in time. To a time when G. Arthur Rowley was scoring 30 goals every season.

webTitle: Making a big splash in a sea of mediocrity

fields.headline: Making a big splash in a sea of mediocrity
fields.trailText: There will undoubtedly be another summer spending spree as Liverpool, Leeds and Arsenal especially, and possibly Chelsea, Aston Villa and Newcastle, expect themselves to bridge the gap. When all the cheques are signed though, don't bank on it.
fields.body: IT HAS COME to something when all that's left to get excited about in this Premiership season is a relegation contest between Bradford City and Wimbledon. Then again, perhaps it is only fitting that a celebration of mediocrity should attract so much attention at the fag end of such an anti-climactic campaign. Last weekend Manchester United confirmed a sixth Championship in eight seasons and proceeded to play out an exhibition match on Easter Monday against a Chelsea side who, like Leeds, had shot their bolt a month before the end of the season. Arsenal, meanwhile, have come good too late, in the league at least. At the top, that leaves Liverpool, who have admittedly come a long way under the astute Gérard Houllier. Only for him, among the managers of the bigger clubs chasing United, has big spending led to anything other than standing still, although it remains a mark of Anfield's decline amid Old Trafford's surge that they are delighted with a position still the length of the East Lancs Road behind. Both at home and abroad, this has been a season of fixture farce that the game's governing bodies, from the FA through Uefa to Fifa, need to address if the golden goose growing fat is not to become foie gras. The standardised calendar that has been mooted has surely become a matter of urgency. The Champions League ground on, too rich for even cash-conscious United's tastes. Here, the once-treasured FA Cup has been a shamefully fragmented afterthought even without the diverting controversy of United's withdrawal, so emasculated was it by wild cards and long gaps between rounds. If the FA are to reassert themselves as guardians of the game, they should start with their own competition. Alongside, the Premiership developed into a procession akin to Formula One - superficially glamorous but of muddy reality. It has served to prove that success at home and in Europe are increasingly incompatible, particularly on the Thursday-Sunday treadmill that the once-respected, now-marginalised Uefa Cup produces. Europe has yielded another unwanted repercussion for home consumption. Fans may still covet the title of their own country but it has seemed, in the Premiership at least, that managers settled too early for the goal of a top-three finish that admits them to the Champions League and appeases their accountants. Too often we heard the cop-out clause of aiming for that - rather than the title itself - from at least five managers. It may well have trickled down to players, enabling them to limit their horizons. Sir Alex Ferguson says this is United's best side in his 14 years in charge but he must have had trouble reaching that conclusion given the limpness of the domestic challenge. Indeed, after the title-clinching victory, the vanquished manager, Southampton's Glenn Hoddle, expressed his fears that England could turn into Scotland where Rangers dominate so dully. This is not to be xenophobic but practical. If fans are to be kept onside, they want to see players whom they believe will value the shirt. Having spent a season defending his expensive policies, Gianluca Vialli now seems ready to re-evaluate given the way some of his mercenaries and tourists have performed of late. This season, Chelsea were the first to field an all-overseas XI, some of whom have picked and chosen which domestic games they sit out. Wenger himself may have noted that his side have slipped this season as more imports seek to gel and he has discarded English players. It holds true at the other end of the table, too, even if the spread of points difference these days bears testimony to bigger-than-ever gaps in quality. At Bradford, Paul Jewell has tried a few imports but they have not integrated. The vital victory at Sunderland last Sunday was achieved with some old home fires burning. At Wimbledon, meanwhile, Egil Olsen has damagingly introduced more Norwegians - and the fact that this country is such a haven for anonymous Scandinavians when they are in short supply in Italy and Spain says much about our pretensions - at the expense of an English cadre that has served the club so well. He is paying the penalty. It is ironic. It is of course about money and for all our nostalgia at times, always has been. It is just that it wasn't always all about money. It seems that this season more than ever an even bigger chunk of the concept of competition has been eroded. Perhaps the prattle of wounded knee that has become the inflated Ruud Van Nistelrooy transfer saga is some symbolic warning to a game obsessed with huge sums but in danger of breaking down through overplaying. There will undoubtedly be another summer spending spree as Liverpool, Leeds and Arsenal especially, and possibly Chelsea, Aston Villa and Newcastle, expect themselves to bridge the gap. webTitle: General Black marches into modern battlefield

fields.headline: General Black marches into modern battlefield
fields.standfirst: Telegraph owner Hollinger is cutting down on print as it catches the Internet bug, Emily Bell reports
fields.trailText: There was not much in the battle plans of Napoleon, or the speeches of Winston Churchill, which could help prepare one for the Internet. So Canadian-born newspaper proprietor and Daily Telegraph owner Conrad Black will find himself oddly bereft of military historical precedent for his most recent strategic move.
fields.body:
There was not much in the battle plans of Napoleon, or the speeches of Winston Churchill, which could help prepare one for the Internet. So Canadian-born newspaper proprietor and Daily Telegraph owner Conrad Black will find himself oddly bereft of military historical precedent for his most recent strategic move.

Black surprised the media industry last week by announcing a major restructuring in Hollinger, his Canadian-based newspaper firm. Black, who controls the world's third largest newspaper group, after Gannett and Rupert Murdoch's News Corp, says Hollinger will sell its 'community' - local - newspapers in Canada and the US and pursue a merger, probably with an electronically-enabled partner. In a typically careful statement, Black says: 'In order to unlock shareholder value, Hollinger International Inc. will make most of its operating assets available in one way or another to facilitate the current trend to larger, consolidated, multi-media entities.'

Not for Black the rhetoric of the over-enthusiastic nerd; his embracing of the Internet age seems to be more a giving in to the irritating 'modern ways' of the newspaper business than fully embracing electronic publishing.

Hollinger vice-chairman and Telegraph chief executive Dan Colson insists the group's decision is a natural progression.

'What we absolutely decided not to do a couple of years ago was try and be all things to all men. Most of the big major publishing companies have overspent on the Internet, and we have seen no shame in sticking to what we know, which is newspaper publishing.

'We had no interest in investing in telephony - cable TV and our Internet investment were done through an in-house venture capital company,' says Colson. But now he says the company wishes to identify new electronic platforms as other ways of distributing its content. Funding this will mean selling around 300 of the company's local newspapers in the US and Canada but 'they are not online and many of them will never be online, so there is no place for them in this strategy'. However, it seems the Telegraph titles, and that pimple of a specialist magazine, the Spectator, are not for outright sale.

Conrad Black says that in the case of the Telegraph and his new Canadian daily paper the National Post, the company will look for partnerships which allow it to retain control of the titles of the papers but which will add a bit of electronic zing and a heap of cash to the enterprises.

Although it seems almost inconceivable that the decidedly inky Black would abandon print it is also worth remembering that in the UK the Telegraph was the first national daily newspaper to print electronically, and while it has not necessarily advanced its web presence as forcefully or innovatively as rivals, Black has long been alive to the possibilities of electronic publishing, if not as enthusiastic about them as Rupert Murdoch.

'We have actually been pursuing a disposal strategy in parts of the US, selling off a large number of the smaller papers over the past three years,' says Colson, who points to the fact that the company is sticking with the larger national or metropolitan newspapers which translate easily into online products. 'We don't want to do 150 deals with 150 platforms for bits of our content like restaurant reviews and obituaries, we want one or two partners. To us the Time Warner/AOL deal was a merger made in heaven - there may be scope for something like that to be replicated.'

As well as following this precedent Black is also watching Murdoch flirt with a number of potential schemes for 'unlocking value' in News Corp, without actually selling the whole shooting match to a 'new economy' firm such as Yahoo! or Oracle.

Persistent rumours over the past two months that Yahoo! is in talks with UK magazine publisher Emap represent the kind of deal of which Black is envious - dot.com dollars in exchange for serious content. But despite the appointment of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter to revamp Black's portfolio, there is scepticism about whether Hollinger will achieve the transformation Black is looking for.

'I'm really not sure that a Time Warner/AOL deal is the right play,' says one media investment banker, 'the big bulking up deals of like with like, such as Pearson and Bertelsmann recently, are rather more impressive. There is probably someone out there but maybe not the kind of sparkling partner they want'.

It is true that Black has been peevish - probably quite rightly - about Hollinger's share price in the past six months or so, but the group's performance has generally been very good.

It has posted increased profits of 24 per cent for 1999 but the shares have failed to respond accordingly, tarred with the dull brush of old media.

The fact that the company sits on a debt of $2.4 billion is inconvenient but not really debilitating, and under the current restructuring scheme, Black says that any proceeds from the sale - which are likely to be around the $1.8bn mark - will go towards reducing this debt as well as buying back Hollinger shares.

Black is personally as far from dull as it is possible to imagine. His recent outbursts against both liberal politicians in his native Canada and his highly entertaining threat to sue the British ambassador to Berlin for claiming that the Telegraph was biased on the issue of Britain's position in Europe are very much in the tradition of Black's taste for the dramatic.

His insistence that the Telegraph will remain under his control will calm the eurosceptics who rely on its unique take on the evils of joining a single currency to sustain them.

One further source of puzzlement for industry analysts is where exactly this rearrangement of deck chairs will leave Hollinger.

The surrender of the vast majority of his titles, if not necessarily the important metropolitan papers, such as the Ottowa Citizen and the Chicago Sun-Times, represents a huge switch in focus for Black, at least in his domestic market.

In the UK it would seem unlikely that Black, who is a true espouser of causes rather than a purely expedient proprietor, would let go of the titles ahead of either a general election or - more importantly - any referendum on a single European currency.

In the long term, Black seems to be focusing on moving his Hollinger troops away from the local skirmishes and onto bigger battlefields.

Of which Napoleon would undoubtedly have approved.
