fields.headline: Crisis as player indiscipline worsens
fields.trailText: Denis Campbell on the moves afoot to stop exodus of the men in black.
fields.body:
The Football Association are set to take unprecedented action to tackle the growing number of referees quitting the game in disgust at suffering abuse, threats and violence.

They will launch a campaign to halt an annual exodus of around 7,000 referees that is causing a serious shortage of officials at football's lower levels. Many who hang up their whistles are disillusioned at becoming targets of worsening indiscipline by players.

Veteran referees will act as 'personal mentors' to referees who are just starting their careers and will guide them through the potential pitfalls of keeping order on the pitch.

The FA are planning a high-profile advertising campaign, using newspapers, match-day programmes, libraries and town halls, to appeal for thousands of new referees.

Top referees such as Premier League middleman Graham Poll - England's representative at Euro 2000 - will act as 'role models' to encourage volunteers.

John Baker, of the FA's referees department, told The Observer: 'We train 7,500 new referees a year but the overall number of referees only rises by about 500 a year because 7,000 qualified officials decide to stop taking charge. We're paddling hard just to stay afloat.

'About 20 per cent of Sunday games in some places don't have a referee. We clearly need to recruit more referees and, particularly, retain them for much longer by making them feel more valued and less stranded and giving them better back-up.'

The campaign will begin in August and September. It will stress that people who love football can help the game by becoming referees, and that officiating is responsible, challenging and satisfying.

People coming to the end of their playing career, and those already involved in running amateur or youth football, will be among groups targeted. The FA want more 18 to 25-year-olds volunteers to provide a new generation of referees.

Under the mentoring scheme, newly qualified referees will receive special attention. Instructors will attend some of their first games to give advice, talk through problems and show them how to fill in a misconduct reports. After 10 games, groups of referees who trained together will meet up, swap experiences and discuss how to handle difficult moments.

Baker said parents of youngsters playing games were almost as likely to be aggressive towards referees as adults in Sunday league football. He said more referees quit through 'natural wastage' than because they had been verbally or physically abused.

Peter Willis, president of the 18,000-strong National Referees Association, welcomed 'any initiative by the FA that will help people take up refereeing. This sounds brilliant'. Each of the 73 county FAs are appointing a recruitment and retention officer to stem the losses.

Philip Don, the Premier League's referees officer, said that respect for referees had declined in recent years 'as has respect for teachers, police officers and anybody in authority. I was threatened when I was 15 and punched when I was 23, but carried on. My view was that if I packed up, they would have won. But I can really sympathise with anyone who starts refereeing and then finds it's not for him.'

Lee Addison is typical of those who have quit. The 26-year-old sent off a player for foul and abusive language during a park game he was refereeing in Enfield, Middlesex. As he was manhandled from the pitch, he shouted: 'Ref, if I see you on the streets, I'm going to knife you.' Addison mentioned both incidents in his match report.

'But at the disciplinary meeting, the player produced some witnesses who joined him in telling lies. The London FA people were asking me if I was sure he'd said that - as if I'd forget something like that. They eventually suspended him for the dismissal but found him not guilty of threatening me. 'I was so angry that I packed it in.'

Addison earned £16 for what proved to be his final stint in the middle. He now plays football and rugby at the weekend instead. He used to belong to the North Middlesex Referees Society, England's largest with 282 members including two Premier League and Football League officials.

Their training secretary, Robin Jagot, said misbehaviour by Premiership players was partly to blame for rising 'antics, aggro and indiscipline' in local football. 'One of our refs got punched to the ground for playing the advantage rule,' said Jagot. 'The team responsible disappeared without even getting changed, because someone had called the police. But the police said they couldn't identify who was responsible, so no action was taken.'

Sports Minister Kate Hoey got a insight into the refereeing crisis when she attended a recent meeting of the society. She heard how schoolboys were copying misbehaviour by big-name stars, anger at the MBE awarded to Ian Wright and criticism of television for turning moments during a match that a referee had missed into big controversies.

Hoey presented whistles to eight newly qualified referees. The meeting loudly chorused 'Hear, hear' when she said she hoped all eight would still be in the game five years from now.

fields.headline: Aggro makes ref grow stronger
fields.trailText: I do not know the full extent to which referees are abused, verbally and physically, but it is a sad fact of football life that there is a great deal of nastiness in the game at every level.
fields.body:
Professional football is an environment in which only the strongest survive - and this applies to referees as much as to anyone else. So while I can appreciate the concern about the high number of referees who drop out of the game at an early stage because of the abuse they take, I have to say that this vexation can also be viewed as an important test of character.

I do not know the full extent to which referees are abused, verbally and physically, but it is a sad fact of football life that there is a great deal of nastiness in the game at every level.

Even at schoolboy matches, it is not unusual to find the parents of the boys shouting insults at the referee and the opposing team. I have actually witnessed parents getting in fights with each other. Nobody can condone that sort of behaviour, but, at the same time, I cannot help thinking that those who come through all the aggro can only have benefited from these experiences.

Those who claim that match officials dropping out is bound to have an adverse effect on the overall standard of refereeing could make the same point about players. I still remember what I went through at the start of my career. As a schoolboy player in Edinburgh, the games I played on the other side of the city represented trips into some kind of war zone.

The feeling that I needed to have a thick skin, as well as ability, was also very real when I joined Dundee. I was one of only two apprentices - full-back Mike Cairne was the other - and both of us felt we were given quite a hard time. The treatment we got from the senior players was hardly in the kid-glove category. For example, if we tried to burst to the front on training runs, we would be liable to be kicked and told to get to the back.

We also experienced a considerable amount of intimidation from opposing players and fans in reserve team matches. The fact that there were so few spectators at these games meant that you could clearly hear almost every insult.

Cairne, a Scotland youth international, was a good player. But the pressure of all this was too much for him, and he went out of the game.

He is in good company. The proportion of young professional football recruits who fail to last the distance is very high, and the matter of temperament is one of the main reasons. I would suggest it is the same with referees - although this is not to say that in a number of cases what they have to contend with is particularly unpalatable. We should try to address this problem.

While I do not totally go along with the view that the abuse directed at referees stems from the example set by the players, coaches and managers at the top - I prefer to attribute it to the general behavioural decline in today's society - it is difficult to dispute that we can play a part in improving the situation.

One of the problems in our relationship with match officials is a lack of understanding in terms of where they are coming from.

My own perception of refereeing is that it is a very strange job for anyone to want to take on. As someone who has been fortunate enough to be able to fully express his love of the game through playing and managing, it is difficult for me to appreciate how anyone can get any enjoyment from controlling games.

The feeling among managers and players that referees are an entirely different breed was really driven home to me by a comment that was attributed to Paul Alcock following that infamous clash with Paolo Di Canio.

When asked if he felt like calling it a day, Alcock reportedly said that taking charge of Premiership games was a release from the pressures of his main job.

That referees do not rely on the game for their livelihoods is one of a number of reasons why their relationship with managers and players is not as harmonious as it could be. For example, one of my own criticisms - and I know it is echoed by a lot of other managers and players - is that referees are not more open in terms of admitting to their mistakes. Another is that some referees can come across as trying to develop themselves as celebrities.

So I am very much in favour of the idea of full-time professional referees. Moreover, as a way of improving our understanding of each other's problems, I would like to see a system whereby they could train regularly with the clubs.

Even this, of course, is not going to stop players disputing refereeing decisions - the best way to do this is through the 10-yard 'dissent' rule that the Premiership will introduce next season. This is something I have been advocating for the past 10 years.

How to stop managers publicly disputing refereeing decisions is another matter. It is a sensitive subject for me, because I am still perceived as one of the managers who tend to give referees the most stick. But the last time I could be said to have gone over the top was some two years ago, when I publicly described Stephen Lodge as a 'joke' over his performance in a match against Arsenal.

Quite apart from writing a letter of apology to him, I made a conscious decision to show greater restraint in my media comments about referees - if only because I had become tired of being held up as an example of referees being abused - and think that my record since then has been good.

If it is going to make any difference to the treatment of referees coming through the ranks, I am happy to try and keep it that way.

webTitle: ROY KEANE NAMED FOOTBALLER OF THE YEAR

fields.headline: ROY KEANE NAMED FOOTBALLER OF THE YEAR
fields.trailText: Despite the occasional doubts over his temperament, Keane was the runaway winner of the FWA award, gaining 53 per cent of the vote - the highest winning margin in the award's 52-year history.
fields.body:
IT'S NOT JUST the football writers who believe that Roy Keane is the best. The Manchester United midfielder won the FWA's Player of the Year Award yesterday, but an academic study shown exclusively to The Observer proves that Keane (right), alongside fellow midfielder David Beckham, holds the key to United's continued success.

A group of scientists from Liverpool's John Moores University studied every aspect of the final 20 games of United's treble-winning season last year, including the conclusion to the Premiership season, wrapping up yet another Double by defeating Newcastle in the FA Cup final and their triumphant Champions' League final victory over Bayern Munich at the end of May.

'United dominated their opponents in every aspect of play,' said Professor Tom Reilly, director of the university's Sport and Exercise Science research institute.

'What we found was that United scored a large number of goals from both the right flank and the middle of the pitch and those areas were also important to the team regaining possession from opponents in the build-up to goals.

'We were just looking at the cold statistics of the matches but anyone with a reasonable knowledge of football would be able to pick out the significance of both David Beckham and Roy Keane to the United system of play.'

Despite the occasional doubts over his temperament, Keane was the runaway winner of the FWA award, gaining 53 per cent of the vote - the highest winning margin in the award's 52-year history. Sunderland's Kevin Phillips finished second and Leeds United's Australian winger, Harry Kewell, was third.

fields.headline: It's our party...
fields.trailText: An outbreak of handbags at 20 paces has soured relations between the PFA and the England 2006 World Cup-bid team ahead of this evening's players' awards dinner.
fields.body:
An outbreak of handbags at 20 paces has soured relations between the PFA and the England 2006 World Cup-bid team ahead of this evening's players' awards dinner.

When Fifa president Sepp Blatter agreed to present the main award, Alec McGivan and his fellow 2006 campaigners spotted a perfect excuse to roll out the red carpet just nine weeks before the 24-strong Fifa executive - headed by Blatter - decides between England, Germany, South Africa, Brazil and Morocco.

But McGivan's suggestion that the FA and 2006 team should meet, greet and entertain the most powerful figure in world football went down badly with PFA chief exec Gordon Taylor.

'It's our event; we can look after our guest of honour ourselves', is the politest way to summarise his forthright response.

At the Grosvenor House Hotel bash tonight, Blatter may well reflect that neither of the likely winners, Roy Keane (an Irishman) and Harry Kewell (who's Australian) are English.

fields.headline: Best tragedy has a winner
fields.trailText: Addaction, a drink and drugs rehabilitation charity, has been chosen as the beneficiary of the charity premiere of the forthcoming Best biopic.
fields.body:
George Best's 30-year struggle with alcoholism will have one winner, at least.

Addaction, a drink and drugs rehabilitation charity, has been chosen as the beneficiary of the charity premiere of the forthcoming Best biopic. It will receive about £8,000 from the event at the UCI Plaza cinema in London on 11 May.

Addaction fundraising manager Nicky Buckley said: 'It's great to have a high-profile person like George on board giving us his support and backing, especially as he can relate to some of the people that we treat.'

It is hoped Best will attend, though he is still too unwell to make tomorrow's world premiere of his life story in Belfast.

The Belfast Telegraph has hailed the movie as 'arguably the greatest football film ever made', while actor John Lynch - who plays the man himself - revealed that a recent private screening left Rodney Marsh in tears.

fields.headline: Arrogant Barcelona look foolish
fields.trailText: Barça get themselves thrown out of next season's Spanish Cup and insult the King of Spain in the same week.
fields.body:
Barcelona seem to have declared war on the rest of the world.

First they incurred the Spanish FA's wrath over the Spanish Cup semi-final second leg against Atletico Madrid last Monday. The ruling body took a dim view of the Catalan club's failure to raise a team for the game (their players, pictured, lined up along the touchline with their arms folded and refused to play). Their excuses about injuries and international call-ups were dismissed, leaving them with a heavy fine and ban from next year's competition.

Now it has emerged that Barça also offended the King of Spain. Spain's football knock-out competition isn't known as the Copa del Rey, or King's Cup, for nothing. The royal authorities help run it and the monarch expects to be kept abreast of any important developments. Madrid high society has interpreted Barcelona's failure to keep the palace informed as an insulting breach of protocol.

The club's arrogance grows by the day and last week saw them trying to get Atletico Madrid striker Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink banned from playing in this weekend's crucial league match against them.

The ex-Leeds United front man was due to be suspended for the cancelled semi-final and Barça argued that his ban should carry over into their league match. Although at a later press conference to 'clarify Barça's legal position' on the Spanish FA's decision, they later conceded that should the semi-final be rescheduled for May 16, their preferred date, they would be happy for Hasselbaink to serve his suspension then.

fields.headline: Jardel's out of bounds
fields.trailText: After van Nistelrooy, Victor Vago introduces us to the Next Big Thing.
fields.body:
Mancheter united's pursuit of Ruud van Nistelrooy appears doomed after the extraordinary events of last week. Their initial interest was explained by Sir Alex Ferguson who decreed that there was no one in the world to touch van Nistelrooy in terms of quality and age.

Whether he was right may now be irrelevant after the Dutch international's training-ground collapse on Friday. United, regardless of whether the deal is revived in the future, must consider other options.

The obvious candidate to top their list is the Champions League top scorer, Mario Jardel, Porto's Brazilian international forward. He is three years older than Van Nistelrooy at 26 but his scoring record puts the injured man - and every other striker in Europe - in the shade.

There is a problem, however. Britain's employment laws demand that non-EU foreigners must have played in 75 per cent of their national side's recent matches. And Jardel, competing with some of the finest players on the planet, is nowhere near that level for Brazil - yet. While a Tunisian or a Moldovan with the necessary caps can gain a work permit to play in the Premiership, Jardel is kept out - and, with Lazio said to be interested, he will surely move to Italy, where regulations are more lax.

Jardel is simply waiting for his chance to perform in a bigger league. A powerful header of the ball and a deadly finisher, he would be ideally suited to the Premiership and has already attracted the attention of Leeds scouts.

Four years ago, Rangers tried to take him to Scotland, but were unable to convince the Home Office. After all his exploits, it appears Jardel, who would love to play at Old Trafford, cannot overcome the red tape. His attempt to secure EU citizenship through his wife's French and Italian origins has come to nothing.

His wife once adorned the cover of Playboy but would not do so nowadays as it would offend Jardel, who has become a committed Christian. 'God will always receive the glory for my accomplishments,' he says.

'Super Mario', as he is known, was the top scorer in Europe last season with 36 league and cup goals (as opposed to Van Nistelrooy's 'mere' 31). This season he is likely to beat that total and set a record. He will probably leave at the end of the season and is keen on three countries - England, Italy and Spain.

Jardel started with local Brazilian club Ferroviario and moved to Vasco da Gama, then to Gremio, where he scored 10 in 13 matches on the way to winning the league title and Libertadores Cup. A move to Porto followed in 1996 and they have won the league in each of his seasons there. He scored 34 goals in his first season, 29 in his second and 36 in his third.

This season, he has already scored 35 and, with three league matches left, he stands to set a new landmark. His latest hat-trick in the 4-1 win against Vitoria Setubal last weekend nudged him towards the record. Add to that the 10 goals that make him top scorer in the Champions League and another nine in the less prestigious Portuguese Cup and Supercup, and he is already on 52 goals.

Porto would be reluctant to sell, but know they cannot stand in the way of his ambitions. The asking price is £11 million - £7.5m cheaper than United's crocked original target.

Jardel said: 'The real test is in the top leagues of Europe, such as England, Italy or Spain. I've got two years left to run on my contract and will carry on at Porto if no one buys me. I'll have to see if anyone pays the £11m.

'Who wouldn't like to play in England, Italy or Spain? They have attractive levels of football. The English game is fast and exciting and its attacking style suits strikers. I follow it a lot and like it, but I wouldn't want to join just any club. Manchester United are a winning club and I'd prefer to go there than a less successful team.'

Not that he would restrict himself to United if a move to Britain became possible. Jardel knows all about David O'Leary's checks on his form. 'Leeds United have had a great campaign and I'm pleased about their interest. They have good forwards - the whole squad is good. Who knows if one day I'll be juggling with a ball on an English pitch?'

He won the world under-20 championship with Brazil in 1993 and clearly a bright future already beckoned. However, his move to Portugal limited his chances at full international level to only seven appearances.

His hopes of becoming a Brazil regular depend on more than just his record, and he realises that time may run out if he does not move out of Portugal. His problem is that ahead of him he has Rivaldo, Ronaldo (when fit), Ronaldinho, Amoruso and Elber. Wanderley Luxemburgo, the Brazil manager, has at least, given Jardel a limited number of chances.

Benfica's German coach, Jupp Heynckes, rates Jardel highly. He said: 'He's an exceptionally dangerous striker with a great instinct for goal. He anticipates chances. You can leave him alone outside the box, but inside the box he's outstanding - a real phenomenon. He can succeed elsewhere in Europe. I recommended him to Bayern Munich but he's too expensive for Germany.'

Unfortunately, he's not too expensive, for Manchester United, Leeds, Rangers or any other British side - he's simply unavailable because of red tape.

fields.headline: Huge interest in Premier rights
fields.trailText: Jon Henderson explains why the Premier League stands to raise close to £2 billion over the next three years.
fields.body:
The Premier League have sent out 74 tender documents to companies interested in bidding for the various television rights packages on offer from the football season after next.

It is the sort of vigorous response the League were hoping for, after they circulated details of the three-year packages at the start of the month, and there was a buoyant meeting of the clubs last week. The level of interest is remarkable considering the first two Premiership contracts in 1992 and 1996 were won by Sky in the face of minimal opposition.

The main morsels on offer this time are 66 matches to be shown either on subscription or free-to-air services (or both), 40 pay-per-view games and highlights for Match of the Day-style programmes on Saturdays and Sundays. With internet and overseas rights also being sold off in football's biggest-ever auction, the Premier League stand to raise close to £2 billion over three years.

The chief problem the League now face is processing all the bids and reaching a decision within the next three months. Although the mood of last week's meeting was to spend as long as it takes over reaching a decision, League officials secretly accept that everything has to be done and dusted by the start of next season.

webTitle: Poor old Windows and offices junkies

fields.headline: Poor old Windows and offices junkies
fields.trailText: If the Nasdaq catches a cold every time Microsoft sneezes, then stand by for a bad case of pneumonia. As the US judicial process moves inexorably towards a decision to break up Bill Gates's empire, all kinds of people are getting cold feet.
fields.body:
If the Nasdaq catches a cold every time Microsoft sneezes, then stand by for a bad case of pneumonia. As the US judicial process moves inexorably towards a decision to break up Bill Gates's empire, all kinds of people are getting cold feet. Like those disgruntled Russian and East Germans who yearn for the old certainties of Stalinism, they wonder whether the world can cope with the terrifying freedoms which lie ahead.

Consider the strange case of Louise Kehoe, the Financial Times 's Silicon Valley correspondent. Ms. Kehoe is a terrific journalist with wonderful contacts and robust common sense . At a time, for example, when most technology hacks are drooling about the prospects for WAP, she is one of the few who has taken the trouble to examine the technology critically - and to report objectively on its limitations. (She was not impressed.)

It is a testimony to the power of Microsoft-fixation that not even Kehoe is immune to it. In her column last Wednesday she fell to worrying about what would happen to the millions of pathetic Windows and Office junkies when nasty ol' judge Jackson splits Microsoft into two companies - Windows Inc. and Office Inc. 'Bad enough,' she writes, 'to be bounced between the customer support departments of hardware and software companies. Will we in future have to determine whether a problem lies in the operating system or a software application before getting help?'

There is a lot more in that vein. 'Perhaps Microsoft has abused its market power to enforce standards,' Kehoe burbles, 'but at least it did so efficiently.' All of which makes one wonder when was the last time she actually tried getting help from the current version of Microsoft. And does she know the famous joke about a helicopter which gets lost in fog and spots an office building through a gap in the mist? As it descends to seek assistance, workers in the building gather at the windows to watch. The pilot scrawls 'Help! Where Are We?' in large letters on a card and holds it against the cockpit window. 'In a helicopter,' the workers write back. 'Ah,' says the pilot, 'that's Microsoft. We must be in Redmond.'

Neal Stephenson, the science-fiction novelist, has written a wonderful essay entitled In the Beginning was the Command Line which contains an hilarious account of his attempts to get help for a problem with Windows NT. The final straw for Stephenson was that when Microsoft finally accepted his description of the bug he had encountered, the company asserted that it then owned the copyright on his report! I need hardly add that Mr. Stephenson is now a keen Linux user.

Another intriguing aspect of media coverage of Microsoft's woes is the sudden splurge of articles about Bill Gates's philanthropy. The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is now the largest charitable foundation in the history of the world. Its assets stand at $21.8 billion, which means that under US law it has to give away more than $1billion a year - no mean feat. So far, it has given (among other things) $850 million to vaccination programmes in poor countries and $550 million to schools and libraries. Just to put that in context: the New York Times estimates that, at current values, Andrew Carnegie gave away only $3 billion and John D. Rockefeller a paltry $6 billion. Gates's donations to the Foundation come in the form of quarterly bundles of Microsoft shares, which the trustees exchange for hard cash. It's nice to see people who know what they're doing.

fields.headline: A modern fairytale
fields.trailText:
If I Told You Once
Judy Budnitz
Flamingo £12.99, pp304
Buy it at BOL
fields.body:
If I Told You Once
Judy Budnitz
Flamingo £12.99, pp304
Buy it at BOL

Judy Budnitz has achieved that rare phenomenon, a contemporary fairytale with some of the resonance and grim brutality of the masters of the form. If I Told You Once (Flamingo £12.99, pp304) tells the tale of four generations of women, spanning the transition from the dark, ancient forests of the east to a bright, new country across the sea. It is, in a sense, the story of eastern European Jewish migration to the the American Dream, with sinister tales of a savage culling in the old country filtering through to the guilt-ridden survivors, but it is very much stranger than that.

It begins in the voice of Ilana, describing life in her village, a place buried in snow for nine months of the year, of ferocious, almost Monty Pythonesque grimness: 'It was a place where someone had forgotten to add the colour: low, grey clouds, crooked houses of weatherbeaten wood, coils of smoke rising from cook stores and rubbish heaps." Ilana's huge, hairy brother, Ari, tears wild beasts apart, 'not for sport but simply out of his rough love'. Her mother lurches from one excruciating childbirth to the next.

It is only when Ilana encounters a young bandit in the forest that she has a glimpse of a different life. He gives her an egg, a Fabergé egg in fact, in which she sees 'a picture of a life more refined, more considered, a world where people had found a way to distinguish themselves from animals'. After a series of adventures, involving Bluebeard-like forbidden chambers, lethal metal sex traps, a footless maiden, rape and various brutal deaths, Ilana manages to escape to the bright, new country with her lover, a young actor.

Through the birth of her beloved twin sons, Eli and Wolf and her less beloved daughter, Sashie, she keeps the storytelling tradition alive. Sashie rebels against the witch-like ferocity and solidity of her mother, harbouring fantasies, later fuelled by the discovery of the Fabergé egg, of a grand, aristocratic past, but Ilana persists in dragging her back to the lumpen reality of her heritage.

This is a powerful, evocative tale of the human struggle against brutality, the tensions between memory and history, the desire to remember and the need to forget. Shot through with metafictional uncertainty, a winning black humour and prose of, at times, simplicity and strength, it quietly challenges its own assertion that 'there are some stories that defy telling'.

webTitle: The unlucky cards in Dagenham's losing hand

fields.headline: The unlucky cards in Dagenham's losing hand
fields.trailText: The carnival is over for Ford's little Fiesta. More than 3,000 workers who make the car at Dagenham are going to be out in the cold when the music stops.
fields.body:
The carnival is over for Ford's little Fiesta. More than 3,000 workers who make the car at Dagenham are going to be out in the cold when the music stops.

It now looks certain that the motor giant will announce in the next three weeks that it intends to axe car manufacturing at the massive Essex plant when the current Fiesta model is phased out next year. The new Fiesta will be produced in Cologne.

Employment and production at Dagenham have declined steadily over the last 20 years. The factory made the Cortina and then, in the Eighties, its replacement, the Sierra. But when the Sierra came to the end of its lifecycle, Dagenham lost out on its successor, the Mondeo. Today the Mondeo is made in Ford's Genk factory in Belgium, and Dagenham only has the Fiesta and its light-van derivative.

So after 70 years production of Ford's blue-badged runarounds, what has finally dealt the fatal blow? Is it lazy British workers, a government that has turned its back on the 'old economy', or strategic errors by Ford chiefs in the US?

Popular though the Fiesta is in the UK, the tired model has had its day and is not doing well on the Continent. Ford bosses have admitted that its replacement is long overdue, and have belatedly speeded up plans to launch an all-new Fiesta. But despite dragging forward the launch date it will not hit the forecourts until late 2001.

Nigel Griffiths, European autos analyst for consultancy Standard & Poor's DRI, said: 'Ford really should have got its act together and had a totally new Fiesta model available much sooner. The last facelift late last year did not do the business; it is losing out to more exciting rivals, such as the Peugeot 206, Renault Clio and Fiat Punto. Ford's market share is appalling across Europe.'

This slump is partly the result of declining Fiesta sales but also caused by poor sales of the Mondeo, due to be replaced this autumn. Ford made just £17 million profits in Europe last year on an £18 billion turnover, with profit margins on car sales of just 0.1 per cent. This contrasts sharply with Ford's record global profits of £4.5bn.

The Galaxy people-carrier, sporty Puma and tiny Ka are doing well in Europe but are sidelines in comparison with Ford's three mass-market models, the Mondeo, Focus and Fiesta.

The Focus, which replaced the Escort, is doing well but Ford chiefs admit that the fortunes of a huge business cannot rely on one model alone.

Despite being the second largest carmaker in the world, after General Motors, Ford is only the fourth bestseller in a western European car market of 16 million a year. It was brand leader in Europe in 1997 with 11 per cent. But Volkswagen overtook Ford in 1998 and has stayed at the top ever since. In the first quarter of this year, the Ford brand (excluding other badges in the group such as Volvo and Jaguar) commanded only 8.7 per cent of the European market, behind VW, Renault and Vauxhall/Opel, which each have more than 10 per cent.

Like all manufacturers with plants in the UK, Ford has a difficulty with the strength of the pound against the euro. But across Europe it has a wider sales problem and too much factory capacity.

Griffiths said: 'As far as they are concerned they are haemorrhaging in Europe. It is not just that they are not making money but they have not had much return on their European investments and they want to do something about that.'

The problems have prompted Ford to conduct a root-and-branch review of its European operations and Dagenham is under the spotlight. Griffiths said: 'If there is a big change at Dagenham, then that will involve more radical change at other European plants as well.' But that could involve other factories gaining additional models whereas Dagenham is particularly vulnerable to the opposite fate.

Not only is the Fiesta selling badly on the Continent but there has been a 'consumer strike' in the UK over high British prices.

The factory has improved efficiency enormously in the last 10 years but is still not as productive as other European plants - it takes 25 per cent longer to build a Fiesta in Dagenham than in Cologne. And, although workers cost less to employ in the UK than on the Continent, which is an advantage, they can be sacked for around half the cost of a German or Belgian worker.

Then there is a local issue of working practices at Dagenham. Huge strides have been made at the plant to improve productivity and modernise industrial and employee relations during the Nineties. But it is still behind the times. There have been high-profile rows over racism at the plant, shopfloor disputes, problems with absenteeism and hiccups in the supply of components.

Meanwhile, the strength of the pound against the euro causes problems beyond the workforce's control. And the flexible labour laws that helped attract companies to invest here in the first place make it cheaper for them to leave when they need to make cutbacks.

Joe Dickinson, of consultants AT Kearney, said: 'You have got to admit that the cost of closing plants in the UK is a lot lower than in Germany or Belgium. It is not a common market in Europe in the sense of labour laws.'

Ford opened its factories in the UK half a century before the Thatcherite policies of union-breaking and flexible labour brought Far Eastern manufacturers flocking, but it is now in the centre of the debate about how easy it is to ditch thousands of British workers and, indeed, an entire plant if that is what the rigours of the market demand.

Ford has already cut out one factory from the brand when it denied the Focus to its Halewood plant on Merseyside in 1998 and, instead, decided to replace production of the Escort with the forthcoming small Jaguar.

But now it wants to cut more capacity and again looks to Britain. One industry observer last week predicted that the new Fiesta would be built first at Cologne and then, if more were needed, at Ford's plant in Valencia, Spain - deep in euroland.

That would be the final insult for the redundant Dagenham workforce. But is Britain outraged or merely resigned?

The Government, for one, appears only sufficiently outraged in such cases to set up task forces for the mopping up exercise. No moves to weaken sterling, encourage interest rate cuts or commit to the euro. And British motorists? They want groovy wheels and value for money - and whoever delivers the best deal wins.

webTitle: There goes the family silver again

fields.headline: There goes the family silver again
fields.standfirst: The crisis in British manufacturing is entirely of the Government's own making. It must act on sterling
fields.trailText: The crisis in British manufacturing is entirely of the Government's own making. It must act on sterling.
fields.body:
It's as if the country can't and won't confront the truth. Over the last three months, the heart has begun to be ripped out of our industrial and commercial centres as a result of one of the most stunning periods of currency overvaluation ever. Longbridge's future now hangs by a thread; Dagenham's closure is nearly certain. Many more shocks are in the pipeline. Yet the principal cause of all this remains largely undiscussed.

Sterling has climbed to levels that rival the uncompetitiveness following Britain's return to the Gold Standard in 1925 or the first years of Mrs Thatcher's governments in the early 1980s. But because it is impossible to report or discuss this phenomenon without taking a position on whether we should join the euro, Britain has almost imposed a self-denying ordinance upon itself.

Compared with the outcry following Churchill's decision in the Twenties or the passionate denunciation of Thatcher and Howe in the Eighties, the Government has been allowed to get away almost scot-free from the economic and social consequences of its exchange-rate policy. An eerie silence reigns. BMW and Ford can explain that the chief reason that volume car production is no longer possible at Longbridge or Dagenham is because the exchange rate makes it hopeless, but there is little or no political resonance.

Yet the carnage extends well beyond the car industry. Britain's trade surplus in pharmaceuticals in 1999 had its biggest percentage fall since 1945 - and this in one of our last internationally competitive industries. Exports may have risen some 7 per cent, but imports have jumped 24 per cent. With the pound now even higher, this year the trends will be much worse.

Part of the reason for only localised anger is that while the CBI's recent survey of business confidence warns that a recession in manufacturing is imminent, manufacturing only constitutes a quarter of GDP and a fifth of employment. Unemployment generally is still falling, benefiting from the momentum of nearly eight years of sustained economic growth. Perhaps the vigour of the service sector will mask the crisis hitting manufacturing.

But the service sector trades internationally as well. Tourism, for example, is just as exchange-rate dependent. Day trips from France on Eurostar are down this year by 9 per cent; overall, the number of tourists visiting Britain in January and February grew by just 2 per cent - the lowest growth rate for more than 10 years. The same trends are evident across the board - the inflow of overseas students, the capacity to underwrite international insurance business, sales of music, etc. The idea that the service sector is insulated from the crazy valuation of the pound is wrong; the discomfort will soon become generalised.

Another important reason for the silence is that the launch of the euro has made it harder to understand just how high the pound has risen. The fall in the euro is reported joyfully by a broadly Eurosceptic press, but what is omitted is that translating the euro/sterling rate into its equivalent Deutschmark rate means that the pound now buys DM3.36. That is 20 per cent above the DM2.78 rate at which sterling crashed out of the ERM in 1992 because it was overvalued.

And this, of course, is the single biggest reason for the silence over the exchange rate. The launch of the euro is the central reason for the pound's overvaluation. The world now has two giant currencies - the dollar and the euro - and one very large currency - the yen. The scale of untrammelled, speculative flows between these currency blocs is awesome, changing the dynamics of exchange-rate determination forever. 'Baby' currencies such as sterling are squeezed between the new giant currency blocs so that their movements are even more volatile than before; they are carried higher or lower for longer. The choice is stark. We throw in our lot with the Europeans or we learn to live with extreme currency overvaluation. We have no 'sovereignty' whatsoever.

This has been true for the last 16 months, but there has a massive lacuna in political debate. The Tories cannot attack the Government because they are so anti-euro that they don't have a single coherent idea to offer on how the pound can be lowered. New Labour, emerging as the most timid administration since the war, refuses to champion the euro or even acknowledge that membership of the euro might have taken some of the pressure off the car industry.

Brown's and Blair's blanket veto extends even to the all-party pressure group, Britain in Europe, so that it can not even talk about the issue it was established to fight for! The Eurosceptic press hardly helps; Daily Mail readers would have needed to be sleuths to have learned that Nissan's announcement 10 days ago of 5,000 potential job losses was accompanied by a plea to join the euro.

Nissan is not alone. The entire car industry says the same, as does every inward investor. Yet the Government finds itself adopting the same free-market mantra as the early Thatcherites. I remem ber interviewing Leon Brittan in 1982 when, as Chief Secretary to the Treasury, he insisted that there was nothing that could be done about the high pound; no commitment to join the ERM; no intervention; no change in interest-rate policy; no declaration of intent to lower it; no nothing. You could not buck the market.

Last week, Trade Minister Patricia Hewitt dismissed my plea that the proceeds of the mobile-phone auction be deployed overtly to buy euro assets as part of a plan to curb the rise in the exchange rate and join the euro at a lower rate. Drop in the ocean, she opined. You can't challenge the market. No recognition that euro membership would have eased the pressure. No nothing. I found myself transported in a timewarp, as, open-mouthed, as I had been by Leon Brittan's near identical comments 20 years earlier.

I doubt Hewitt privately believes what she and her fellow Ministers have currently to say in public, but New Labour is reaping what it has sown. Because it is not clear whether it is a free-market or Keynesian government and because it does not want to challenge the conservative economic consensus, it is left with no exchange-rate policy.

Worse, it has allowed Euroscepticism to develop to such a degree that even if it wanted eventually to join the euro, the technical and political obstacles are close to insuperable - the rate needs to be 30 per cent lower and a two-to-one majority against joining needs to be overturned.

Perhaps the emasculation of what remains of our industrial heartlands will change opinion. While we wait, many more British businesses will follow Longbridge and Dagenham. It's little surprise that a growing number of British working people wonder if New Labour represents their interests. Over the exchange rate, it doesn't.

The Tories cannot attack the Government because they are so anti-euro that they don't have a single coherent idea to offer on how the pound can be lowered. New Labour, emerging as the most timid administration since the war, refuses to champion the euro or even acknowledge that membership of the euro might have taken some of the pressure off the car industry. Brown's and Blair's blanket veto extends even to the all-party pressure group, Britain in Europe, so that it can not even talk about the issue it was established to fight for! The Eurosceptic press hardly helps; Daily Mail readers would have needed to be sleuths to have learned that Nissan's announcement 10 days ago of 5,000 potential job losses was accompanied by a plea to join the euro. Nissan is not alone. The entire car industry says the same, as does every inward investor. Yet the Government finds itself adopting the same free-market mantra as the early Thatcherites. I remem ber interviewing Leon Brittan in 1982 when, as Chief Secretary to the Treasury, he insisted that there was nothing that could be done about the high pound; no commitment to join the ERM; no intervention; no change in interest-rate policy; no declaration of intent to lower it; no nothing. You could not buck the market. Last week, Trade Minister Patricia Hewitt dismissed my plea that the proceeds of the mobile-phone auction be deployed overtly to buy euro assets as part of a plan to curb the rise in the exchange rate and join the euro at a lower rate. Drop in the ocean, she opined. You can't challenge the market. No recognition that euro membership would have eased the pressure. No nothing. I found myself transported in a timewarp, as, open-mouthed, as I had been by Leon Brittan's near identical comments 20 years earlier. I doubt Hewitt privately believes what she and her fellow Ministers have currently to say in public, but New Labour is reaping what it has sown. Because it is not clear whether it is a free-market or Keynesian government and because it does not want to challenge the conservative economic consensus, it is left with no exchange-rate policy. Worse, it has allowed Euroscepticism to develop to such a degree that even if it wanted eventually to join the euro, the technical and political obstacles are close to insuperable - the rate needs to be 30 per cent lower and a two-to-one majority against joining needs to be overturned. Perhaps the emasculation of what remains of our industrial heartlands will change opinion. While we wait, many more British businesses will follow Longbridge and Dagenham. It's little surprise that a growing number of British working people wonder if New Labour represents their interests. Over the exchange rate, it doesn't.

webTitle: America rallies to teenage gay icon

fields.headline: America rallies to teenage gay icon
fields.standfirst: College football hero Corey Johnson came out - and no one was outraged. In a tolerant America, gay is the new straight
fields.trailText: Many of the thousands of people converging on Washington, DC, today for what's hoped to be the country's largest ever gay and lesbian march will not be craning their necks to see Ellen DeGeneres, k.d. lang or the Pet Shop Boys - but a teenage American football captain from Massachusetts.
fields.body:
Many of the thousands of people converging on Washington, DC, today for what's hoped to be the country's largest ever gay and lesbian march will not be craning their necks to see Ellen DeGeneres, k.d. lang or the Pet Shop Boys - but a teenage American football captain from Massachusetts.

A year ago, Corey Johnson, 18, revealed to team mates at Masconomet High, near Boston, that he was gay, an act of bravery given the reputation of football jocks for being the most boorish and bigoted of all schoolboys. They did not beat him up. Instead they sang him the gay anthem 'YMCA' on the team bus and finished the season with seven wins and four defeats.

Since Johnson's story became public earlier this year he has become the country's latest gay icon, a hero in a tale of youthful tolerance, and an antidote to the grim stories of Matthew Shephard and Teena Brandon, both murdered because of their sexual orientation. Shephard, a gay 18-year-old student in Laramie, Wyoming, died in 1998 after being beaten and tied to a prairie fence by two rednecks; Brandon, 21, was murdered in Lincoln, Nebraska in 1993 for passing herself off as a man. Her story was told in this year's Oscar-winning film Boys Don't Cry.

Johnson has been approached for a profile in Vanity Fair (he declined; not enough teenage readers who might benefit from his experience) and is one of the hottest 'gets' on the talk show circuit. Such has been the media interest that he is being advised by Kevin Costner's publicity agent.

Johnson says he is no hero and that in revealing himself as the only openly gay pupil in a school of 1,200 he was just telling the truth. He hopes his example will encourage others of his age to feel safe in revealing themselves, too. 'People at my school would have said this was impossible - for the captain of the football team to come out and have it be an accepting environment,' he told School Sports , the magazine that first published his story.

'Just by telling the truth, I've been able to help people because they see that somebody can live their life without hiding things about an integral part of who they are.'

The lack of shock at Johnson's declaration, says the magazine's editor Jonathan Segal, suggests discrimination even in sports at school is fading. 'The more Corey Johnsons that come out ... the more readily prejudices will dissipate. But we still have a long way to go.'

Not as far as before. A recent Newsweek cover proclaimed what's 'Gay Today' and concluded that 30 years after the Stonewall Riots in New York's Greenwich Village and with Aids a diminishing concern, gay rights is now a mature movement and that the struggle for tolerance has moved to the frontiers of family life.

The magazine spotlighted a minister in robes, a soldier, a doctor, a teacher and New York City cop - all emblematic of a mild, open society. As US satirist Fran Lebowitz says: 'Who are the most square people on earth? The only people left who want to go into the army and get married? Homosexuals.'

Even Dan Savage, a 36- year-old columnist known for racy tales of homosexual life, has settled down and adopted a son in a genteel Seattle suburb. 'What's wrong with being boring?' he says. 'The vast majority of people are boring and stupid and cheap.

'We told ourselves for a long time that because we were gay, we were somehow more with-it and on-the-edge, so we believed it. It was Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci and me. Oscar Wilde was one big messed-up queen in England, but guess what? There were a lot more, but they just weren't interesting.'

The Washington Post - which last week ran a story titled 'Is Gay Mainstream?' - reported that organisers in Washington had a difficult time deciding on causes to support for the march. After much debate, they settled on a mission statement that highlights marriage, hate-crime protection, health concerns such as Aids and breast cancer, anti-discrimination laws, military service and racial/social justice.

These days, some say campaigning is a bore. 'No one is signing up for the Millennium March. People are voting with their feet,' says Michael Warner, a professor at Rutgers University in New York who last year wrote The Trouble with Normal, in which he said gay marriage is not worth marching for.

'This Fifties version of how gay life should be that we've been handed is actually not making a lot of people happy, which is the only thing that gives me hope,' he says. 'The Millennium March is just a fund-raiser groping for a theme. [The people] in charge have wedded themselves so earnestly to the idea of a happy gay and lesbian identity; they seem determined to make gay life as boring as it can possibly be.'

What's boring to some is radical to others. Gay commentator Andrew Sullivan argues that revolution resides in the details. 'What could be more boring than to still be referring to yourself as "queer",' he asks.

'What's finished is far-left politics. It's far more radical now to be a reform rabbi [a group that has announced it supports gay marriage] than a member of the Lesbian Avengers. It's more radical to settle down and get married than to be a gay activist.'

Virtually the only people still interested in gay issues are homophobes. Earlier this month, a national talk radio host, Dr Laura Schlessinger, called homosexuality a 'biological error' and gay sex 'deviant'. Her words attracted the public condemnation of Sir Elton John and others but for the most part were ignored as a tiresome rant.

According to a Newsweek poll, the US public has become more accepting. Fewer (46 per cent, down from 54 per cent in 1998) believe homosexuality is a sin, while a high percentage think gays should have equal rights in employment and housing. A small majority of gays, lesbians and bisexuals (56 per cent) say straight people are more tolerant.

But hate crimes against homosexuals still occur. Thirty-one states have legislation banning same-sex marriages, gay adoption is still fiercely opposed by conservative groups (Texan Governor George W. Bush has endorsed these groups in principle) and homophobia is acute in black and Latino communities.

After the rally in Washington, Johnson will take a lower profile. 'He's still coming to terms with his new identity,' says Chad Konecky, writer of the School Sports story. 'But he understands there's this tremendous opportunity for him to spread the message of diversity and tolerance. He's been given this unique platform and he understands that.'

fields.headline: Gently does it
fields.standfirst: Fast food, ready-made meals, TV dinners - whatever happened to the simple pleasures of preparing supper?
fields.trailText: Fast food, ready-made meals, TV dinners - whatever happened to the simple pleasures of preparing supper?
fields.body:
Cooking is too often about simply getting something on the table. The pasta sauce I can make in the nine minutes it takes for the penne to become al dente; the chops I just about have time to grill in the moments between my arrival home and everyone else's; the supermarket-made vegetable bake that takes exactly the same amount of time in the oven as it takes me to have a bath and get ready to watch ER . Too often what I cook is decided by the time I have available or the amount of energy I have left at the end of the day. But sometimes, just sometimes, I want to cook for the sheer pleasure of it.

And there is pleasure. The satisfaction of watching mushrooms turn from white to gold in sizzling butter; the feel of soft fresh pasta between your fingers; the sensation of meticulously rubbing the sandy, papery skins off new potatoes; the smell of a cake as it rises in your oven or witnessing mayonnaise slowly thicken as you beat it, patiently, adding the oil drop by tiny drop, the way we are told to by those writers who would rather die than buy a tube of ready-made.

Germaine Greer said recently how much she prefers cooking 'the hard way': 'I wanted the release of concentrating on each process and the physicality of the contact with the fruit, even if the stinging juice under my torn thumbnail brought tears to my eyes.' I know what she means and I agree, and it is too bad that I don't always allow myself the time to cook like this. Saving a few minutes or getting supper ready in time to watch our favourite soap has become so crucial that one can sometimes forget there is probably more pleasure in watching a meal slowly come together than there could ever be in even your favourite movie. That is why books are better, I suppose. They at least wait for us to finish cooking.

Unless you have devoted your life to keeping home, your weekday eating will inevitably be a hotch-potch of short cuts and cop outs. Mine certainly is, though I do take the time to smell and taste, to poke and stroke. I can't even peel a banana without taking a quick sniff. But these are stolen moments. I somehow want the pleasure of eating to outlast the pleasure of preparation, but it's as if you can't relax until you are sitting down with your meal in front of you.

The clever thing, and perhaps the most life-enriching, would be to relax as soon as we take our coats off and start to cook rather than when we sit down at the table. But hunger (or what we perceive as hunger) sometimes gets in the way. Sod the joy of sniffing and stirring. We want our supper Now.

And yet time in the kitchen can be just as therapeutic and as satisfying as time spent at the table. The other day, rain coming down in sheets (and another excuse not to get started on the garden), I spent an entire morning making one dish for supper. I let a white sauce bubble slowly so that the floury taste would completely cook out, and for once I remembered to put in the bay leaves and stud the onion with cloves and finish the sauce with cream. I soaked dried porcini till they plumped up like slices of sponge to add depth and earthy savour to a sauce of cultivated mushrooms. I pounded basil with pinenuts and pecorino by hand to make a sweet pesto (pure aromatherapy, even with understated spring basil). The only easy way out I took was dodging the raindrops to get some sheets of silky, hand-made lasagne from Mr Rocco up the road. And anyway this wasn't cheating: his pasta is the best I have ever eaten and makes my home-made version look and eat like a duvet.

Perhaps you think I should cook this multi-layered food every day. Well, I don't. It is not simply that I feel there is more to life than standing at the stove but, over the years, I have found that if you buy really good ingredients, then you rarely have to do much to them in order to eat them at their best. I have never really understood the point of complicated recipes and, to my taste, the result is rarely worth the trouble. But the trouble taken can, I suppose, be a good enough reason for cooking a recipe if it gives you pleasure. The physical act of cooking, of peeling and chopping, of simmering and sieving, can be pure joy if you have nothing else in particular to do.

With no one screaming for their supper, you can potter about doing things 'the hard way'. With the soporific burbling of the radio in the background and the cat patiently watching your every move, you can vent your anger, calm your nerves, unruffle your feathers. You can fill your kitchen with the smell of baking, fondle every vegetable, sieve every sauce, skin every broad bean. And then you can eat.

Lentil moussaka with mint and harissa

Serves 6

250g green or brown lentils

olive oil

2 medium-sized aubergines

3 medium-sized onions

2 plump, juicy cloves of garlic

1 tsp cumin seeds

5 tomatoes

500ml tomato passata

the leaves from a small bunch of mint

1 heaped tsp (or maybe a little more) harissa paste

500ml bechamel sauce

Rinse the lentils in a sieve under running water and then boil them in deep water until they are tender. This will take about 20 minutes, depending on the type, size and age of your lentils.

Meanwhile, warm a thin layer of olive oil in a casserole, thinly slice the aubergines lengthways (you will need about 12 slices), fry them, a few at a time, till golden on each side, then remove them and put them to one side. Peel and roughly chop the onions, then cook them in a little olive oil in the same casserole till they start to soften, then add the garlic and the cumin seeds and continue cooking for 10 to 15 minutes over a moderate heat till all is soft and fragrant.

Put a small slit in the top of each tomato and then put them in a deep bowl and pour a kettle of boiling water over them. Leave them for a couple of minutes then lift each one out with a draining spoon and peel away the skin. Chop the tomatoes roughly and add them to the onions, then let them soften a while before pouring in the passata.

Bring the onion and tomato sauce to the boil, adding the harissa, drained lentils and torn-up mint leaves. Taste for seasoning - you will need salt and black pepper - then turn down the heat so that the lentils simmer gently for 10 minutes.

Lay the aubergines in a 32cm baking dish and cover with the lentil sauce. Lay the remaining aubergine slices on top and cover with the bechamel sauce. Bake for 50 minutes at 180 C/gas mark 4 or until bubbling.

Mushroom lasagne with basil and cream

Serves 6

2 onions

4 large, juicy cloves of garlic

a thick slice of butter

10g packet dried porcini

750g mushrooms

a good handful of chopped parsley leaves

150ml cream

4 or 5 tbsps freshly grated Parmesan, plus 3 more for later

750ml bechamel sauce

450g of fresh lasagne

for the basil sauce

60g pine kernels

50g basil leaves

2 cloves of garlic, peeled

enough olive oil to make a thick, spoonable paste

4 tbsps freshly grated Parmesan

Peel and roughly chop the onions, peel and thinly slice the garlic and then set them to cook in a deep-sided frying pan with a thick slice of butter. Cover the dried porcini with warm water - barely 100ml - and leave to soak. After 20 minutes, the onions and garlic will have softened and taken on an almost translucent quality. Meanwhile, cut the fresh mushrooms into thick slices. To make the basil sauce, either blitz the pine kernels, basil, garlic, olive oil and Parmesan in a food processor, or do it the hard way by pounding the garlic with a little salt in a mortar, then mashing in the basil, pine kernels and olive oil to make a rough and slightly sloppy paste.

Stir the sliced mushrooms into the onions and garlic and partially cover with a lid. The mushrooms should colour and soften. Add the reconstituted porcini and their soaking water, then the parsley, 4 or 5 tablespoons of Parmesan and the cream. Season with salt and pepper and simmer and stir until the cream has thickened.

Spread a few spoonfuls of the bechamel sauce on the bottom of a large dish (I used a 40cm oval baking dish) then cover with a layer of the pasta. Spoon on half the mushroom filling, cover with another layer of pasta, a second layer of mushrooms and cream, and top with a third single layer of pasta. Spread the basil sauce over the pasta, then smooth the remaining bechamel sauce over and cover with the remaining Parmesan. Bake at 180 C/ gas mark 4 for 50 minutes or until golden and bubbling.

webTitle: A second term? I'll be lucky

fields.headline: A second term? I'll be lucky
fields.standfirst:
Ken Livingstone seems certain to become London's Mayor this week. Jay Rayner put our five key capital questions to him

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone seems certain to become London's Mayor this week.  Jay Rayner put our five key capital questions to him
fields.body:
On the day we meet, Ken Livingstone is in the headlines again, this time for comparing deaths as a result of international capitalism to those under Hitler's rule in Germany. He stops talking to listen to the radio news in the café near his borrowed campaign offices off Oxford Street. It is a mixture of condemnations from business leaders and members of the Jewish community. Livingstone shrugs. Just politics as usual, and it doesn't appear to be having any impact on his poll lead.

'After two years campaigning for this job,' he later says, 'there's nothing new. There are no new questions. Unless you go and give a talk at a school. Then you get new questions. Kids always come up with something new.' Such long experience of providing the answers should, then, have proved ideal training for our five questions for the candidates for Mayor of London.

Are you going to take regeneration in east London seriously?

After a long diagnosis of the problem - the death of the London docks, failure of investment, mismanagement of government subsidy - Livingstone finally turns to the cure. For the first time, but certainly not the last, he draws on his experience as leader of the Greater London Council during the Eighties. 'We found at the GLC that if you give people a second chance to get an education they will jump at it,' he says. 'I think you've got to have a drive like that. The key lies in training and then bringing them into employment. You've got to get these people into the pattern of work.'

The problem is, he says, that the private sector is not geared up for the in-work training that such a policy entails. 'But local government, the health service and the voluntary sector does have the capacity to employ people and they need to be given money to do it.' Once people have these skills they can then swap into the private sector, he says. He also wants to see a new programme of council house building. Money for both schemes would come from the £284 million of Strategic Regeneration Grants the Mayor has at his disposal.

How will you make Londoners happier and therefore healthier?

'On the day of the Budget London's hospitals had a collective deficit of £100m and some of them were technically bankrupt,' he says. 'The Budget gave £106m but unless you increase the baseline funding the deficits will just return.' He sets off on a long speech about the underfunding of the health service, London's failure to receive a proportionate cut of the health spending budget and calls on voters to 'name and shame governments that discriminate against Londoners'.

This is all very entertaining but has nothing to do with the job to which Livingstone hopes to be elected this week. The mayor will have no responsibility for primary health care services, the funding of which remains with the various trusts. When this is pointed out to him the candidate instead talks up his congestion charging policy which, he says, 'would reduce pollution. We also need to beautify the city. Some streets have no trees and on hot summer days the temperature will be much lower if they had trees. Also I will encourage people to get out and walk more in London. One of the nicest things you can do in London on a Sunday is have lunch by the river and go for a walk.'

Despite repeated prompting he did not, at any point, raise poor housing, low pay and unemployment, the issues broadly regarded as having the greatest impact on public health. Clearly Livingstone does not think that addressing these problems is a public health issue - as the other three main candidates all do. Or, if he does, he is not inclined to say so.

How will you make the lives of Londoners more beautiful?

The key here, he says, is proper use of London's parks. Once again, an opportunity for GLC references: 'What people remember from the GLC is the various concerts we staged. A quarter of a million Londoners coming together. And the gardening exhibitions.' That, he says, will return. In addition he will do something about the under-use of London's facilities by cutting the costs. 'An awful lot of Londoners can't afford to use the facilities. To get into the cinema or the theatre can cost far too much. And charging for museums has turned away more Londoners than tourists. We're going to introduce a Capital Card which will provide cheap entrance to places on Wednesday afternoons.'

Where will the money for all this come from? The £3.3 billion budget under the control of the Greater London Authority is merely money already being spent in London. 'We have an arts budget,' he says, simply. 'At the moment it's minuscule, £16m. It will have to increase. By the last day I want it to be £160m.' 'Orinoco Flow' by Enya comes on the radio. Livingstone stops again. 'We'll have a concert and we'll get Enya there,' he says. This may or may not be a vote winner.

How will you get London moving?

Livingstone dismisses claims by other candidates that a paper-based - as against electronic - congestion charging system is unworkable. 'We can't wait for an electronic system to be ready. There may be some evasion of the charge under a paper-based system but the vast majority of people are honest.' As to the congestion charge he favours the proposal put forward by London First, the business development group: £5 a day for a small area of central London. 'But I will put it out to consultation.'

He also wants to use bonds to fund regeneration of the Tube, cut fares (as he did at the GLC), get conductors back on buses and clean them up. He accepts that all this will cost. 'You've got to get more money,' he says, eventually. 'You can't solve London's problems without it.'

So where will this cash come from? Finally we get to the heart of Livingstone's policy. He does not believe the £3.3bn budget he will have to work with is enough. 'London gives far more in taxes than it receives,' he says. 'It's no good just bleeding London dry. The Mayor's going to lead the campaign to get extra money. The Government is currently thinking of cutting money spent in London by £800m. That will actually make the situation worse. The Mayor needs to have a bare knuckle fight to stop that happening.'

Is he really the candidate best placed to get money out of a Government that so clearly dislikes him? 'Politicians respect strength,' he says. 'If you make their life more difficult they'll pay you more respect.' He says Tony Blair and Gordon Brown will be scared of him.

How will you make London safer?

During the Eighties, Livingstone says, there were 28,000 police officers in London serving 6.5 million people. Now there are 26,000 serving 7 million. 'There aren't the police officers to get the job done. We need to get back to the 28,000 level. And you've got to pay them more. The cost of living in London is 26 per cent higher than elsewhere. Police officers want a rise of £5,000 and they ought to get it.'

Does this mean, once again, banging on Gordon Brown's door to get the cash. 'Yup. It means banging on Gordon's door. Unless you can persuade police officers to work for nothing.' He also wants an audit of police resources to see where they are spending their money and he wants more officers on bicycles. As to morale within the Metropolitan police: 'I'd fight to support their pay demands. I'd support all public sector workers.'

It is hard to escape the impression that Ken Livingstone is campaigning to do a different job than that advertised: one with far greater powers and far more money to spend. I ask him if he is disappointed by the way the position has been framed. 'Come back in 25 years time and I suspect it will be much more like the job of Mayor of New York,' he says.

'The London Mayor will run health, schools, everything. And we'll be the model for regional government in Britain.' And will he be its Mayor then? He shakes his head. 'I suspect a city like London changes so rapidly it burns up its politicians. I'll be lucky to get a second term.' He hesitates. 'Maybe I'll be lucky to get a first.' It is the one thing he says without any conviction whatsoever.

What the candidates stand for

Frank Dobson

Transport

No to congestion charging at least for first four years. Funding of Tube regeneration by Public Private Partnership.

Crime

Will bring back police housing allowance to aid recruitment.

Public Health

A Chief Medical Officer and affordable social housing.

Life of the city

Will plant 100,000 trees. Wants parks areas that are for adults accompanied by children only.

Economy

Committed to creating 100,000 new jobs. Will work to get more cash out of Europe for London.

Big Idea

Vote for me because I've been in the Cabinet and have a better relationship with the Treasury

Ken Livingstone

Transport

Wants congestion charging as soon as possible and wants to fund the Tube through bonds.

Crime

Wants the Government to cough up more money for police pay.

Public Health

Wants more money for hospitals even though it's not in the mayor's remit. Believes Londoners should take more walks.

Life of the city

Wants to stage more concerts in London's parks. Will book Enya to appear.

Economy

Will get the unemployed into jobs in the public and voluntary sector. Wants more government cash.

Big Idea

Vote for me and I'll demand more money from the Government.

Steve Norris

Transport

Rejects congestion charging and believes some Public Private Partnership is way to fund Tube.

Crime

Wants more money for police pay. Pledges to replace the 906 officers who have left Met since Labour was elected in May 1997.

Public Health

Will appoint a commissioner for public health. Will demand more government money for NHS.

Life of the city

Will appoint commissioners for public spaces and architecture.

Economy

Wants to target regeneration grants at skills training.

Big Idea

Vote for me and I'll get things done, even if I have to dump Conservative Party policy to do it.

Susan Kramer

Transport

Congestion charging, probably £5 per day for central London. Believes in bonds to fund the tube.

Crime

Wants a Community Constabulary uniting park keepers, traffic wardens, caretakers to curb anti-social behaviour. Higher police pay.

Public Health

Will appoint a Chief Medical Officer to audit resources.

Life of the city

Wants 100,000 new affordable homes, paid for by investment from new community banks.

Economy

Wants to set up community banks to invest in specific local areas.

Big Idea

Vote for me because I'm a banker and I know about raising money.
