fields.headline: Annual events
fields.standfirst: Too much trouble, too garish, too short-lived? Nonsense, annuals bring a welcome dose of colour and scent
fields.trailText: Too much trouble, too garish, too short-lived? Nonsense, annuals bring a welcome dose of colour and scent
fields.body:
I travelled back from Scotland last Saturday night having spent a week taking part in the restoration of a Thomas Mawson garden near Crieff. This involves landscaping on a heroic scale in a heroic setting and, on the plane, I allowed myself to cherry-pick the perfect job to do when I got back. To my own amazement, it turned out to be cutting the grass. This had exactly the right soothing, easy rhythm that allowed me to cover the length of the garden on a lovely spring evening, and yet acknowledge that I was exhausted and good for nothing, really.

The crab and pear blossom is stunning and Sarah had cut a huge branch of crab apple for a vase in the centre of the kitchen table. The business of cutting flowers is always a battle between house and garden - the gain of one inevitably means the loss of the other - but this was tucked in the hedge, and it was the right decision. If we had more space, I would love a cutting garden where there could be rows of flowers dedicated to decorating the house. As it is, we try to be generous with our planting, so that there is enough to spare for great bunches of flowers without reducing the borders to shreds and tatters.

While I was in Crieff, Gareth hired a chipper and chipped the enormous pile of woody material that has accumulated over the winter - part prunings and part the result of alterations that removed a lot of hornbeam hedging. The sprawling heap is now a neat block perhaps 2m square and 1m high. We will leave it until the autumn and use it to mulch the hedges over the winter.

We have lifted a section of the terrace where we eat and moved the York stone to the new bit of the jewel garden. This gives us a place to sit there (in what was the chicken run only a couple of years ago) and increases the border in the walled garden. It is exciting on both accounts. Any extra planting space is pounced upon, and this corner had been chosen for paving precisely because it was so sunny.

As it turned out, the old terrace was too hot in the middle of the day (when we are most likely to eat outside) and the butter used to melt and people would bake. I'll dig the soil, add plenty of compost and plant it up with roses, rosemary, lavender, verbascums, melianthus, poppies and, in the autumn, tulips for next spring.

The new site for the paving has an experimental cover made from a post at each corner of the square and bean sticks nailed an inch apart over the top. I remember sitting under a similar shelter in Mexico - it was the business. But it is experimental at the moment because it does rather spoil the view across the river to the church. Which matters more, shelter or view? Time will tell.

It is odd how some people still have a thing about annuals. Too much trouble, too garish, too ephemeral, too common. Annuals fire horticultural snobbery - which is always on a hair trigger at the best of times - in the same way that hanging baskets and garden ornaments do. And yet garden centres will sell more trays of annuals over the coming month or two than all their other plants put together over the whole year.

Somebody out there likes them - I certainly do. We grow hundreds and hundreds of them, and would grow more if we had the space. It's what you do with them that counts, and I see annuals as an integral part of the overall floral mix in our borders. Ignore or dismiss them and you impoverish your garden. The key is to choose annuals that work with your other plants rather than restrict yourself to a 'display' that is not harmonised with anything in particular.

Roger Phillips and Martyn Rix, in the introduction to their excellent book, Annuals (Macmillan, £19.99), make the point that most modern cultivars tend to be lower, stockier and more garish than their wild relatives because the flowers are tested in open fields, where taller plants would blow over and more subtle colours would become lost. However, few gardens are like open-trials fields and the plants have a very different effect when brought into the restricted, sheltered environment of a back garden. The reasons that growers persist in this is because their biggest customers are not garden centres but local authorities and corporations buying in bulk for summer titivation of public areas.

An annual is any plant that germinates, grows, flowers and sets seed in the same growing season - usually between March and October in this country, although some annuals, such as field poppies and corn marigolds, can string together a complete life-cycle in around three months. Drought will speed up the cycle as they race to set seed before the lack of water kills them.

In the wild, most annuals are found in cornfields or on dry, open slopes. They are rarely found in tightly packed places interspersed with shrubs, or in damp conditions - both of which are closer to the conditions of the average back garden than a cornfield. And most annuals prefer to be dry and in full sun when they are in flower - a summer like the one that we all endured in 1998 reduces many to soggy tissue.

My own preference is to use annuals as a deliberate part of controlled colour schemes, interweaving them with perennials, shrubs and bulbs. At this time of year, it is easier to do this with biennials (plants that complete their life cycle in two years) such as forget-me-nots ( Myosotis sylvatica ) and wallflowers ( Cheiranthus cheiri , although also Erysimum cheiri ), which grow outside our window among 'Queen of the Night' and 'Black Parrot' tulips, and purple honesty ( Lunaria annua ), in the shade of a huge Rosa rugosa . It will not be long before the Iceland poppies are out, and the sweet peas are starting to put on growth now that their roots are stretching out into the soil and they should start flowering in June.

The greenhouse and cold frames are now crammed with seedlings of sunflowers, cosmos, cornflowers, tithonias, leonotis, salvias, cleomes, tobacco plants (only sylvestris ), lupins, helianthus, rudbeckia and cerinthe. Poppies have been sown direct (they intensely dislike being moved about, even as tiny seedlings) and the purple orache has seeded itself like a lovely weed, exactly matching the silvery purple of the negrita tulips. Another annual that can be relied upon to pop up everywhere year after year (as long as the ground is cultivated) is the fabulous Verbena bonariensis , which will flower from July through to November.

Most of these are half-hardy, and it would not be safe to put them outside yet, as we are likely to get frost until mid-May. The hardy annuals are only grown indoors because they are less prone to slug attack that way. It means more handling but guarantees more plants. I also find that if you have a fairly mature border, annuals grown in pots or plugs can be planted more accurately than any amount of direct seed sowing.

Which is not to say that sowing direct is a bad idea, especially if you live in a mild area or if your garden is reasonably sheltered and dry. For the new garden or novice, nothing is more satisfying than a few packets of seeds sown into soil that has been dug and raked to a fine tilth. Do not feed the soil with manure, as that will only produce lots of green growth without any extra flowers. The best way is to sow in zig-zags, crosses, circles or lines to differentiate the growing seedlings from weeds. The only hard bit is to sow much more thinly than seems sensible and then to be ruthless enough to thin the seedlings further so that each plant has room to expand. Poppies, cornflowers, helianthus, eschscholzia, phacelia, nasturtiums, calendula, nigella and zinnias, for example, will all do well when sown directly where they are to flower.

In an age of instant garden gratification and magic transformation, no flowers do more in less time than annuals. A few packets of seed are certainly the cheapest and easiest way to a makeover.

Thompson & Morgan special offer

Observer readers can order six Nicotiana sylvestris (otherwise known as the tobacco plant) for £9.99, including p&p. They reach a height of 1.5m, with a spread of 60cm. Send a cheque payable to Thompson & Morgan (Young Plants) Ltd to: Observer Offers, OBT24, PO Box 89, St Leonards-0n-Sea, East Sussex TN38 9ZX, or call 0870 870 1362 with credit-card details. Last order date: 30 May. Allow up to 28 days for delivery

Your roots: How to make the most of your annuals

Hardy annuals withstand frost but need light to grow and flower. They are best sown or planted in March or April and will flower until they have set all their seed. Dead-heading flowers as they fade will encourage them to keep on flowering for longer. Opium poppies, nasturtiums, nigellas, cornflowers, sweet peas and corn cockles are all hardy annuals.

Half-hardy annuals are frost-tender and should only be planted or sown after the middle of May. The first frosts of autumn kill them. Bells of Ireland, zinnias, nicotianas, sunflowers, busy Lizzies and snapdragons are half-hardy annuals.

Preparing annuals for cutting

 Make extra sure of feeding them (to encourage vigorous plants with large flowers and long stems).

 Thin them carefully, cutting selectively to thin them out throughout the flowering season.

 Sow two or three successive crops, starting in March and finishing at the end of May.

Climbing annuals

Sweet peas ( Lathyrus odoratus ) are the best of all annual climbers. Avoid modern varieties and stick to reliably scented plants such as the Spencer group.

Sweet peas grow well up a trellis, netting, or in a pot up a wigwam of canes. If planted at the base of a wall, they'll need lots of water. They like the richest soil possible. If you keep picking the flowers, they will flower on into August.

Black-eyed Susan ( Thunbergia alata ) grows to 10ft and has yellow or orange flowers with chocolate centres. Ipomoea tricolor (morning glory) is easy if raised in warm, humid conditions, then planted in sun. The canary creeper ( Tropaeolum peregrinum ) grows fast with yellow flowers.

Tall annuals

Any annual growing over 4ft will need some support. But they can be very useful at the back of a border to stagger the height of flowering. Hollyhock ( Alcea rosea ) will reach 8ft and is excellent for a softer, cottage-garden feel. Sunflowers ( Helianthus annuus ) are not all giants and not all sunny yellow. 'Velvet Queen' is a glorious russet and 'Lemon Queen' is lemon yellow. Both grow to about 5ft.

Nicotiana sylvestris has my favourite scent of all plants and grows to 4ft or 5ft. Cosmos bipinnatis is a tall, delicately branched plant with beautifully elegant flowers. They need dead-heading daily to prolong flowering. Try the white 'Purity'.

Scented annuals

Because they are so desperate for pollination, scent is often an important part of the annual's armoury. Use it! These are just a few of my favourite scented annuals: Nicotiana sylvestris , lemon verbena and Lippia citriodora . Night-scented stock ( Matthiola incana ) has a warm, spicy scent and the fragrance of the evening primrose ( Oenothera biennis ) is much stronger at night.

Annuals for shade

Although most annuals really need as much sun as possible, some have adapted to grow in shade. My favourite is the white foxglove, Digitalis purpurea f. albiflora , which will gracefully grow in almost complete shade and, like night-scented stock, dry shade at that.

Tobacco plants all grow in shade (but do not necessarily prefer it). The monkey flower, mimulus, is completely happy without direct light. Evening primrose grows anywhere with some moisture or heavy soil - it seeds very freely.

Any extra planting space is pounced upon, and this corner had been chosen for paving precisely because it was so sunny. As it turned out, the old terrace was too hot in the middle of the day (when we are most likely to eat outside) and the butter used to melt and people would bake. I'll dig the soil, add plenty of compost and plant it up with roses, rosemary, lavender, verbascums, melianthus, poppies and, in the autumn, tulips for next spring. The new site for the paving has an experimental cover made from a post at each corner of the square and bean sticks nailed an inch apart over the top. I remember sitting under a similar shelter in Mexico - it was the business. But it is experimental at the moment because it does rather spoil the view across the river to the church. Which matters more, shelter or view? Time will tell. It is odd how some people still have a thing about annuals. Too much trouble, too garish, too ephemeral, too common. Annuals fire horticultural snobbery - which is always on a hair trigger at the best of times - in the same way that hanging baskets and garden ornaments do. And yet garden centres will sell more trays of annuals over the coming month or two than all their other plants put together over the whole year. Somebody out there likes them - I certainly do. We grow hundreds and hundreds of them, and would grow more if we had the space. It's what you do with them that counts, and I see annuals as an integral part of the overall floral mix in our borders. Ignore or dismiss them and you impoverish your garden. The key is to choose annuals that work with your other plants rather than restrict yourself to a 'display' that is not harmonised with anything in particular. Roger Phillips and Martyn Rix, in the introduction to their excellent book, Annuals (Macmillan, £19.99), make the point that most modern cultivars tend to be lower, stockier and more garish than their wild relatives because the flowers are tested in open fields, where taller plants would blow over and more subtle colours would become lost. However, few gardens are like open-trials fields and the plants have a very different effect when brought into the restricted, sheltered environment of a back garden. The reasons that growers persist in this is because their biggest customers are not garden centres but local authorities and corporations buying in bulk for summer titivation of public areas. An annual is any plant that germinates, grows, flowers and sets seed in the same growing season - usually between March and October in this country, although some annuals, such as field poppies and corn marigolds, can string together a complete life-cycle in around three months. Drought will speed up the cycle as they race to set seed before the lack of water kills them. In the wild, most annuals are found in cornfields or on dry, open slopes. They are rarely found in tightly packed places interspersed with shrubs, or in damp conditions - both of which are closer to the conditions of the average back garden than a cornfield. And most annuals prefer to be dry and in full sun when they are in flower - a summer like the one that we all endured in 1998 reduces many to soggy tissue. My own preference is to use annuals as a deliberate part of controlled colour schemes, interweaving them with perennials, shrubs and bulbs. At this time of year, it is easier to do this with biennials (plants that complete their life cycle in two years) such as forget-me-nots ( Myosotis sylvatica ) and wallflowers ( Cheiranthus cheiri , although also Erysimum cheiri ), which grow outside our window among 'Queen of the Night' and 'Black Parrot' tulips, and purple honesty ( Lunaria annua ), in the shade of a huge Rosa rugosa . It will not be long before the Iceland poppies are out, and the sweet peas are starting to put on growth now that their roots are stretching out into the soil and they should start flowering in June. The greenhouse and cold frames are now crammed with seedlings of sunflowers, cosmos, cornflowers, tithonias, leonotis, salvias, cleomes, tobacco plants (only sylvestris ), lupins, helianthus, rudbeckia and cerinthe. Poppies have been sown direct (they intensely dislike being moved about, even as tiny seedlings) and the purple orache has seeded itself like a lovely weed, exactly matching the silvery purple of the negrita tulips. Another annual that can be relied upon to pop up everywhere year after year (as long as the ground is cultivated) is the fabulous Verbena bonariensis , which will flower from July through to November. Most of these are half-hardy, and it would not be safe to put them outside yet, as we are likely to get frost until mid-May. The hardy annuals are only grown indoors because they are less prone to slug attack that way. It means more handling but guarantees more plants. I also find that if you have a fairly mature border, annuals grown in pots or plugs can be planted more accurately than any amount of direct seed sowing. Which is not to say that sowing direct is a bad idea, especially if you live in a mild area or if your garden is reasonably sheltered and dry. For the new garden or novice, nothing is more satisfying than a few packets of seeds sown into soil that has been dug and raked to a fine tilth. Do not feed the soil with manure, as that will only produce lots of green growth without any extra flowers. The best way is to sow in zig-zags, crosses, circles or lines to differentiate the growing seedlings from weeds. The only hard bit is to sow much more thinly than seems sensible and then to be ruthless enough to thin the seedlings further so that each plant has room to expand. Poppies, cornflowers, helianthus, eschscholzia, phacelia, nasturtiums, calendula, nigella and zinnias, for example, will all do well when sown directly where they are to flower. In an age of instant garden gratification and magic transformation, no flowers do more in less time than annuals. A few packets of seed are certainly the cheapest and easiest way to a makeover. Last order date: 30 May. Allow up to 28 days for delivery Your roots: How to make the most of your annuals Hardy annuals withstand frost but need light to grow and flower. They are best sown or planted in March or April and will flower until they have set all their seed. Dead-heading flowers as they fade will encourage them to keep on flowering for longer. Opium poppies, nasturtiums, nigellas, cornflowers, sweet peas and corn cockles are all hardy annuals. Half-hardy annuals are frost-tender and should only be planted or sown after the middle of May. The first frosts of autumn kill them. Bells of Ireland, zinnias, nicotianas, sunflowers, busy Lizzies and snapdragons are half-hardy annuals. Preparing annuals for cutting  Make extra sure of feeding them (to encourage vigorous plants with large flowers and long stems).  Thin them carefully, cutting selectively to thin them out throughout the flowering season.  Sow two or three successive crops, starting in March and finishing at the end of May. Climbing annuals Sweet peas ( Lathyrus odoratus ) are the best of all annual climbers. Avoid modern varieties and stick to reliably scented plants such as the Spencer group. Sweet peas grow well up a trellis, netting, or in a pot up a wigwam of canes. If planted at the base of a wall, they'll need lots of water. They like the richest soil possible. If you keep picking the flowers, they will flower on into August. Black-eyed Susan ( Thunbergia alata ) grows to 10ft and has yellow or orange flowers with chocolate centres. Ipomoea tricolor (morning glory) is easy if raised in warm, humid conditions, then planted in sun. The canary creeper ( Tropaeolum peregrinum ) grows fast with yellow flowers. Tall annuals Any annual growing over 4ft will need some support. But they can be very useful at the back of a border to stagger the height of flowering. Hollyhock ( Alcea rosea ) will reach 8ft and is excellent for a softer, cottage-garden feel. Sunflowers ( Helianthus annuus ) are not all giants and not all sunny yellow. 'Velvet Queen' is a glorious russet and 'Lemon Queen' is lemon yellow. Both grow to about 5ft. Nicotiana sylvestris has my favourite scent of all plants and grows to 4ft or 5ft. Cosmos bipinnatis is a tall, delicately branched plant with beautifully elegant flowers. They need dead-heading daily to prolong flowering. Try the white 'Purity'. Scented annuals Because they are so desperate for pollination, scent is often an important part of the annual's armoury. Use it! These are just a few of my favourite scented annuals: Nicotiana sylvestris , lemon verbena and Lippia citriodora . Night-scented stock ( Matthiola incana ) has a warm, spicy scent and the fragrance of the evening primrose ( Oenothera biennis ) is much stronger at night. Annuals for shade Although most annuals really need as much sun as possible, some have adapted to grow in shade. My favourite is the white foxglove, Digitalis purpurea f. albiflora , which will gracefully grow in almost complete shade and, like night-scented stock, dry shade at that. Tobacco plants all grow in shade (but do not necessarily prefer it). The monkey flower, mimulus, is completely happy without direct light. Evening primrose grows anywhere with some moisture or heavy soil - it seeds very freely.
